food_suggestions_3: Isabgol (Psyllium husk) 1-2 spoons in warm water at night. Mild laxative like Cremaffin if needed occasionally.

column18: HAVE: Papaya;oats;green leafy vegetables;warm water in morning. AVOID: Maida (white flour) products;processed snacks;red meat.
column19: Walk for 20 mins daily to stimulate bowels. Squatting position (Indian toilet style) helps pass stool easier.
column20: Persistent constipation can make you feel permanently bloated and sluggish. Your gut is moving too slowly.
column21: Stronger laxatives like Dulcolax (Bisacodyl) 5mg at night (short term only). Continue high fiber diet.
column22: See doctor if you have unexplained weight loss;thin pencil-like stools;or family history of colon cancer.
column23: HAVE: Prunes (dried plums);flaxseeds;plenty of fluids (3-4 liters/day). AVOID: Dairy if it tends to 'bind' you.

column25: Severe;chronic constipation can lead to piles (hemorrhoids) or fecal impaction (hard mass stuck inside).

column27: URGENT: Consult if you have severe abdominal pain WITH vomiting and absolutely no gas/stool passing (intestinal obstruction).

keywords: migraine;adha sir dard;half head pain;one sided headache;aura;flashing lights before headache;nausea with headache;sensitive to light
description_1: A migraine is more than just a headache; it's often a throbbing pain on one side, sometimes with nausea.
medicine_1: Take analgesic early: Naproxen 250mg or Paracetamol-Caffeine combo (Saridon) at very start of pain.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if your usual meds don't work anymore;or migraine pattern changes drastically.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Ginger tea for nausea;magnesium rich foods (spinach/almonds). AVOID: Common triggers: aged cheese;chocolate;red wine;MSG.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Rest immediately in a dark;quiet room. Sleep is often the best cure for an attack.
description_2: Migraines can last for days (status migrainosus) and be very debilitating. You might be sensitive to light/sound.
medicine_2: Specific anti-migraine triptans (like Rizact-10) ONLY if previously prescribed by a doctor for acute attacks.
doctor_consult_2: See neurologist if having >4 attacks per month for preventative medication.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Small frequent meals to avoid blood sugar dips. Stay hydrated. AVOID: Strong smells (perfumes/petrol) that might trigger it.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Keep a 'migraine diary' to find your triggers. Regular sleep schedule is crucial.
description_3: Severe migraines can mimic strokes (complex migraine) with numbness or slurred speech.
medicine_3: Preventative daily meds (like Propranolol/Amitriptyline) might be needed if chronic.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if headache is sudden 'thunderclap' (reaches max pain in 60 seconds);or accompanied by fever/stiff neck.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Bland diet during attack if nauseous. AVOID: Caffeine withdrawal (if you are a regular coffee drinker).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Consider tinted glasses if fluorescent lights are a trigger. Practice relaxation techniques.

keywords: dengue;breakbone fever;macchar ka bukhar;mosquito fever;pain behind eyes;severe joint pain;platelets down;red rash
description_1: Dengue is a viral infection from mosquitoes. It causes high fever and intense body aches ('breakbone fever').
medicine_1: Paracetamol ONLY for fever (Crocin). DO NOT TAKE Ibuprofen/Aspirin as they increase bleeding risk.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately if you suspect dengue for a blood test (NS1 antigen/Platelet count).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Papaya leaf juice (often used traditionally for platelets);coconut water;kiwi fruit;lots of fluids. AVOID: Dark colored foods (might confuse with internal bleeding in stool).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Complete bed rest. Use mosquito nets to prevent spreading it to others via mosquitoes.
description_2: As fever drops (critical phase around day 3-5), watch for warning signs like severe belly pain or vomiting.
medicine_2: Continue strict hydration with ORS. Monitor urine frequency (should be every 4-6 hours).
doctor_consult_2: See doctor DAILY during critical phase to monitor platelet count if it is dropping rapidly.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Easy to digest nutritious soft diet (khichdi;soups). AVOID: oily/spicy food that might irritate stomach.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Check for bleeding spots on skin (petechiae) or bleeding gums while brushing.
description_3: Severe Dengue (DHF) involves plasma leakage;fluid accumulation;and severe bleeding. It is life-threatening.
medicine_3: Hospitalization required for IV fluid management if oral intake is poor or platelets <20,000.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if severe persistent vomiting;severe abdominal pain;cold clammy skin;or drowsiness occurs.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: IV fluids in hospital. AVOID: heavy activity even weeks after recovery due to post-dengue fatigue.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Platelet transfusion is only needed in rare severe cases with active bleeding; don't panic just about the number.

keywords: acne;pimples;muhase;zits;breakouts;oily skin;whiteheads;blackheads;cystic acne;spots on face
description_1: Acne is caused by oil and dead skin clogging pores. It's common in teenagers but can happen at any age.
medicine_1: Wash face twice daily with salicylic acid cleanser (like Saslic DS). Apply Benzoyl Peroxide 2.5% gel on active spots at night.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if OTC products don't work after 3 months;or if acne is leaving deep scars/pits.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Low glycemic foods;plenty of water;fruits. AVOID: High sugar/dairy (can trigger acne in some people);whey protein.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't pop pimples! It pushes infection deeper and causes scars. Change pillowcases frequently.
description_2: Persistent or cystic acne (large painful red bumps under skin) needs medical treatment to prevent permanent scarring.
medicine_2: Dermatologist might prescribe topical retinoids (Adapalene) or antibiotics (Clindamycin gel).
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist for hormonal check (PCOS) if you are female with irregular periods and jawline acne.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Foods rich in Zinc (seeds;legumes) and Vitamin A (carrots). AVOID: Greasy junk food (though direct link is debated;it's generally good to avoid).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use 'non-comedogenic' (won't clog pores) makeup/sunscreen. Keep hair off your face.
description_3: Severe nodulocystic acne can be painful and emotionally distressing. It requires strong oral medication.
medicine_3: Oral Isotretinoin (Accutane/Sotret) is highly effective but MUST be taken under strict doctor supervision (pregnancy risk).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if a large pimple near eyes/nose becomes extremely swollen;hot and painful (danger triangle infection).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced anti-inflammatory diet. AVOID: abrasive scrubs that irritate inflamed skin.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Be patient; acne treatments take 6-8 weeks to show real results.

keywords: sinus;sinus infection;naak band;heaviness in face;pain near nose;yellow mucus;post nasal drip;blocked head
description_1: Sinusitis is inflammation of the air cavities around your nose. You might feel pressure in your forehead or cheeks.
medicine_1: Steam inhalation 3 times/day is most effective. Saline nasal spray to clear mucus. OTC decongestant (Sudafed) for max 3 days.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if symptoms last >10 days without improvement;or you have high fever with severe facial pain.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Hot soups with ginger/garlic/pepper to thin mucus;warm herbal teas. AVOID: Cold dairy;frozen desserts which might thicken mucus.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use warm compress on face to relieve pain. Sleep with head elevated to drain sinuses.
description_2: Chronic sinusitis means it lasts for weeks. You might have a constant reduced sense of smell or bad breath.
medicine_2: Steroid nasal sprays (like Flomist - prescription needed) can reduce inflammation long-term.
doctor_consult_2: See ENT specialist if you have recurring sinus infections (>3 per year) to check for nasal polyps.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Pineapple (contains bromelain which may reduce swelling). AVOID: Cigarette smoke;polluted air.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use a humidifier in dry weather. Stay well hydrated to keep mucus thin.
description_3: Severe acute sinusitis can rarely spread to eyes or brain if untreated bacterial infection is present.
medicine_3: Antibiotics (like Augmentin) ONLY if bacterial cause confirmed by doctor (thick colored discharge >10 days + fever).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have swelling around eyes;severe forehead headache with confusion;or stiff neck.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Warm fluids constantly. AVOID: flying if possible when severely congested (can cause severe ear/sinus pain).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Neti pot (jal neti) can be very helpful if done correctly with sterile water.

keywords: sprain;moch;twisted ankle;pulled muscle;strain;ligament tear;swelling after fall;hurt wrist;muscle catch
description_1: A sprain is a stretched or torn ligament (like twisting an ankle). It causes pain, swelling, and bruising.
medicine_1: Follow R.I.C.E: Rest;Ice (20 mins every 2 hours);Compression (crepe bandage);Elevation (keep limb above heart level).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you can't bear ANY weight on the limb after 2 hours;or if joint looks misshapen.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Protein for tissue repair;anti-inflammatory foods (turmeric/haldi milk). AVOID: Alcohol (increases swelling initially).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't massage a fresh injury (first 48 hours) - it increases swelling. Don't apply heat initially.
description_2: If pain persists after 3 days, the sprain might be moderate (Grade 2). You might have significant bruising.
medicine_2: Switch from ice to heat after 48-72 hours to increase blood flow for healing. Use Volini spray for relief.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist if instability feels present (joint feels 'loose') or pain doesn't improve in a week.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Collagen rich foods (bone broth) might help ligament healing. AVOID: Returning to sports too quickly.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use crutches if needed to avoid limping. Gentle range-of-motion exercises once pain subsides.
description_3: Severe sprains (Grade 3 - complete tear) can be as bad as a fracture and might need a cast or surgery.
medicine_3: Stronger NSAIDs prescribed by doctor. MRI might be needed to see extent of tear.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if limb is cold;pale;numb (nerve/blood vessel damage);or if you heard a loud 'pop' at time of injury.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Adequate calcium/Vitamin D. AVOID: High impact activities until fully healed (can take months).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Physiotherapy is vital for severe sprains to regain full strength and balance.

keywords: food poisoning;stomach bug;ate bad food;vomiting and loose motion;gastroenteritis;stomach infection;rotten food reaction
description_1: Food poisoning comes from eating contaminated food. It hits fast (within hours) with vomiting, cramps, and diarrhea.
medicine_1: Stop eating solid food for a few hours. Sip ORS or diluted Gatorade to prevent dehydration.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if vomiting is uncontrollable for >12 hours;blood in vomit/stool;or fever >101°F.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Ice chips;clear broth;then BRAT diet (Banana;Rice;Applesauce;Toast). AVOID: Dairy;caffeine;fatty/spicy foods;alcohol.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Rest is crucial. Your body is trying to eject the toxins - don't take anti-diarrhea meds immediately;let it clear out.
description_2: After the initial severe phase, you might feel very weak and have a sensitive stomach for a few days.
medicine_2: Probiotics (like Enterogermina vials) can help restore gut bacteria. Continue focus on hydration.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if signs of severe dehydration: dizziness;dry mouth;no urine for 8 hours;sunken eyes.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Coconut water;plain crackers;boiled potatoes. AVOID: heavy curries or fibrous raw salads.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wash hands thoroughly to avoid spreading it to family. Disinfect toilet after use.
description_3: Severe bacterial food poisoning (like Salmonella/E.coli) can be dangerous, especially for kids/elderly.
medicine_3: Antibiotics may be needed for specific bacterial causes, but often supportive care (fluids) is enough.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if neurological symptoms appear (blurred vision;muscle weakness - rare signs of botulism).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Bland easy-to-digest foods for a week. AVOID: unpasteurized milk;undercooked meat in future.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Reintroduce regular food slowly. Start with half-portions.

keywords: ear pain;kaan dard;earache;blocked ear;ear infection;fluid in ear;swimmer's ear;shooting pain in ear
description_1: Ear pain can be from infection, wax blockage, or even a cold. It can be sharp or dull.
medicine_1: Use a warm compress against the ear. OTC painkiller (Ibuprofen) helps. Don't put oil inside without knowing cause.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have fever;discharge (pus/blood) from ear;or hearing loss.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Soft foods if jaw movement hurts the ear. AVOID: Very crunchy/chewy foods (can aggravate if jaw-related).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Keep ear dry during shower (use cotton ball with Vaseline). DO NOT use ear buds (Q-tips) - they push wax deeper.
description_2: Persistent ear pain, especially in kids, is often an infection (otitis media) following a cold.
medicine_2: Antibiotic ear drops (like Ciplox) ONLY if prescribed. Nasal decongestant drops can sometimes unblock the eustachian tube.
doctor_consult_2: See ENT if you have recurring infections or ringing in ears (tinnitus) with the pain.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods. AVOID: Smoking (irritates eustachian tubes).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Try chewing gum or yawning to 'pop' ears if caused by altitude change/flight.
description_3: Severe ear pain with swelling behind the ear can be mastoiditis (serious bone infection).
medicine_3: Requires urgent IV antibiotics and possibly surgery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if severe dizziness (vertigo);facial paralysis;or sudden total hearing loss occurs.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: swimming until infection clears completely.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Don't ignore ear pain in babies (they might just tug at their ear and cry excessively).

keywords: high BP;hypertension;BP badh gaya;high blood pressure symptoms;pounding head;uneasiness;ghabrahat with BP
description_1: High BP often has no symptoms ('silent killer'), but sudden spikes can cause headaches, anxiety, or nosebleeds.
medicine_1: Sit or lie down immediately and relax. If you have prescribed BP meds and missed a dose;take it now. check BP if you have a machine.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if BP is >180/120 (Hypertensive crisis);or if symptoms don't settle with rest.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Banana (potassium helps lower BP);unsalted nuts;hibiscus tea. AVOID: Salt (pickle/papad/chips);coffee;alcohol;licorice.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Deep slow breathing can temporarily lower BP. Reduce stress in that moment.
description_2: Persistent uncontrolled high BP damages heart/kidneys. You might feel tired or have vision changes.
medicine_2: Regular daily medication (Amlodipine/Telmisartan etc.) as PRESCRIBED. Do not stop because you 'feel fine'.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor for regular monitoring (every 3-6 months if stable). Need to adjust meds if not at target (usually <140/90).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: DASH diet (fruits;veggies;low-fat dairy;whole grains). AVOID: Processed foods high in hidden sodium (sauces/canned soups).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Daily 30 min brisk walk. Quit smoking. Manage stress with yoga/meditation.
description_3: Hypertensive Emergency: Extremely high BP causing organ damage (heart attack/stroke signs).
medicine_3: Requires immediate IV medication in ICU to lower BP gradually (lowering too fast is dangerous).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO ER if accompanied by chest pain;severe shortness of breath;slurred speech;weakness on one side.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Low sodium DASH diet strictly. AVOID: NSAID painkillers (Brufen/Voveran) freely as they can raise BP.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Monitor BP at home at same time daily and keep a log for your doctor.

keywords: low sugar;hypoglycemia;sugar down;shaking;sweating;dizzy due to hunger;feeling faint;diabetic low
description_1: Low blood sugar (usually <70 mg/dL) can happen in diabetics who took too much insulin or skipped a meal.
medicine_1: 'Rule of 15': Eat 15g fast sugar (3 tsp sugar/glucose powder/half cup juice). Wait 15 mins. Recheck. If still low;repeat.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if sugar doesn't rise after 2 treatments;or if episodes happen frequently (meds need adjustment).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Glucose biscuits;fruit juice;regular soda (not diet);candies. AVOID: Chocolate/nuts for INITIAL treatment (fat slows sugar absorption).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Sit down so you don't fall if you faint. Wear a medical ID bracelet if you are diabetic.
description_2: If not treated, you might become confused, slurred, or irritable ('hangry' to extreme).
medicine_2: Once sugar is >70;eat a small snack with protein/carb (half sandwich;few crackers with cheese) to keep it stable.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor to review insulin/tablet dosages if you have unexplained lows, especially at night.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Complex carbs in regular meals to prevent drops. AVOID: Skipping meals;drinking alcohol on empty stomach.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Always carry emergency sugar source (glucose tablets/candies) with you.
description_3: Severe hypoglycemia can lead to seizures, unconsciousness (diabetic coma), and can be fatal.
medicine_3: Glucagon injection kit may be needed for emergencies if patient can't swallow safely.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: CALL AMBULANCE if patient is unconscious or having seizure. DO NOT force food/water by mouth if unconscious (choking risk).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Rub glucose gel/honey on gums if semi-conscious (only if trained to do so). AVOID: delaying treatment.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Teach family/friends how to recognize your signs of low sugar.

keywords: piles;bawasir;hemorrhoids;blood in poop;painful anus;itchy bum;lump near anus;pain while sitting
description_1: Piles are swollen veins in your bottom. They can cause pain, itching, and bright red blood after passing stool.
medicine_1: Sitz bath: Sit in a tub of warm water for 15 mins, 3 times/day. Use OTC piles ointment (Anovate/Shield) for relief.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if bleeding is heavy;stools are black/tarry (indicates bleeding higher up);or pain is unbearable.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: High fiber (oats;figs;isabgol);plenty of water to keep stool soft. AVOID: Spicy foods (burns!);constipating foods (maida/red meat).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't strain on the toilet. Don't sit on toilet for long periods (no phone in washroom!). Use moist wipes instead of rough paper.
description_2: Persistent piles can prolapse (come outside). They might need to be pushed back in gently.
medicine_2: Stool softeners (Lactulose) can prevent straining. Flavonoid tablets (Daflon) are sometimes prescribed for acute flare-ups.
doctor_consult_2: See surgeon if they don't improve with home care in 2 weeks or if a painful hard lump forms (thrombosed pile).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Prune juice;fruits with skin (pears/apples). AVOID: Heavy weight lifting (increases abdominal pressure).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use a donut cushion for sitting if painful. lose weight if obese to reduce pelvic pressure.
description_3: Severe/Thrombosed piles can be intensely painful due to a blood clot forming inside.
medicine_3: Might require a minor procedure to drain the clot or surgery (hemorrhoidectomy) for permanent fix.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if large amount of blood loss causes dizziness/fainting.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Liquid/soft diet during severe flare-ups. AVOID: ignoring constipation—it's the root cause.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Regular exercise helps bowel movement and reduces pressure on veins.

keywords: asthma;dama;wheezing;saans fulna;breathlessness;chest tight;whistling sound when breathing;short of breath;asthma flare
description_1: Asthma causes your airways to narrow and swell. You might hear a whistling sound (wheeze) when breathing out.
medicine_1: Use Rescue Inhaler (usually Blue - Salbutamol/Asthalin) immediately: 2-4 puffs with a spacer. Sit upright;don't lie down.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if rescue inhaler doesn't last for 4 hours;or if you need it >2 times a week (asthma is not well controlled).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Warm caffeinated drink (coffee can mildly open airways in emergency if no inhaler - NOT a replacement). AVOID: Cold air;allergens (dust/pets);smoke.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Stay calm;panic makes breathing harder. Perform pursed-lip breathing (like blowing out a candle slowly).
description_2: If attack persists, you might have difficulty speaking in full sentences. Chest feels very tight.
medicine_2: Repeat rescue inhaler every 20 minutes for up to 1 hour if needed while seeking help. severely.
doctor_consult_2: See pulmonologist for a Preventer inhaler (usually steroid - brown/purple) to use DAILY to stop attacks before they start.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Magnesium rich foods might help. AVOID: Sulfites in dried fruits/wine if they are a trigger for you.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use a peak flow meter at home to monitor lung function daily. keep house free of dust mites/mold.
description_3: Severe Asthma Attack (Status Asthmaticus) is life-threatening. Lips/fingernails might turn blue.
medicine_3: Needs hospital treatment with oxygen;nebulizers;and IV steroids.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: CALL AMBULANCE if struggling to breathe even after inhaler;can't speak;or becoming drowsy/confused.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Easy to eat foods during recovery. AVOID: NSAID painkillers (can trigger asthma in some).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Always carry your rescue inhaler everywhere. Ensure you know correct inhaler technique (ask doctor/pharmacist).

keywords: neck pain;gardan dard;cervical;stiff neck;spondylitis;pain radiating to arm;text neck;crick in neck
description_1: Neck pain is often from poor posture (looking down at phone), sleeping wrong, or stress.
medicine_1: Gentle neck stretches (slowly look left/right/up/down). Apply heat pack. fix your posture immediately.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if pain shoots down your arm into fingers (radiculopathy);or accompanied by numbness/tingling.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods (ginger/turmeric). AVOID: Inflammatory processed sugar/trans fats.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Adjust computer monitor to eye level. Don't tuck phone between ear and shoulder. Use a supportive (not too high) pillow.
description_2: Persistent pain might be cervical spondylosis (arthritis of neck). You might feel grinding sounds when turning head.
medicine_2: Physiotherapy usually needed for strengthening neck muscles. Muscle relaxants might be prescribed for acute spasms.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist if you have loss of grip strength in hands or balance issues while walking (rare severe spinal cord compression).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Calcium/Vitamin D for bone health. AVOID: Carrying heavy shoulder bags on one side constantly.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Take frequent breaks from desk work to move your neck. frequent mobile use with bent neck ('text neck') is a major cause.
description_3: Severe neck pain with fever and inability to touch chin to chest could be Meningitis (EMERGENCY).
medicine_3: Meningitis requires immediate hospitalization and IV antibiotics.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult IMMediately if accompanied by high fever;severe headache;sensitivity to light;rash.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Soft diet if chewing aggravates pain. AVOID: driving if you can't turn your head freely.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Ergonomic chair and desk setup is crucial for long-term relief.

keywords: chickenpox;mata;varicella;itchy blisters;water filled bumps;red spots all over;contagious rash;viral rash kids
description_1: Chickenpox is a highly contagious viral infection causing an incredibly itchy, blister-like rash all over.
medicine_1: Calamine lotion for itching. Paracetamol for fever. Trim fingernails short to prevent scratching and secondary infection.
doctor_consult_1: Consult to confirm diagnosis (especially in adults/pregnant women who can have more severe disease).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Neem leaf baths (traditional soothing remedy);soft bland diet if sores are in mouth. AVOID: Aspirin in children with viral fever (Reye's syndrome risk).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Isolate the patient until ALL blisters have crusted over (usually 5-7 days). It spreads through air and touch.
description_2: The itching can be intense and interfere with sleep. New waves of blisters might appear for a few days.
medicine_2: Oral acyclovir (antiviral) can reduce severity if started within 24 hours of first rash (often prescribed for adults/teens).
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if blisters become very red;warm;tender with pus (bacterial superinfection).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Cool hydrating fluids;khichdi. AVOID: salty/acidic foods if mouth sores are present.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wear loose cotton clothes. Mittens for small babies to stop them scratching at night.
description_3: Severe complications can include pneumonia or brain inflammation (encephalitis), though rare in healthy kids.
medicine_3: Hospital care needed for complications, especially in immunocompromised people.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if difficulty breathing;severe drowsiness;persistent vomiting;or seizures occur.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: High calorie soft diet to maintain strength. AVOID: steroid creams on chickenpox without strict medical advice.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Vaccination (Varicella vaccine) can prevent this effectively.

keywords: fungal infection;daad;ringworm;jock itch;athlete's foot;itchy round rash;red scaly patch;skin fungus
description_1: Fungal infections often appear as ring-shaped, red, scaly, very itchy patches, often in sweaty areas (groin/feet/underarms).
medicine_1: Apply anti-fungal cream (Clotrimazole/Terbinafine) 2 times/day for 2 weeks. Keep area bone dry.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it doesn't improve after 2 weeks of OTC cream;spreads to scalp/nails;or covers large areas.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Probiotic foods (curd) might help skin microbiome. AVOID: Excess sugar (yeast/fungi thrive on sugar).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't share towels/clothes. Wear breathable cotton underwear/socks. Change out of sweaty gym clothes immediately.
description_2: Persistent or widespread fungal infection (common in humid Indian weather) can be very stubborn.
medicine_2: Oral antifungal pills (Fluconazole/Itraconazole) might be prescribed by dermatologist for 2-6 weeks. DO NOT self-medicate with steroid creams (makes it worse long-term).
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist early if you have diabetes (prone to severe infections).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Garlic (natural antifungal properties) in diet. AVOID: tight synthetic clothing that traps moisture.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wash clothes in hot water and dry in direct sunlight to kill fungus.
description_3: Severe/Chronic widespread tinea can indicate underlying immunity issues or steroid abuse.
medicine_3: Requires prolonged systemic treatment and investigation of underlying causes.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if the area becomes intensely painful;hot;red;swollen with pus (secondary bacterial cellulitis).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet to support immunity. AVOID: scratching—it spreads the fungus to other body parts.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Use antifungal dusting powder (Abzorb/Clocip) daily in folds of skin as prevention.

keywords: kidney stone;pathri;renal colic;severe side pain;pain radiating to groin;blood in urine;pain while peeing (severe);flank pain
description_1: Small kidney stones might pass unnoticed, but larger ones cause sudden, excruciating sharp pain in your back/side.
medicine_1: Drink HUGE amounts of water (3-4 liters) to try and flush it out. Take strong NSAID painkiller (Diclofenac) if prescribed.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately for severe pain. You need imaging (Ultrasound/CT) to confirm size and location.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Water;lemon juice;coconut water;barley water. AVOID: Oxalate rich foods (spinach;beetroot;nuts);excess salt;animal protein while having stones.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Jump or skip rope gently (sometimes helps move the stone). Strain your urine through a cloth to catch the stone for analysis.
description_2: If stone is stuck, pain will come in severe waves (renal colic) and you might vomit from pain.
medicine_2: Tamsulosin medication might be prescribed to relax the ureter and help stone pass. Stronger prescription painkillers needed.
doctor_consult_2: See urologist if stone is >5mm (unlikely to pass on its own) or if you have fever (dangerous infection risk).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Low salt diet is crucial for prevention. AVOID: cola drinks;excessive Vitamin C supplements.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use a hot water bottle on the painful side for some relief.
description_3: Severe obstruction by stone can damage kidneys or cause life-threatening sepsis if infected.
medicine_3: Surgery (Lithotripsy/Ureteroscopy) may be needed to break or remove the stone.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have fever with shaking chills;uncontrollable vomiting;or cannot pass ANY urine (anuria).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: IV fluids in hospital if unable to drink due to vomiting. AVOID: delaying care if fever is present.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Once passed, analysis of stone helps determine specific diet changes to prevent recurrence.

keywords: dandruff;rusi;itchy scalp;white flakes;seborrheic dermatitis;oily scalp flakes;scaly scalp;fungal scalp
description_1: Dandruff is often a mild fungal issue or oily skin, causing white flakes and itching.
medicine_1: Use Ketoconazole shampoo (Nizoral/Scalpe) 2-3 times a week. Leave it on scalp for 5 mins before rinsing.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if OTC shampoos don't work after a month;or if you have red;thick scaly patches (could be psoriasis).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Foods rich in Zinc and B vitamins;Omega-3. AVOID: Excess sugar/yeast products might aggravate it for some.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't scratch vigorously (can cause infections). Wash combs/pillowcases regularly. manage stress (major trigger).
description_2: Persistent severe dandruff with yellow oily flakes might be Seborrheic Dermatitis. It can also affecting eyebrows/nose.
medicine_2: Dermatologist might prescribe stronger steroid lotions or coal tar shampoos for short term use to reduce inflammation.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you have hair loss accompanying the dandruff.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Probiotics. AVOID: Hot water on scalp (dries it out more;causing overcompensation of oil).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Get some sunlight on scalp (in moderation; UV can reduce fungus).
description_3: Severe thick silvery scales that bleed when removed might be Scalp Psoriasis, an autoimmune condition.
medicine_3: Requires specific treatments like Vitamin D analogs;salicylic acid ointments;or systemic meds.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if scalp is swollen;oozing pus;or you have swollen lymph nodes in neck (infection).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory diet. AVOID: hair oils if you have seborrheic dermatitis (fungus feeds on the oil!).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Maintain good scalp hygiene but don't over-wash (can strip natural oils).

keywords: vertigo;chakkar;dizziness;head spinning;feeling off balance;room spinning;giddiness;woozy;motion sickness feeling
description_1: Vertigo is a sensation that you or the room is spinning. It's often due to inner ear issues (BPPV).
medicine_1: Sit or lie down immediately. Keep eyes fixed on one stationary object. Avoid sudden head movements.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if vertigo is severe;persistent;accompanied by vomiting;or new for you.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Ginger tea;hydrating fluids. AVOID: Caffeine;alcohol;tobacco;high salt (can increase inner ear fluid pressure).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Move slowly when standing up. Sleep with head slightly raised on two pillows.
description_2: BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo) is triggered by specific head positions. It lasts seconds to minutes but is intense.
medicine_2: Epley Maneuver (performed by doctor/physio) can often fix BPPV instantly by repositioning inner ear crystals. Vertin tablets might be prescribed.
doctor_consult_2: See ENT or neurologist if you also have hearing loss;ringing in ears;or severe headaches.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin D supplement if deficient (linked to BPPV). AVOID: Driving or operating heavy machinery while dizzy.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Install grab bars in bathroom to prevent falls. Use a night light.
description_3: Severe constant vertigo for days could be Labyrinthitis (viral inner ear infection) or rarely a stroke (if other signs present).
medicine_3: Labyrinthitis needs vestibular sedatives and time to heal. Stroke needs IMMEDIATE emergency care.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if accompanied by double vision;slurred speech;limb weakness;or inability to walk at all.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Normal diet as tolerated. AVOID: dark rooms while moving (visual cues help balance).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Vestibular rehabilitation exercises can help brain adapt to chronic dizziness.

keywords: mouth ulcers;chale;canker sores;painful sores in mouth;white spots in mouth;gum sores;stomatitis;difficulty eating spicy
description_1: Mouth ulcers are painful white/yellow sores inside cheeks/lips. Caused by stress, accidental biting, or vitamin deficiency.
medicine_1: Apply topical anesthetic gel (Zytee/Mucopain/Orajel) before meals to eat comfortably. Rinse with warm salt water.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if ulcer lasts >3 weeks (painless non-healing ulcers need cancer check);or if they are huge (>1cm).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Cold foods (ice cream/yogurt);bland soft diet. AVOID: Spicy;acidic (lemon/tomato);salty;crunchy foods that scrape.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use a soft toothbrush. Avoid toothpaste with SLS (sodium lauryl sulfate) if you get them often. Manage stress.
description_2: Recurrent multiple ulcers might indicate Vitamin B12/Iron deficiency or underlying autoimmune issues.
medicine_2: B-complex vitamin supplements (like Becosules) often help. Triamcinolone oral paste (steroid) speeds healing.
doctor_consult_2: See dentist/doctor if you also have ulcers on genitals or skin rashes (Behcet's disease etc.).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Iron and B12 rich foods (eggs;milk;leafy greens). AVOID: very hot food/drinks.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Stay hydrated. sometimes caused by quitting smoking (temporary reaction).
description_3: Severe widespread ulcers can be from viral infections (Herpes) or severe drug reactions (Stevens-Johnson Syndrome - rare).
medicine_3: Antiviral meds needed for herpes. SJS is a medical emergency.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if ulcers are accompanied by high fever;skin rash all over body;or eye redness.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Liquid nutritional supplements if eating solids is impossible. AVOID: self-treating indefinitely.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Chew slowly to avoid accidental bites that can turn into ulcers.

keywords: thyroid;hypothyroid;mota hona;weight gain;feeling cold;tired all the time;hair fall;dry skin;slow metabolism
description_1: Hypothyroidism means your thyroid gland is underactive. You might feel sluggish, gain weight easily, and feel cold.
medicine_1: Requires blood test (TSH/T3/T4) to confirm. No home remedy fixes it, but good lifestyle helps symptoms.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have unexplained fatigue;weight gain despite normal diet;depression;irregular periods.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Iodine rich foods (iodized salt);Selenium (brazil nuts);Vitamin D. AVOID: excessive raw cruciferous veggies (cabbage/cauliflower) - though cooking makes them okay.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Regular exercise is crucial to boost slow metabolism. Stick to a sleep schedule to combat fatigue.
description_2: Once diagnosed, it requires lifelong daily medication to replace the missing hormone.
medicine_2: Levothyroxine (Thyronorm/Eltroxin) must be taken EMPTY STOMACH first thing in morning. Wait 30-60 mins before tea/breakfast.
doctor_consult_2: See endocrinologist to adjust dose every 6-12 weeks initially until TSH is stable.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: High fiber diet to combat constipation associated with it. AVOID: taking calcium/iron supplements at same time as thyroid pill (blocks absorption).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Keep warm. Use moisturizers for dry skin.
description_3: Severe untreated hypothyroidism can lead to Myxedema Coma (rare, life-threatening slowing of body functions).
medicine_3: Medical emergency requiring IV thyroid hormones and life support.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if extreme drowsiness;confusion;or intense intolerance to cold develops.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced controlled-calorie diet to manage weight. AVOID: crash diets which further slow metabolism.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Don't switch brands of thyroid medication without telling your doctor (slight absorption differences exist).

keywords: bad breath;muh ki badbu;halitosis;smelly breath;foul taste in mouth;stinky breath;white tongue
description_1: Bad breath is usually from bacteria on teeth/tongue, gum disease, or dry mouth.
medicine_1: Brush twice daily AND floss. Most important: Scrape your tongue daily. Stay well hydrated.
doctor_consult_1: Consult dentist if it persists despite good hygiene (could be gum infection or a rotting tooth).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Crunchy fruits/veggies (apples/carrots act as natural toothbrush);fennel seeds (saunf);water. AVOID: Onions;garlic;coffee;tobacco;alcohol.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Chew sugar-free gum to stimulate saliva. Rinse mouth with water after every meal/snack.
description_2: Persistent bad breath can also come from tonsil stones, acid reflux, or sinus infections (post-nasal drip).
medicine_2: Chlorhexidine mouthwash (short term only - can stain teeth if used long term). treat the underlying cause (e.g., antacids for reflux).
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you also have persistent heartburn or chronic blocked nose.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Probiotic yogurt. Green tea (has antibacterial properties). AVOID: sugary sticky candies.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Quit smoking - it's a major cause of unfixable bad breath.
description_3: Severe 'fruity' breath can be a sign of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA). 'Fishy' breath can signal kidney issues.
medicine_3: DKA is a medical emergency requiring immediate hospital treatment.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if breath smells distinctly like acetone (nail polish remover) or ammonia;and you feel ill.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Parsley/mint leaves to chew temporarily. AVOID: skipping meals (hunger can cause ketone breath).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Regular dental cleanings (scaling) every 6-12 months are essential.

keywords: heel pain;edi mein dard;plantar fasciitis;pain first steps morning;foot pain;pain under heel;stiff foot morning
description_1: Pain usually felt on the bottom of the heel, worst when you take first steps in the morning.
medicine_1: Rest from running/jumping. Roll a frozen water bottle under your foot for 20 mins. Calf stretches are VITAL.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if pain is severe even while resting;or if you have diabetes and ANY foot pain.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory diet. AVOID: Walking barefoot on hard floors.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wear supportive shoes with good arch support AT ALL TIMES (even indoors). Avoid completely flat slippers.
description_2: Persistent pain is from inflammation of the band of tissue (plantar fascia) connecting heel to toes.
medicine_2: Silicone heel cushions in shoes can help. Physiotherapy for specific stretching/strengthening exercises.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist if no improvement in 6 weeks. Might need night splints or rarely steroid injection.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: maintain healthy weight to reduce load on feet. AVOID: worn-out shoes.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Do 'toe curls' (trying to pick up a towel with your toes) to strengthen foot muscles.
description_3: Severe cases might involve heel spurs (bony growth), though the spur itself isn't always the cause of pain.
medicine_3: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Therapy (ESWT) or surgery are last resort options.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have severe pain with redness/warmth (could be infection/gout) or numbness.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Collagen/Vitamin C for tissue repair. AVOID: high-impact activities until healed.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It can take months to fully heal - consistency with stretching is key.

keywords: sunburn;dhup se jalna;red skin sun;tanned painfully;peeling skin;hot skin after sun;sun damage
description_1: Skin becomes red, painful, and hot to touch after too much sun exposure. It appears a few hours later.
medicine_1: Cool bath/shower. Apply pure Aloe Vera gel or Calamine lotion generously. Stay out of sun completely.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if widespread blistering occurs;or accompanied by high fever/chills (sun poisoning).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Lots of water/fluids to rehydrate skin from inside. Anti-inflammatory foods. AVOID: Alcohol (dehydrating).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wear loose;soft cotton clothes that don't rub the burned area. Do NOT peel flaking skin.
description_2: If severe, you might get fluid-filled blisters. This is a second-degree burn.
medicine_2: NSAIDs (Ibuprofen) can reduce early inflammation/pain. Hydrocortisone 1% cream (mild steroid) for unbroken skin if very inflamed.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist if blisters are large or show signs of infection (pus/yellow crusting).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Watermelon;cucumber;tomatoes (contain lycopene which might help skin protect itself). AVOID: Petroleum jelly/heavy oils initially (traps heat).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Moisturize constantly as it heals and starts peeling.
description_3: Severe repeated sunburns significantly increase risk of skin cancer later in life.
medicine_3: Prevention is best medicine: Sunscreen SPF 30+;hats;full sleeves.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you feel dizzy;faint;nauseous;or confused (signs of heat stroke along with sunburn).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Cool fluids. AVOID: using harsh soap on burned areas.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Protect the healed new skin vigilantly—it's very sensitive to sun.

keywords: nosebleed;naksir;nak seer;bleeding from nose;epistaxis;bloody nose;nose drip blood
description_1: Nosebleeds are common due to dry air, nose picking, or injury. Most stop easily.
medicine_1: Lean FORWARD slightly (NOT back - don't swallow blood). Pinch the soft part of nose just below bridge firmly for 10 FULL minutes without peeking.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if bleeding doesn't stop after 20 mins of pressure;or if it's heavy gushing blood.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Cool fluids. AVOID: Hot spicy foods/hot drinks immediately after a bleed (dilates blood vessels).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Apply ice pack to bridge of nose. spit out any blood in mouth.
description_2: Frequent nosebleeds might be from dry nasal lining or high blood pressure, or blood clotting issues.
medicine_2: Use saline nasal spray daily to keep inside of nose moist. Apply a little petroleum jelly inside nostrils gently.
doctor_consult_2: See ENT if they happen very often without clear reason, to rule out growths or need for cautery (sealing the vessel).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin K rich foods (leafy greens) if deficient. Vitamin C for fragile capillaries. AVOID: Picking your nose!
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use a humidifier in bedroom if air is very dry (AC/heater use).
description_3: Severe massive nosebleeds (usually from back of nose - posterior epistaxis) are dangerous and hard to stop at home.
medicine_3: Requires nasal packing by a doctor in hospital.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you feel dizzy;weak;or if nosebleed follows a serious head injury.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Iron rich foods if you have had frequent heavy bleeds to prevent anemia. AVOID: heavy lifting/bending down for 24hrs after a bleed.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Keep fingernails short to prevent accidental injury inside nose.

keywords: motion sickness;travel sickness;gadi mein ulti;car sickness;sea sickness;air sickness;nausea in car;vomiting while traveling
description_1: Feeling nauseous, dizzy, or sweating when traveling by car, boat, or plane. It's a conflict between eyes and inner ear.
medicine_1: Look out at the horizon (stable view). Don't read or look at phone. Sit in front seat of car or over wing in plane.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you are extremely sensitive and it prevents necessary travel.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Ginger candies;dry crackers before travel. AVOID: Heavy;greasy;spicy meals before/during travel;alcohol.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Open a window for fresh air if possible. Acupressure wristbands (Sea-Bands) help some people.
description_2: If you know you get it, take preventative meds BEFORE you start feeling sick (30-60 mins before trip).
medicine_2: Antihistamines like Promethazine (Avomine) or Meclizine are effective but cause drowsiness.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor for prescription patches (Scopolamine) for very long sea voyages if needed.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Peppermint helps settle stomach. AVOID: Strong odors (food/perfume) in the vehicle.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Try to sleep during the journey if possible.
description_3: Severe intractable vomiting during long travel can cause dehydration.
medicine_3: May require injectable anti-emetics if oral meds are vomited instantly.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if neurological symptoms (not just regular dizziness) occur.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Sips of water once nausea settles. AVOID: staring at moving objects inside the vehicle.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Focusing on breathing slowly can help reduce the urge to vomit.

keywords: malaria;shivering fever;thand lagke bukhar;rigors;mosquito bite fever;alternate day fever;intense chills;sweating after fever
description_1: Malaria is spread by mosquitoes. Its hallmark is high fever that comes with severe shaking chills (rigors), often every 48 hours.
medicine_1: Paracetamol (Dolo 650) to manage fever spikes. DO NOT self-medicate with anti-malarials without a blood test.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately if you have fever with severe shivering, especially if you traveled recently to high-risk areas.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Fluids;coconut water;simple khichdi during non-fever periods. AVOID: Heavy oily foods that burden the liver.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use mosquito nets strictly. Rest is essential during fever bouts.
description_2: Confirmed Malaria needs specific treatment based on the type (Vivax or Falciparum). You might feel exhausted even when fever is down.
medicine_2: Prescribed Anti-malarials (like Lariago/Chloroquine or Artemisinin-based therapy ACT) MUST be completed fully.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you develop yellowish eyes (jaundice);dark urine;or confusion.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Iron-rich foods (spinach/dates) post-recovery as malaria destroys red blood cells. AVOID: Alcohol completely during treatment.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Monitor temperature patterns to tell the doctor. Keep hydrated to protect kidneys.
description_3: Severe Malaria (usually Falciparum) can affect the brain (Cerebral Malaria) or kidneys and is fatal if delayed.
medicine_3: Requires immediate hospitalization for IV anti-malarials and supportive care.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if patient becomes drowsy;has seizures;or difficulty breathing.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: IV fluids in hospital. AVOID: traditional healers for confirmed malaria - it needs allopathic drugs.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Continue using repellents (Odomos) even while sick to prevent mosquitoes biting you and spreading it to others.

keywords: typhoid;motijhara;intestinal fever;stomach fever;step ladder fever;prolonged fever;loss of appetite;rose spots
description_1: Typhoid is a bacterial infection from contaminated water/food. It causes a fever that slowly gets higher day by day, with stomach pain.
medicine_1: Paracetamol for fever. Requires antibiotics, but only after prescribed by a doctor following a Widal or blood culture test.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if fever >102°F persists for more than 4-5 days despite basic care;or severe stomach pain occurs.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Very soft bland diet (boiled potato;soft rice;custard);boiled cooled water ONLY. AVOID: Raw roadside food/pani puri;raw salads.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Strict hygiene: Wash hands after toilet. Do not prepare food for others while infected.
description_2: As it progresses, you might have extreme weakness, a 'coated' white tongue, and either constipation or 'pea-soup' diarrhea.
medicine_2: Antibiotics (like Cefixime/Azithromycin) must be taken for the FULL course (often 7-14 days) even if fever stops earlier.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you notice blood in stools or sudden severe abdominal distension (risk of intestinal perforation).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: High calorie liquid diet if solids are hard to eat. AVOID: heavy fiber/roughage that can irritate inflamed intestines.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Complete bed rest is often needed for 2-3 weeks for full recovery.
description_3: Severe Typhoid can cause intestinal bleeding or holes (perforation), which is a surgical emergency.
medicine_3: Surgery might be needed for perforation. IV antibiotics in hospital for severe cases.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if severe abdominal pain with rigid tummy;vomiting;or passing black stools.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: IV nutrition may be needed. AVOID: strenuous activity for weeks after recovery to prevent relapse.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Typhoid vaccine is available for future prevention.

keywords: conjunctivitis;aankh aana;pink eye;eye flu;red eye;sticky eyes morning;itchy eyes;watery discharge from eye
description_1: Conjunctivitis is inflammation of the eye layer. Your eye looks red, feels gritty, and might be sticky with yellow discharge when you wake up.
medicine_1: Wash eyes gently with clean filtered water. Use soothing lubricating eye drops (Refresh/Tears Naturale). Don't touch your eyes!
doctor_consult_1: Consult if vision is blurry (beyond just discharge);eye is very painful;or sensitive to light.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Vitamin A rich foods (carrots/papaya). AVOID: touching communal items (towels/remotes) to prevent spreading it to family.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use dark glasses to reduce glare sensitivity and stop yourself from touching eyes. Wash hands constantly.
description_2: If bacterial (thick yellow pus), it needs antibiotic drops. Viral 'eye flu' (watery, itchy) just needs time and hygiene.
medicine_2: Antibiotic drops (like Ciprofloxacin/Moxifloxacin) ONLY if prescribed. Continue cold compresses for comfort.
doctor_consult_2: See ophthalmologist if it doesn't improve in 3 days or if it affects the cornea (black part of eye looks cloudy).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal healthy diet. AVOID: wearing contact lenses until completely healed.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Change pillowcases daily. Do not share eye makeup or drops with anyone else.
description_3: Severe forms can damage vision if they cause corneal ulcers. Never use steroid drops without eye doctor's strict advice.
medicine_3: Specific antiviral or stronger antibiotic treatments might be needed for severe cases.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have severe eye pain;loss of vision;or intense redness around the iris.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: self-medicating with chemist-suggested strong drops containing steroids.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Throw away old eye makeup after infection clears.

keywords: anemia;khoon ki kami;low hemoglobin;pale skin;tiredness;weakness;short of breath on exertion;dizzy when standing
description_1: Anemia means low red blood cells, usually due to low iron. You might look pale (check inside lower eyelid) and feel tired easily.
medicine_1: Start Iron rich diet. OTC supplements (Dexorange/Livogen) can be taken, but best after doctor confirms low Hemoglobin levels.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have shortness of breath even at rest;palpitations;or extreme fatigue disrupting work.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Spinach (palak);jaggery (gud);dates;beetroot;meat/liver (if non-veg). AVOID: Tea/coffee immediately with meals (blocks iron absorption).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Combine iron foods with Vitamin C (squeeze lemon on palak) for better absorption. Don't over-exert.
description_2: Persistent anemia needs investigation for the CAUSE (heavy periods? piles bleeding? poor diet? worms?).
medicine_2: Prescribed higher dose Iron-Folic acid tablets. De-worming tablet (Albendazole) might be given once.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you have black tarry stools (sign of internal bleeding causing anemia).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Pomegranate;figs. AVOID: Calcium supplements at same time as iron (take at different times of day).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Rise slowly from sitting/lying positions to avoid dizziness (orthostatic hypotension).
description_3: Severe anemia (Hemoglobin <6-7 g/dL) can strain the heart and cause heart failure.
medicine_3: Blood transfusion might be needed in very severe, acute cases.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have chest pain;fast irregular heartbeat;or severe fainting episodes.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Fortified cereals. AVOID: ignoring it - chronic anemia lowers immunity and productivity significantly.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Cooking in iron vessels (kadhai) can add small amounts of iron to food naturally.

keywords: diabetes;high sugar;madhumeh;sugar badhna;hyperglycemia;excessive thirst;frequent urination;blurred vision high sugar
description_1: High blood sugar often causes extreme thirst, needing to pee often (especially at night), and feeling tired.
medicine_1: Check blood sugar if you have a glucometer. Drink plain water (NO sugary drinks). Take your prescribed meds if missed.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if random sugar is >300 mg/dL consistently;or if you have ketones in urine (needs test strips).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Bitter gourd (karela);jamun;fenugreek (methi) seeds;fiber rich veggies. AVOID: Sugar;sweets;white rice;potatoes;fruit juices;maid a.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Walk for 15-30 mins (if not feeling unwell) to help lower sugar naturally. Stay hydrated.
description_2: Persistent high sugar damages nerves and blood vessels over time. You might feel tingling in feet.
medicine_2: Metformin or other anti-diabetic drugs MUST be taken daily as prescribed. Do not skip even if you 'feel fine'.
doctor_consult_2: See Diabetologist for HbA1c test every 3 months to check long-term control (target usually <7%).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Complex carbs (millets/bajra/ragi) in controlled portions. AVOID: 'Diabetic' sweets in excess (they still have calories/carbs).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Check your feet daily for any small cuts or sores that you might not feel due to nerve damage.
description_3: Severe High Sugar (DKA or HHS) is a life-threatening emergency with dehydration, confusion, and rapid breathing.
medicine_3: Requires hospitalization for IV insulin and fluids.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if breath smells fruity;vomiting occurs;or becoming drowsy/confused.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Nothing by mouth if vomiting and heading to hospital. AVOID: stopping insulin without doctor advice ever.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Carry a medical ID stating you are diabetic.

keywords: jaundice;piliya;yellow eyes;yellow urine;liver infection;hepatitis;loss of appetite;pale stool
description_1: Jaundice turns skin and whites of eyes yellow due to high bilirubin. Often from contaminated water (Hep A/E) in India.
medicine_1: Rest is the ONLY real cure for viral Hepatitis A/E. Stop all supplements/medicines not strictly necessary to rest the liver.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if vomiting is persistent;or you have severe right-sided abdominal pain;or altered mental state.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Sugarcane juice (hygienic only!);glucose water;soft digestible fruits (papaya);boiled vegetables. AVOID: ALL oil/ghee/fat;alcohol completely;spicy food.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Complete bed rest is vital for weeks. Your liver needs energy to heal, so don't expend it on physical activity.
description_2: As it progresses, you might have intense itching all over body and very dark (mustard oil colored) urine.
medicine_2: Ursodeoxycholic acid is sometimes prescribed for severe itching/slow recovery, but mostly it's just supportive care.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if jaundice persists >4-6 weeks or worsens instead of improving.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Small frequent carbohydrate meals. AVOID: Paracetamol or other drugs that can affect liver unless doctor permits.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Sunlight doesn't cure adult jaundice (unlike newborn jaundice). Stick to hygiene to not spread it.
description_3: Severe Hepatitis can rarely lead to sudden liver failure. Warning signs are drowsiness or bleeding easily.
medicine_3: Liver failure requires ICU care and possibly transplant.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if patient becomes confused;irritable;very sleepy during day (Hepatic Encephalopathy signs).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: IV glucose might be needed if patient cannot eat enough to maintain sugar levels. AVOID: sedatives.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Boil drinking water for 20 mins during outbreaks.

keywords: eczema;khajli;atopic dermatitis;dry itchy skin;red scaly patches;skin rash flexures;sensitive skin
description_1: Eczema causes very dry, itchy, red patches, often behind knees or inside elbows. It flares up with triggers.
medicine_1: Moisturize! Use thick unscented creams (Cetaphil/Venusia) immediately after bathing while skin is damp. Avoid harsh soaps.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if skin is cracked;oozing yellow fluid (infected);or if itching disrupts sleep severely.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Foods rich in Omega-3 (flaxseeds/walnuts). AVOID: Common triggers: wool;synthetic fabrics;harsh detergents;certain foods if allergic.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Take short, lukewarm (not hot) showers. Keep fingernails short to reduce damage from scratching.
description_2: Persistent eczema needs proactive management, not just treating flare-ups. Skin barrier is broken.
medicine_2: Topical steroids (like Fluticasone cream) used SPARINGLY only during active red flare-ups as prescribed.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist for non-steroid alternatives (Tacrolimus) for long-term maintenance on sensitive areas like face.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Hydrating Diet. AVOID: Fragranced lotions/perfumes directly on affected skin.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use a humidifier in dry winters. Wear cotton layers.
description_3: Severe Infected Eczema can cause widespread painful raw skin and fever.
medicine_3: Antibiotics (oral or cream) are needed if bacterial superinfection (S. aureus) occurs.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you develop painful small blisters all over eczema areas (could be Eczema Herpeticum - viral emergency).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced anti-inflammatory diet. AVOID: smallpox vaccination if you have active eczema (rare relevance now but historically important).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: 'Wet wrap' therapy can be used for severe flares under medical guidance.

keywords: frozen shoulder;kanda jam hona;stiff shoulder;adhesive capsulitis;unable to lift arm;shoulder pain night
description_1: Shoulder capsule becomes thick and tight. Pain is usually dull/aching and movement becomes severely limited.
medicine_1: Pain relief (NSAIDs) and GENTLE pendulum exercises (letting arm hang and swing naturally). Don't force painful movements initially.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you can't move arm enough to dress yourself or sleep is severely disturbed by pain.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods. AVOID: sleeping on the affected shoulder.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Keep moving it gently within pain-free range to prevent it getting completely stuck. Apply heat before stretching.
description_2: It has three stages: Freezing (painful), Frozen (stiff but less painful), Thawing (slow recovery). Can take 1-2 years total!
medicine_2: Physiotherapy is the MAIN treatment. Sometimes steroid injections into the joint can help reduce early acute pain.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist to rule out rotator cuff tear which might need different treatment.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin D/Calcium for general bone health. AVOID: jerking movements or lifting heavy weights overhead.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use a pillow to support the arm while sleeping.
description_3: Severe refractory cases that don't improve with months of physio might need intervention.
medicine_3: Manipulation under anesthesia or arthroscopic surgery to release the tight capsule.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if shoulder becomes red;hot and swollen (could be infection, not just frozen).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: completely immobilizing the arm (slings make it worse long-term).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Patience is key; it's a slow healing condition. Diabetes increases risk significantly.

keywords: vitamin d deficiency;low vitamin d;haddiyon mein dard;bone pain;weakness;fatigue;muscle aches;hair fall
description_1: Very common in India despite sun! Causes vague aches, bone pain, fatigue, and low mood.
medicine_1: Sunlight exposure (11am-2pm for 20 mins) is best natural source but often not enough if severely low.
doctor_consult_1: Consult for a blood test if you have persistent unexplained bone aches or muscle weakness.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Fortified milk;egg yolks;mushrooms;fatty fish. AVOID: sunscreen during your 20 min 'D-dose' sun exposure (apply after).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: If prescribed supplements (like Cholecalciferol 60k IU sachets), take them usually once a WEEK with milk (it's fat soluble).
description_2: Persistent deficiency can lead to weak bones (osteoporosis/osteomalacia). You might feel deep bone pain in shins/back.
medicine_2: Continue maintenance dose (usually 1000-2000 IU daily) after the initial high-dose weekly course finishes.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you have history of kidney stones before starting high dose Vitamin D.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Calcium rich foods (Vitamin D needs calcium to work for bones). AVOID: taking more than prescribed (Vitamin D toxicity is possible).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Combine with regular strength training for best bone health.
description_3: Severe long-term deficiency can cause fractures from minor falls, especially in elderly.
medicine_3: Bone density scan (DEXA) might be needed to check for osteoporosis.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have severe sudden back pain (could be compression fracture) or muscle spasms (tetany from low calcium).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: thinking you get enough sun if you are always fully covered/indoors.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Get re-tested after 3 months of supplementation to check progress.

keywords: sciatica;nass dabna;leg pain from back;shooting pain down leg;numbness in foot;tingling leg;L4 L5 pain
description_1: Pain that shoots from your lower back, through the hip/buttock, down the back of one leg. Caused by pinched sciatic nerve.
medicine_1: Don't stay in bed >2 days. Gentle walking is better. Avoid sitting for long periods. Use heat on buttock/back.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have foot drop (can't lift front part of foot);or numbness around genitals/anus.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Vitamin B12 can sometimes help nerve health. AVOID: High heels;sitting on a thick wallet in back pocket.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Sleep with a pillow under knees (if on back) or between knees (if on side) to relieve nerve pressure.
description_2: Persistent sciatica can cause muscle weakness in the leg. It might feel like an electric shock.
medicine_2: Neuropathic painkillers (like Pregabalin/Gabapentin) are often more effective than standard painkillers for nerve pain.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist/neurologist for MRI if pain is severe and doesn't improve in 4-6 weeks.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory diet. AVOID: heavy lifting;bending forward at waist with straight legs.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Physiotherapy for specific nerve flossing/gliding exercises is very helpful.
description_3: Severe compression (Cauda Equina Syndrome) affects bladder/bowel nerves and is a surgical emergency.
medicine_3: Emergency decompression surgery needed to prevent permanent paralysis/incontinence.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO ER if you lose control of urine/stool or cannot feel toilet paper when wiping.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy weight to reduce spine load. AVOID: ignoring progressive weakness in the leg.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Proper ergonomics while sitting is crucial for long-term management.

keywords: ulcer;pet mein chale;burning stomach pain;gastric ulcer;pain on empty stomach;black stool;gnawing pain
description_1: Sores in stomach lining. Causes burning pain often felt between meals or at night when stomach is empty.
medicine_1: Avoid NSAID painkillers (Aspirin/Brufen) as they CAUSE ulcers. Take antacids for temporary relief.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if pain is severe;you vomit 'coffee ground' like material;or have black sticky stools.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Cold milk (temporary relief);bland foods;cabbage juice (traditional remedy). AVOID: Chillies;coffee;alcohol;smoking;very hot temperature foods.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Eat smaller meals more frequently so stomach is never completely empty of food to buffer acid.
description_2: Persistent ulcers are often caused by H. pylori bacteria. You might feel bloated and nauseous often.
medicine_2: PPIs (Pantoprazole/Omeprazole) are main treatment to reduce acid and let ulcer heal (usually 4-8 weeks course).
doctor_consult_2: See gastroenterologist for Endoscopy to confirm ulcer and test for H. pylori bacteria.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: High fiber diet once healed to prevent recurrence. AVOID: stress (it aggravates existing ulcers).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Don't eat within 3 hours of sleeping.
description_3: Bleeding Ulcer or Perforated Ulcer (hole in stomach) is life-threatening.
medicine_3: Requires endoscopic therapy to stop bleeding or surgery for perforation.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if you vomit bright red blood or have sudden excruciating abdominal pain.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Soft diet during healing. AVOID: alcohol completely until fully healed.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: If H. pylori positive, a specific 14-day antibiotic kit must be completed.

keywords: tinnitus;kaan bajna;ringing in ears;buzzing sound in ear;whistling ear;noise in head;hissing ear
description_1: Hearing sounds (ringing/buzzing) when no external sound is present. Often due to loud noise exposure or age.
medicine_1: Avoid total silence (makes it more noticeable). Play soft 'white noise' (fan/soft music) in background to mask it.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if tinnitus is only in ONE ear;is pulsatile (beats with your heart);or accompanied by sudden hearing loss.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Some claim Magnesium/Zinc helps (evidence limited). AVOID: Loud noises (use earplugs at concerts);excess caffeine/salt (can worsen it).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Reduce stress - tinnitus often gets louder when you are anxious or tired.
description_2: Persistent tinnitus can be very distressing and affect sleep. It's usually not dangerous but can be annoying.
medicine_2: Ginkgo Biloba is sometimes prescribed but effectiveness varies. Treating underlying hearing loss with hearing aids often helps tinnitus too.
doctor_consult_2: See ENT to rule out earwax blockage (easiest fix!) or rarer causes like acoustic neuroma.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal healthy diet. AVOID: focusing on the sound (easier said than done, but retraining therapy helps).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) helps you learn to ignore the sound so it doesn't bother you.
description_3: Severe disabling tinnitus might need specialized Tinnitus Retraining Therapy (TRT).
medicine_3: Certain antidepressants can sometimes help reduce the distress associated with it.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if it happens suddenly after head trauma or with severe vertigo.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Good sleep hygiene. AVOID: aspirin in high doses (can cause tinnitus).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Protect your remaining hearing from loud noises.

keywords: heat rash;ghamori;prickly heat;summer rash;sweat rash;itchy red bumps;miliaria
description_1: Tiny red itchy bumps that sting ('prickly') caused by trapped sweat in hot humid weather. Common on neck/back.
medicine_1: Keep skin cool and dry. Use Prickly Heat powder (Nycil/Dermicool). Calamine lotion soothes the sting.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if rash looks infected (pus);is very painful;or you have fever with it.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Hydrating cool drinks (nimbu pani;chaas). AVOID: heavy creams/oils that block sweat ducts more.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wear loose cotton clothes. Stay in AC or well-ventilated areas. Take cool showers and air-dry.
description_2: Persistent rash might get infected if scratched. It usually clears up on its own once you cool down.
medicine_2: Mild steroid cream (Hydrocortisone) can be used for very itchy areas for 2-3 days only.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if it doesn't improve after a few days of keeping cool.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin C rich foods. AVOID: synthetic tight clothing (gym wear) for long periods after sweating.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use a fan directly on skin if AC not available.
description_3: Severe cases can cause deeper painful lumps (miliaria profunda) but this is rare.
medicine_3: Usually just requires cooler environment.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if accompanied by signs of heat exhaustion (dizziness, nausea).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Cooling foods like cucumber. AVOID: vigorous exercise until it clears.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Bathe with neem water for antibacterial benefit.

keywords: varicose veins;nasse fulna;swollen leg veins;blue veins legs;spider veins;aching legs;heavy legs evening
description_1: Swollen, twisted blue/purple veins, usually in legs. Caused by weak valves in veins allowing blood to pool.
medicine_1: Wear Compression Stockings (especially when standing a lot). Elevate legs above heart level when resting.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if veins become red/warm/tender (phlebitis);or if sores (ulcers) develop near ankle.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: High fiber diet (to prevent constipation which increases pressure). AVOID: High sodium (causes water retention/swelling).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't stand or sit in one position for hours. Flex ankles up and down frequently if sitting.
description_2: Persistent severe varicosities can cause chronic aching, ankle swelling, and skin darkening near ankles.
medicine_2: Venoactive drugs (like Daflon) can help with pain and heaviness during flare-ups.
doctor_consult_2: See vascular surgeon if they are very painful or bleeding.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Berries/citrus fruits (flavonoids help vein health). AVOID: wearing tight girdles/clothing that restricts waist/groin blood flow.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Regular walking improves 'calf muscle pump' which helps push blood back up.
description_3: Severe cases can lead to venous ulcers which are very hard to heal, or blood clots (DVT - though risk is low in superficial veins).
medicine_3: Treatments include Laser therapy, Sclerotherapy (injections), or surgery (stripping).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if sudden severe swelling in ONE whole leg (could be deep vein thrombosis - DVT).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy weight. AVOID: high heels for long periods (reduces effective calf muscle pumping).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Don't cross legs when sitting for long periods.

keywords: panic attack;ghabrahat attack;feeling of dying;heart racing sudden;cant breathe anxiety;choking feeling fear
description_1: Sudden intense surge of fear/anxiety reaching a peak within minutes. You might feel you are dying or having a heart attack.
medicine_1: Remind yourself: 'This is a panic attack. It will pass. I am safe.' Breathe slowly into a paper bag or cupped hands if hyperventilating.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if attacks are frequent;you live in constant fear of the next one (Panic Disorder).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Sips of water. AVOID: Caffeine/nicotine (major triggers).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use '5-4-3-2-1' grounding technique. Splash cold water on face (activates 'dive reflex' to slow heart rate).
description_2: Persistent panic disorder can make you avoid places where you had attacks (agoraphobia).
medicine_2: SSRI medications or benzodiazepines (short term ONLY for emergencies) prescribed by psychiatrist.
doctor_consult_2: See cardiologist ONCE to rule out real heart issues, then trust the 'all clear' to reduce health anxiety.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Regular meals to avoid low sugar anxiety. AVOID: alcohol (rebound anxiety is worse).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: CBT (therapy) is extremely effective for curing panic disorder long-term.
description_3: Severe attacks can mimic heart attacks. If unsure (especially if older/risk factors), it's safer to get checked first time.
medicine_3: ECG is usually normal during panic attack (apart from fast heart rate).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if chest pain is crushing and radiates to left arm/jaw (better safe than sorry if first time).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Chamomile tea. AVOID: recreational drugs (cannabis can trigger severe panic).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Learn progressive muscle relaxation to lower general baseline anxiety.

keywords: depression;udasi;low mood;feeling sad constantly;no interest in anything;crying spells;hopelessness
description_1: More than just sadness, it's a persistent low mood for >2 weeks, losing interest in things you used to enjoy.
medicine_1: Try 'Behavioral Activation': Force yourself to do ONE small task/hobby even if you don't 'feel' like it. Action comes before motivation.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it affects your work/studies;appetite changes;sleep is disturbed;or you have dark thoughts.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Omega-3 rich foods (walnuts/fish);Vitamin D. AVOID: Alcohol (it is a depressant and makes it worse long-term).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Exercise (even 20 min walk) releases endorphins. Stick to a routine. Get morning sunlight.
description_2: Persistent depression can lead to physical symptoms like unexplained aches, slow movements, and gut issues.
medicine_2: Talking therapy (Counselling/CBT) is very effective for mild-moderate depression.
doctor_consult_2: See psychiatrist if you can't function;medication (antidepressants) might be needed to correct chemical imbalances.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Balanced nutritious meals. AVOID: isolating yourself completely (though it's hard, try to see one friend).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Challenge negative thoughts: 'Is this thought 100% true fact, or just my depressed feeling?'
description_3: Severe depression can lead to self-harm or suicide. This is a medical emergency.
medicine_3: Requires immediate psychiatric intervention, sometimes hospitalization for safety.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: CALL FOR HELP/Suicide Hotline (like 14416 in India) if you have thoughts of ending your life.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Comfort food in moderation if it helps momentarily, but focus on nutrition. AVOID: making major life decisions while depressed.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Remember, depression is a treatable illness, not a character flaw.

keywords: scabies;khajli raat mein;intense itching at night;rash between fingers;contagious itch;mite infection
description_1: Infestation by tiny mites that burrow into skin. Causes INTENSE itching, especially at night. Often affects whole family.
medicine_1: Permethrin 5% cream applied from NECK DOWN to toes (every inch!). Leave overnight (8-14 hrs) then wash. Repeat after 1 week.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if itching persists >2-3 weeks after treatment;or if sores get infected.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: close physical contact until treated.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: WASH EVERYTHING (clothes/sheets/towels) used in last 3 days in HOT water. Treat ALL family members same day even if not itchy yet.
description_2: Persistent itching for a few weeks after treatment is normal (dead mites still cause allergy). Use anti-allergic pills.
medicine_2: Antihistamines (Levocetirizine/Atarax) at night help with sleep and itching.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist if standard treatment fails (might need oral Ivermectin).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Healthy skin diet. AVOID: scratching if possible (causes bacterial infection).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Vacuum furniture/carpets. Mites die after 3 days away from human skin.
description_3: Severe 'Crusted Scabies' happens in people with low immunity and is highly contagious with thousands of mites.
medicine_3: Requires aggressive oral and topical treatment under specialist care.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have widespread crusted plaques and are immunocompromised.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hygienic living conditions. AVOID: sharing beds/clothes with untreated people.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Don't over-treat with Permethrin more than instructed; it can irritate skin itself.

keywords: hair loss;baal jhadna;alopecia;balding;thinning hair;clumps of hair falling;receding hairline
description_1: Normal to lose 50-100 strands/day. More than that, or visible thinning, can be from stress, diet, or genetics.
medicine_1: Check diet for protein/iron. Use gentle sulfate-free shampoo. Avoid tight hairstyles that pull (traction alopecia).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if sudden patchy hair loss (round bald spots - Alopecia Areata);or loss associated with other illness.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Protein (dal/eggs/paneer);Iron (spinach);Biotin rich foods (almonds/sweet potato). AVOID: crash diets;excessive heat styling/chemical treatments.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Reduce stress (major trigger for Telogen Effluvium - temporary shedding). Massage scalp gently to improve blood flow.
description_2: Persistent thinning in specific patterns (top of head for men, widening partition for women) is likely genetic (androgenic alopecia).
medicine_2: Minoxidil topical solution (5% or 10%) can help regrow/maintain hair but must be used FOREVER. (Consult doctor before starting).
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist to rule out fungal infection or thyroid issues causing the loss.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Balanced nutrition. AVOID: smoking (damages hair follicles).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Be gentle when hair is wet (most fragile).
description_3: Severe sudden total hair loss (Alopecia Totalis) is an autoimmune condition.
medicine_3: Might need steroid injections or advanced immunosuppressive treatments by dermatologist.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if hair loss is accompanied by scalp scarring, redness or pus.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Collagen supplements might help some. AVOID: 'miracle' herbal cures with no scientific backing.
