lifestyle_suggestions_3: Acceptance or styling changes can sometimes be less stressful than constant fighting against genetics.

keywords: knee pain;ghutne mein dard;arthritis knee;creaking knee;stiff knees morning;pain climbing stairs;swollen knee
description_1: Wear and tear of knee cartilage, common with age. Causes pain, stiffness (especially after sitting), and crackling sounds.
medicine_1: Weight management is #1 cure. Use knee cap for support. Apply Volini gel. Do Quadriceps strengthening exercises (straight leg raises).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if knee is red/hot/swollen suddenly;or if knee 'locks' or gives way.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods (turmeric/ginger/fish oil). AVOID: Foods that cause weight gain (sugar/fried).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Avoid sitting cross-legged (Indian style) or squatting if it hurts. Use western toilet.
description_2: Persistent progressive pain might need more than just home care. You might limp while walking.
medicine_2: Paracetamol or mild NSAIDs for pain. Glucosamine supplements help SOME people (not all).
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist for X-ray to see severity of joint gap reduction.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Calcium/Vitamin D. AVOID: high impact activities like running on hard surfaces.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use a walking stick on the opposite side of the painful knee to offload pressure.
description_3: Severe end-stage arthritis (bone rubbing on bone) causes unbearable constant pain and deformity.
medicine_3: Knee replacement surgery might be the only option for good quality of life.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if unable to bear ANY weight or severe injury occurs.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy weight maintenance. AVOID: ignoring early symptoms; early exercise can delay surgery by years.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Cycling (stationary) is excellent low-impact exercise for knees.

keywords: snoring;kharrate;loud snoring;choking in sleep;stopped breathing sleep;sleep apnea;daytime sleepiness
description_1: Loud snoring happens when airflow is partially blocked. If breathing actually stops briefly, it's Sleep Apnea (serious).
medicine_1: Sleep on your SIDE, not back. Lose weight if overweight (even 5kg helps hugely). Avoid alcohol before bed (relaxes throat muscles too much).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if your partner says you 'stop breathing' or 'gasp' in sleep;or if you are excessively sleepy during the day.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Light dinner. AVOID: Alcohol;sedatives/sleeping pills (can make apnea worse dangerous).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Elevate head of bed slightly. Clear nasal congestion before sleep with saline spray.
description_2: Persistent Sleep Apnea strains the heart and causes high BP, morning headaches, and poor focus.
medicine_2: CPAP machine is the gold standard treatment - it keeps airways open with air pressure while you sleep.
doctor_consult_2: See pulmonologist/ENT for a 'Sleep Study' (Polysomnography) to diagnose.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Healthy diet for weight loss. AVOID: smoking (increases throat inflammation).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Throat exercises (myofunctional therapy) can sometimes help reduce snoring.
description_3: Severe untreated sleep apnea significantly increases risk of heart attack and stroke while sleeping.
medicine_3: Requires strict adherence to CPAP therapy or sometimes surgery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you fall asleep uncontrollably during the day (e.g., while driving).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Water before bed to prevent sticky mucus. AVOID: heavy meals late at night.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Singing can actually tone throat muscles and might reduce mild snoring!

keywords: malaria;shivering fever;thand lagke bukhar;rigors;mosquito bite fever;alternate day fever;intense chills;sweating after fever
description_1: Malaria is spread by mosquitoes. Its hallmark is high fever that comes with severe shaking chills (rigors), often every 48 hours.
medicine_1: Paracetamol (Dolo 650) to manage fever spikes. DO NOT self-medicate with anti-malarials without a blood test.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately if you have fever with severe shivering, especially if you traveled recently to high-risk areas.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Fluids;coconut water;simple khichdi during non-fever periods. AVOID: Heavy oily foods that burden the liver.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use mosquito nets strictly. Rest is essential during fever bouts.
description_2: Confirmed Malaria needs specific treatment based on the type (Vivax or Falciparum). You might feel exhausted even when fever is down.
medicine_2: Prescribed Anti-malarials (like Lariago/Chloroquine or Artemisinin-based therapy ACT) MUST be completed fully.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you develop yellowish eyes (jaundice);dark urine;or confusion.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Iron-rich foods (spinach/dates) post-recovery as malaria destroys red blood cells. AVOID: Alcohol completely during treatment.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Monitor temperature patterns to tell the doctor. Keep hydrated to protect kidneys.
description_3: Severe Malaria (usually Falciparum) can affect the brain (Cerebral Malaria) or kidneys and is fatal if delayed.
medicine_3: Requires immediate hospitalization for IV anti-malarials and supportive care.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if patient becomes drowsy;has seizures;or difficulty breathing.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: IV fluids in hospital. AVOID: traditional healers for confirmed malaria - it needs allopathic drugs.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Continue using repellents (Odomos) even while sick to prevent mosquitoes biting you and spreading it to others.

keywords: typhoid;motijhara;intestinal fever;stomach fever;step ladder fever;prolonged fever;loss of appetite;rose spots
description_1: Typhoid is a bacterial infection from contaminated water/food. It causes a fever that slowly gets higher day by day, with stomach pain.
medicine_1: Paracetamol for fever. Requires antibiotics, but only after prescribed by a doctor following a Widal or blood culture test.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if fever >102°F persists for more than 4-5 days despite basic care;or severe stomach pain occurs.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Very soft bland diet (boiled potato;soft rice;custard);boiled cooled water ONLY. AVOID: Raw roadside food/pani puri;raw salads.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Strict hygiene: Wash hands after toilet. Do not prepare food for others while infected.
description_2: As it progresses, you might have extreme weakness, a 'coated' white tongue, and either constipation or 'pea-soup' diarrhea.
medicine_2: Antibiotics (like Cefixime/Azithromycin) must be taken for the FULL course (often 7-14 days) even if fever stops earlier.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you notice blood in stools or sudden severe abdominal distension (risk of intestinal perforation).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: High calorie liquid diet if solids are hard to eat. AVOID: heavy fiber/roughage that can irritate inflamed intestines.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Complete bed rest is often needed for 2-3 weeks for full recovery.
description_3: Severe Typhoid can cause intestinal bleeding or holes (perforation), which is a surgical emergency.
medicine_3: Surgery might be needed for perforation. IV antibiotics in hospital for severe cases.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if severe abdominal pain with rigid tummy;vomiting;or passing black stools.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: IV nutrition may be needed. AVOID: strenuous activity for weeks after recovery to prevent relapse.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Typhoid vaccine is available for future prevention.

keywords: conjunctivitis;aankh aana;pink eye;eye flu;red eye;sticky eyes morning;itchy eyes;watery discharge from eye
description_1: Conjunctivitis is inflammation of the eye layer. Your eye looks red, feels gritty, and might be sticky with yellow discharge when you wake up.
medicine_1: Wash eyes gently with clean filtered water. Use soothing lubricating eye drops (Refresh/Tears Naturale). Don't touch your eyes!
doctor_consult_1: Consult if vision is blurry (beyond just discharge);eye is very painful;or sensitive to light.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Vitamin A rich foods (carrots/papaya). AVOID: touching communal items (towels/remotes) to prevent spreading it to family.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use dark glasses to reduce glare sensitivity and stop yourself from touching eyes. Wash hands constantly.
description_2: If bacterial (thick yellow pus), it needs antibiotic drops. Viral 'eye flu' (watery, itchy) just needs time and hygiene.
medicine_2: Antibiotic drops (like Ciprofloxacin/Moxifloxacin) ONLY if prescribed. Continue cold compresses for comfort.
doctor_consult_2: See ophthalmologist if it doesn't improve in 3 days or if it affects the cornea (black part of eye looks cloudy).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal healthy diet. AVOID: wearing contact lenses until completely healed.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Change pillowcases daily. Do not share eye makeup or drops with anyone else.
description_3: Severe forms can damage vision if they cause corneal ulcers. Never use steroid drops without eye doctor's strict advice.
medicine_3: Specific antiviral or stronger antibiotic treatments might be needed for severe cases.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have severe eye pain;loss of vision;or intense redness around the iris.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: self-medicating with chemist-suggested strong drops containing steroids.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Throw away old eye makeup after infection clears.

keywords: anemia;khoon ki kami;low hemoglobin;pale skin;tiredness;weakness;short of breath on exertion;dizzy when standing
description_1: Anemia means low red blood cells, usually due to low iron. You might look pale (check inside lower eyelid) and feel tired easily.
medicine_1: Start Iron rich diet. OTC supplements (Dexorange/Livogen) can be taken, but best after doctor confirms low Hemoglobin levels.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have shortness of breath even at rest;palpitations;or extreme fatigue disrupting work.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Spinach (palak);jaggery (gud);dates;beetroot;meat/liver (if non-veg). AVOID: Tea/coffee immediately with meals (blocks iron absorption).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Combine iron foods with Vitamin C (squeeze lemon on palak) for better absorption. Don't over-exert.
description_2: Persistent anemia needs investigation for the CAUSE (heavy periods? piles bleeding? poor diet? worms?).
medicine_2: Prescribed higher dose Iron-Folic acid tablets. De-worming tablet (Albendazole) might be given once.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you have black tarry stools (sign of internal bleeding causing anemia).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Pomegranate;figs. AVOID: Calcium supplements at same time as iron (take at different times of day).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Rise slowly from sitting/lying positions to avoid dizziness (orthostatic hypotension).
description_3: Severe anemia (Hemoglobin <6-7 g/dL) can strain the heart and cause heart failure.
medicine_3: Blood transfusion might be needed in very severe, acute cases.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have chest pain;fast irregular heartbeat;or severe fainting episodes.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Fortified cereals. AVOID: ignoring it - chronic anemia lowers immunity and productivity significantly.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Cooking in iron vessels (kadhai) can add small amounts of iron to food naturally.

keywords: diabetes;high sugar;madhumeh;sugar badhna;hyperglycemia;excessive thirst;frequent urination;blurred vision high sugar
description_1: High blood sugar often causes extreme thirst, needing to pee often (especially at night), and feeling tired.
medicine_1: Check blood sugar if you have a glucometer. Drink plain water (NO sugary drinks). Take your prescribed meds if missed.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if random sugar is >300 mg/dL consistently;or if you have ketones in urine (needs test strips).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Bitter gourd (karela);jamun;fenugreek (methi) seeds;fiber rich veggies. AVOID: Sugar;sweets;white rice;potatoes;fruit juices;maid a.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Walk for 15-30 mins (if not feeling unwell) to help lower sugar naturally. Stay hydrated.
description_2: Persistent high sugar damages nerves and blood vessels over time. You might feel tingling in feet.
medicine_2: Metformin or other anti-diabetic drugs MUST be taken daily as prescribed. Do not skip even if you 'feel fine'.
doctor_consult_2: See Diabetologist for HbA1c test every 3 months to check long-term control (target usually <7%).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Complex carbs (millets/bajra/ragi) in controlled portions. AVOID: 'Diabetic' sweets in excess (they still have calories/carbs).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Check your feet daily for any small cuts or sores that you might not feel due to nerve damage.
description_3: Severe High Sugar (DKA or HHS) is a life-threatening emergency with dehydration, confusion, and rapid breathing.
medicine_3: Requires hospitalization for IV insulin and fluids.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if breath smells fruity;vomiting occurs;or becoming drowsy/confused.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Nothing by mouth if vomiting and heading to hospital. AVOID: stopping insulin without doctor advice ever.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Carry a medical ID stating you are diabetic.

keywords: jaundice;piliya;yellow eyes;yellow urine;liver infection;hepatitis;loss of appetite;pale stool
description_1: Jaundice turns skin and whites of eyes yellow due to high bilirubin. Often from contaminated water (Hep A/E) in India.
medicine_1: Rest is the ONLY real cure for viral Hepatitis A/E. Stop all supplements/medicines not strictly necessary to rest the liver.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if vomiting is persistent;or you have severe right-sided abdominal pain;or altered mental state.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Sugarcane juice (hygienic only!);glucose water;soft digestible fruits (papaya);boiled vegetables. AVOID: ALL oil/ghee/fat;alcohol completely;spicy food.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Complete bed rest is vital for weeks. Your liver needs energy to heal, so don't expend it on physical activity.
description_2: As it progresses, you might have intense itching all over body and very dark (mustard oil colored) urine.
medicine_2: Ursodeoxycholic acid is sometimes prescribed for severe itching/slow recovery, but mostly it's just supportive care.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if jaundice persists >4-6 weeks or worsens instead of improving.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Small frequent carbohydrate meals. AVOID: Paracetamol or other drugs that can affect liver unless doctor permits.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Sunlight doesn't cure adult jaundice (unlike newborn jaundice). Stick to hygiene to not spread it.
description_3: Severe Hepatitis can rarely lead to sudden liver failure. Warning signs are drowsiness or bleeding easily.
medicine_3: Liver failure requires ICU care and possibly transplant.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if patient becomes confused;irritable;very sleepy during day (Hepatic Encephalopathy signs).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: IV glucose might be needed if patient cannot eat enough to maintain sugar levels. AVOID: sedatives.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Boil drinking water for 20 mins during outbreaks.

keywords: eczema;khajli;atopic dermatitis;dry itchy skin;red scaly patches;skin rash flexures;sensitive skin
description_1: Eczema causes very dry, itchy, red patches, often behind knees or inside elbows. It flares up with triggers.
medicine_1: Moisturize! Use thick unscented creams (Cetaphil/Venusia) immediately after bathing while skin is damp. Avoid harsh soaps.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if skin is cracked;oozing yellow fluid (infected);or if itching disrupts sleep severely.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Foods rich in Omega-3 (flaxseeds/walnuts). AVOID: Common triggers: wool;synthetic fabrics;harsh detergents;certain foods if allergic.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Take short, lukewarm (not hot) showers. Keep fingernails short to reduce damage from scratching.
description_2: Persistent eczema needs proactive management, not just treating flare-ups. Skin barrier is broken.
medicine_2: Topical steroids (like Fluticasone cream) used SPARINGLY only during active red flare-ups as prescribed.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist for non-steroid alternatives (Tacrolimus) for long-term maintenance on sensitive areas like face.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Hydrating Diet. AVOID: Fragranced lotions/perfumes directly on affected skin.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use a humidifier in dry winters. Wear cotton layers.
description_3: Severe Infected Eczema can cause widespread painful raw skin and fever.
medicine_3: Antibiotics (oral or cream) are needed if bacterial superinfection (S. aureus) occurs.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you develop painful small blisters all over eczema areas (could be Eczema Herpeticum - viral emergency).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced anti-inflammatory diet. AVOID: smallpox vaccination if you have active eczema (rare relevance now but historically important).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: 'Wet wrap' therapy can be used for severe flares under medical guidance.

keywords: frozen shoulder;kanda jam hona;stiff shoulder;adhesive capsulitis;unable to lift arm;shoulder pain night
description_1: Shoulder capsule becomes thick and tight. Pain is usually dull/aching and movement becomes severely limited.
medicine_1: Pain relief (NSAIDs) and GENTLE pendulum exercises (letting arm hang and swing naturally). Don't force painful movements initially.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you can't move arm enough to dress yourself or sleep is severely disturbed by pain.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods. AVOID: sleeping on the affected shoulder.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Keep moving it gently within pain-free range to prevent it getting completely stuck. Apply heat before stretching.
description_2: It has three stages: Freezing (painful), Frozen (stiff but less painful), Thawing (slow recovery). Can take 1-2 years total!
medicine_2: Physiotherapy is the MAIN treatment. Sometimes steroid injections into the joint can help reduce early acute pain.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist to rule out rotator cuff tear which might need different treatment.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin D/Calcium for general bone health. AVOID: jerking movements or lifting heavy weights overhead.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use a pillow to support the arm while sleeping.
description_3: Severe refractory cases that don't improve with months of physio might need intervention.
medicine_3: Manipulation under anesthesia or arthroscopic surgery to release the tight capsule.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if shoulder becomes red;hot and swollen (could be infection, not just frozen).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: completely immobilizing the arm (slings make it worse long-term).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Patience is key; it's a slow healing condition. Diabetes increases risk significantly.

keywords: vitamin d deficiency;low vitamin d;haddiyon mein dard;bone pain;weakness;fatigue;muscle aches;hair fall
description_1: Very common in India despite sun! Causes vague aches, bone pain, fatigue, and low mood.
medicine_1: Sunlight exposure (11am-2pm for 20 mins) is best natural source but often not enough if severely low.
doctor_consult_1: Consult for a blood test if you have persistent unexplained bone aches or muscle weakness.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Fortified milk;egg yolks;mushrooms;fatty fish. AVOID: sunscreen during your 20 min 'D-dose' sun exposure (apply after).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: If prescribed supplements (like Cholecalciferol 60k IU sachets), take them usually once a WEEK with milk (it's fat soluble).
description_2: Persistent deficiency can lead to weak bones (osteoporosis/osteomalacia). You might feel deep bone pain in shins/back.
medicine_2: Continue maintenance dose (usually 1000-2000 IU daily) after the initial high-dose weekly course finishes.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you have history of kidney stones before starting high dose Vitamin D.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Calcium rich foods (Vitamin D needs calcium to work for bones). AVOID: taking more than prescribed (Vitamin D toxicity is possible).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Combine with regular strength training for best bone health.
description_3: Severe long-term deficiency can cause fractures from minor falls, especially in elderly.
medicine_3: Bone density scan (DEXA) might be needed to check for osteoporosis.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have severe sudden back pain (could be compression fracture) or muscle spasms (tetany from low calcium).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: thinking you get enough sun if you are always fully covered/indoors.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Get re-tested after 3 months of supplementation to check progress.

keywords: sciatica;nass dabna;leg pain from back;shooting pain down leg;numbness in foot;tingling leg;L4 L5 pain
description_1: Pain that shoots from your lower back, through the hip/buttock, down the back of one leg. Caused by pinched sciatic nerve.
medicine_1: Don't stay in bed >2 days. Gentle walking is better. Avoid sitting for long periods. Use heat on buttock/back.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have foot drop (can't lift front part of foot);or numbness around genitals/anus.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Vitamin B12 can sometimes help nerve health. AVOID: High heels;sitting on a thick wallet in back pocket.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Sleep with a pillow under knees (if on back) or between knees (if on side) to relieve nerve pressure.
description_2: Persistent sciatica can cause muscle weakness in the leg. It might feel like an electric shock.
medicine_2: Neuropathic painkillers (like Pregabalin/Gabapentin) are often more effective than standard painkillers for nerve pain.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist/neurologist for MRI if pain is severe and doesn't improve in 4-6 weeks.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory diet. AVOID: heavy lifting;bending forward at waist with straight legs.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Physiotherapy for specific nerve flossing/gliding exercises is very helpful.
description_3: Severe compression (Cauda Equina Syndrome) affects bladder/bowel nerves and is a surgical emergency.
medicine_3: Emergency decompression surgery needed to prevent permanent paralysis/incontinence.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO ER if you lose control of urine/stool or cannot feel toilet paper when wiping.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy weight to reduce spine load. AVOID: ignoring progressive weakness in the leg.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Proper ergonomics while sitting is crucial for long-term management.

keywords: ulcer;pet mein chale;burning stomach pain;gastric ulcer;pain on empty stomach;black stool;gnawing pain
description_1: Sores in stomach lining. Causes burning pain often felt between meals or at night when stomach is empty.
medicine_1: Avoid NSAID painkillers (Aspirin/Brufen) as they CAUSE ulcers. Take antacids for temporary relief.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if pain is severe;you vomit 'coffee ground' like material;or have black sticky stools.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Cold milk (temporary relief);bland foods;cabbage juice (traditional remedy). AVOID: Chillies;coffee;alcohol;smoking;very hot temperature foods.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Eat smaller meals more frequently so stomach is never completely empty of food to buffer acid.
description_2: Persistent ulcers are often caused by H. pylori bacteria. You might feel bloated and nauseous often.
medicine_2: PPIs (Pantoprazole/Omeprazole) are main treatment to reduce acid and let ulcer heal (usually 4-8 weeks course).
doctor_consult_2: See gastroenterologist for Endoscopy to confirm ulcer and test for H. pylori bacteria.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: High fiber diet once healed to prevent recurrence. AVOID: stress (it aggravates existing ulcers).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Don't eat within 3 hours of sleeping.
description_3: Bleeding Ulcer or Perforated Ulcer (hole in stomach) is life-threatening.
medicine_3: Requires endoscopic therapy to stop bleeding or surgery for perforation.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if you vomit bright red blood or have sudden excruciating abdominal pain.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Soft diet during healing. AVOID: alcohol completely until fully healed.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: If H. pylori positive, a specific 14-day antibiotic kit must be completed.

keywords: tinnitus;kaan bajna;ringing in ears;buzzing sound in ear;whistling ear;noise in head;hissing ear
description_1: Hearing sounds (ringing/buzzing) when no external sound is present. Often due to loud noise exposure or age.
medicine_1: Avoid total silence (makes it more noticeable). Play soft 'white noise' (fan/soft music) in background to mask it.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if tinnitus is only in ONE ear;is pulsatile (beats with your heart);or accompanied by sudden hearing loss.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Some claim Magnesium/Zinc helps (evidence limited). AVOID: Loud noises (use earplugs at concerts);excess caffeine/salt (can worsen it).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Reduce stress - tinnitus often gets louder when you are anxious or tired.
description_2: Persistent tinnitus can be very distressing and affect sleep. It's usually not dangerous but can be annoying.
medicine_2: Ginkgo Biloba is sometimes prescribed but effectiveness varies. Treating underlying hearing loss with hearing aids often helps tinnitus too.
doctor_consult_2: See ENT to rule out earwax blockage (easiest fix!) or rarer causes like acoustic neuroma.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal healthy diet. AVOID: focusing on the sound (easier said than done, but retraining therapy helps).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) helps you learn to ignore the sound so it doesn't bother you.
description_3: Severe disabling tinnitus might need specialized Tinnitus Retraining Therapy (TRT).
medicine_3: Certain antidepressants can sometimes help reduce the distress associated with it.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if it happens suddenly after head trauma or with severe vertigo.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Good sleep hygiene. AVOID: aspirin in high doses (can cause tinnitus).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Protect your remaining hearing from loud noises.

keywords: heat rash;ghamori;prickly heat;summer rash;sweat rash;itchy red bumps;miliaria
description_1: Tiny red itchy bumps that sting ('prickly') caused by trapped sweat in hot humid weather. Common on neck/back.
medicine_1: Keep skin cool and dry. Use Prickly Heat powder (Nycil/Dermicool). Calamine lotion soothes the sting.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if rash looks infected (pus);is very painful;or you have fever with it.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Hydrating cool drinks (nimbu pani;chaas). AVOID: heavy creams/oils that block sweat ducts more.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wear loose cotton clothes. Stay in AC or well-ventilated areas. Take cool showers and air-dry.
description_2: Persistent rash might get infected if scratched. It usually clears up on its own once you cool down.
medicine_2: Mild steroid cream (Hydrocortisone) can be used for very itchy areas for 2-3 days only.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if it doesn't improve after a few days of keeping cool.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin C rich foods. AVOID: synthetic tight clothing (gym wear) for long periods after sweating.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use a fan directly on skin if AC not available.
description_3: Severe cases can cause deeper painful lumps (miliaria profunda) but this is rare.
medicine_3: Usually just requires cooler environment.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if accompanied by signs of heat exhaustion (dizziness, nausea).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Cooling foods like cucumber. AVOID: vigorous exercise until it clears.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Bathe with neem water for antibacterial benefit.

keywords: varicose veins;nasse fulna;swollen leg veins;blue veins legs;spider veins;aching legs;heavy legs evening
description_1: Swollen, twisted blue/purple veins, usually in legs. Caused by weak valves in veins allowing blood to pool.
medicine_1: Wear Compression Stockings (especially when standing a lot). Elevate legs above heart level when resting.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if veins become red/warm/tender (phlebitis);or if sores (ulcers) develop near ankle.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: High fiber diet (to prevent constipation which increases pressure). AVOID: High sodium (causes water retention/swelling).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't stand or sit in one position for hours. Flex ankles up and down frequently if sitting.
description_2: Persistent severe varicosities can cause chronic aching, ankle swelling, and skin darkening near ankles.
medicine_2: Venoactive drugs (like Daflon) can help with pain and heaviness during flare-ups.
doctor_consult_2: See vascular surgeon if they are very painful or bleeding.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Berries/citrus fruits (flavonoids help vein health). AVOID: wearing tight girdles/clothing that restricts waist/groin blood flow.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Regular walking improves 'calf muscle pump' which helps push blood back up.
description_3: Severe cases can lead to venous ulcers which are very hard to heal, or blood clots (DVT - though risk is low in superficial veins).
medicine_3: Treatments include Laser therapy, Sclerotherapy (injections), or surgery (stripping).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if sudden severe swelling in ONE whole leg (could be deep vein thrombosis - DVT).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy weight. AVOID: high heels for long periods (reduces effective calf muscle pumping).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Don't cross legs when sitting for long periods.

keywords: panic attack;ghabrahat attack;feeling of dying;heart racing sudden;cant breathe anxiety;choking feeling fear
description_1: Sudden intense surge of fear/anxiety reaching a peak within minutes. You might feel you are dying or having a heart attack.
medicine_1: Remind yourself: 'This is a panic attack. It will pass. I am safe.' Breathe slowly into a paper bag or cupped hands if hyperventilating.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if attacks are frequent;you live in constant fear of the next one (Panic Disorder).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Sips of water. AVOID: Caffeine/nicotine (major triggers).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use '5-4-3-2-1' grounding technique. Splash cold water on face (activates 'dive reflex' to slow heart rate).
description_2: Persistent panic disorder can make you avoid places where you had attacks (agoraphobia).
medicine_2: SSRI medications or benzodiazepines (short term ONLY for emergencies) prescribed by psychiatrist.
doctor_consult_2: See cardiologist ONCE to rule out real heart issues, then trust the 'all clear' to reduce health anxiety.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Regular meals to avoid low sugar anxiety. AVOID: alcohol (rebound anxiety is worse).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: CBT (therapy) is extremely effective for curing panic disorder long-term.
description_3: Severe attacks can mimic heart attacks. If unsure (especially if older/risk factors), it's safer to get checked first time.
medicine_3: ECG is usually normal during panic attack (apart from fast heart rate).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if chest pain is crushing and radiates to left arm/jaw (better safe than sorry if first time).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Chamomile tea. AVOID: recreational drugs (cannabis can trigger severe panic).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Learn progressive muscle relaxation to lower general baseline anxiety.

keywords: depression;udasi;low mood;feeling sad constantly;no interest in anything;crying spells;hopelessness
description_1: More than just sadness, it's a persistent low mood for >2 weeks, losing interest in things you used to enjoy.
medicine_1: Try 'Behavioral Activation': Force yourself to do ONE small task/hobby even if you don't 'feel' like it. Action comes before motivation.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it affects your work/studies;appetite changes;sleep is disturbed;or you have dark thoughts.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Omega-3 rich foods (walnuts/fish);Vitamin D. AVOID: Alcohol (it is a depressant and makes it worse long-term).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Exercise (even 20 min walk) releases endorphins. Stick to a routine. Get morning sunlight.
description_2: Persistent depression can lead to physical symptoms like unexplained aches, slow movements, and gut issues.
medicine_2: Talking therapy (Counselling/CBT) is very effective for mild-moderate depression.
doctor_consult_2: See psychiatrist if you can't function;medication (antidepressants) might be needed to correct chemical imbalances.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Balanced nutritious meals. AVOID: isolating yourself completely (though it's hard, try to see one friend).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Challenge negative thoughts: 'Is this thought 100% true fact, or just my depressed feeling?'
description_3: Severe depression can lead to self-harm or suicide. This is a medical emergency.
medicine_3: Requires immediate psychiatric intervention, sometimes hospitalization for safety.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: CALL FOR HELP/Suicide Hotline (like 14416 in India) if you have thoughts of ending your life.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Comfort food in moderation if it helps momentarily, but focus on nutrition. AVOID: making major life decisions while depressed.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Remember, depression is a treatable illness, not a character flaw.

keywords: scabies;khajli raat mein;intense itching at night;rash between fingers;contagious itch;mite infection
description_1: Infestation by tiny mites that burrow into skin. Causes INTENSE itching, especially at night. Often affects whole family.
medicine_1: Permethrin 5% cream applied from NECK DOWN to toes (every inch!). Leave overnight (8-14 hrs) then wash. Repeat after 1 week.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if itching persists >2-3 weeks after treatment;or if sores get infected.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: close physical contact until treated.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: WASH EVERYTHING (clothes/sheets/towels) used in last 3 days in HOT water. Treat ALL family members same day even if not itchy yet.
description_2: Persistent itching for a few weeks after treatment is normal (dead mites still cause allergy). Use anti-allergic pills.
medicine_2: Antihistamines (Levocetirizine/Atarax) at night help with sleep and itching.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist if standard treatment fails (might need oral Ivermectin).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Healthy skin diet. AVOID: scratching if possible (causes bacterial infection).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Vacuum furniture/carpets. Mites die after 3 days away from human skin.
description_3: Severe 'Crusted Scabies' happens in people with low immunity and is highly contagious with thousands of mites.
medicine_3: Requires aggressive oral and topical treatment under specialist care.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have widespread crusted plaques and are immunocompromised.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hygienic living conditions. AVOID: sharing beds/clothes with untreated people.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Don't over-treat with Permethrin more than instructed; it can irritate skin itself.

keywords: hair loss;baal jhadna;alopecia;balding;thinning hair;clumps of hair falling;receding hairline
description_1: Normal to lose 50-100 strands/day. More than that, or visible thinning, can be from stress, diet, or genetics.
medicine_1: Check diet for protein/iron. Use gentle sulfate-free shampoo. Avoid tight hairstyles that pull (traction alopecia).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if sudden patchy hair loss (round bald spots - Alopecia Areata);or loss associated with other illness.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Protein (dal/eggs/paneer);Iron (spinach);Biotin rich foods (almonds/sweet potato). AVOID: crash diets;excessive heat styling/chemical treatments.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Reduce stress (major trigger for Telogen Effluvium - temporary shedding). Massage scalp gently to improve blood flow.
description_2: Persistent thinning in specific patterns (top of head for men, widening partition for women) is likely genetic (androgenic alopecia).
medicine_2: Minoxidil topical solution (5% or 10%) can help regrow/maintain hair but must be used FOREVER. (Consult doctor before starting).
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist to rule out fungal infection or thyroid issues causing the loss.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Balanced nutrition. AVOID: smoking (damages hair follicles).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Be gentle when hair is wet (most fragile).
description_3: Severe sudden total hair loss (Alopecia Totalis) is an autoimmune condition.
medicine_3: Might need steroid injections or advanced immunosuppressive treatments by dermatologist.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if hair loss is accompanied by scalp scarring, redness or pus.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Collagen supplements might help some. AVOID: 'miracle' herbal cures with no scientific backing.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Acceptance or styling changes can sometimes be less stressful than constant fighting against genetics.

keywords: knee pain;ghutne mein dard;arthritis knee;creaking knee;stiff knees morning;pain climbing stairs;swollen knee
description_1: Wear and tear of knee cartilage, common with age. Causes pain, stiffness (especially after sitting), and crackling sounds.
medicine_1: Weight management is #1 cure. Use knee cap for support. Apply Volini gel. Do Quadriceps strengthening exercises (straight leg raises).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if knee is red/hot/swollen suddenly;or if knee 'locks' or gives way.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods (turmeric/ginger/fish oil). AVOID: Foods that cause weight gain (sugar/fried).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Avoid sitting cross-legged (Indian style) or squatting if it hurts. Use western toilet.
description_2: Persistent progressive pain might need more than just home care. You might limp while walking.
medicine_2: Paracetamol or mild NSAIDs for pain. Glucosamine supplements help SOME people (not all).
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist for X-ray to see severity of joint gap reduction.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Calcium/Vitamin D. AVOID: high impact activities like running on hard surfaces.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use a walking stick on the opposite side of the painful knee to offload pressure.
description_3: Severe end-stage arthritis (bone rubbing on bone) causes unbearable constant pain and deformity.
medicine_3: Knee replacement surgery might be the only option for good quality of life.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if unable to bear ANY weight or severe injury occurs.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy weight maintenance. AVOID: ignoring early symptoms; early exercise can delay surgery by years.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Cycling (stationary) is excellent low-impact exercise for knees.

keywords: snoring;kharrate;loud snoring;choking in sleep;stopped breathing sleep;sleep apnea;daytime sleepiness
description_1: Loud snoring happens when airflow is partially blocked. If breathing actually stops briefly, it's Sleep Apnea (serious).
medicine_1: Sleep on your SIDE, not back. Lose weight if overweight (even 5kg helps hugely). Avoid alcohol before bed (relaxes throat muscles too much).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if your partner says you 'stop breathing' or 'gasp' in sleep;or if you are excessively sleepy during the day.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Light dinner. AVOID: Alcohol;sedatives/sleeping pills (can make apnea worse dangerous).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Elevate head of bed slightly. Clear nasal congestion before sleep with saline spray.
description_2: Persistent Sleep Apnea strains the heart and causes high BP, morning headaches, and poor focus.
medicine_2: CPAP machine is the gold standard treatment - it keeps airways open with air pressure while you sleep.
doctor_consult_2: See pulmonologist/ENT for a 'Sleep Study' (Polysomnography) to diagnose.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Healthy diet for weight loss. AVOID: smoking (increases throat inflammation).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Throat exercises (myofunctional therapy) can sometimes help reduce snoring.
description_3: Severe untreated sleep apnea significantly increases risk of heart attack and stroke while sleeping.
medicine_3: Requires strict adherence to CPAP therapy or sometimes surgery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you fall asleep uncontrollably during the day (e.g., while driving).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Water before bed to prevent sticky mucus. AVOID: heavy meals late at night.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Singing can actually tone throat muscles and might reduce mild snoring!

keywords: TB;tapadik;coughing blood;weight loss unexpalined;night sweats;evening fever;chronic cough;chest pain breathing
description_1: TB is a serious bacterial infection usually affecting lungs. Early signs are persistent cough and mild fever in evenings.
medicine_1: No home remedies. Requires strict medical regimen (DOTS therapy). Paracetamol for fever temporarily.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately if you cough up blood;or have had a cough for >3 weeks with weight loss.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: High protein diet (eggs/paneer/soya) is CRUCIAL for recovery. AVOID: Alcohol;smoking (makes TB much worse).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Isolate properly if diagnosed. Wear a mask to protect family. Open windows for ventilation.
description_2: As it progresses, you might have drenching night sweats, severe fatigue, and chest pain.
medicine_2: Anti-TB drugs (Rifampicin/Isoniazid etc.) must be taken exactly as prescribed without missing a SINGLE dose.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you develop jaundice (side effect of TB meds) or vision changes.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Dense nutritious frequent meals. AVOID: malnourishment drastically lowers recovery chance.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Sunlight kills TB bacteria - keep patient's room sunny and airy.
description_3: Untreated TB is fatal and highly contagious. Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR-TB) TB is very hard to treat.
medicine_3: Specialized second-line drugs needed for MDR-TB under strict supervision.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if massive amount of blood is coughed up (emergency).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Supplements as prescribed by doctor (often B6 is given with TB meds). AVOID: discontinuing meds when you feel better.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Adherence to the 6-9 month course is the only way to be cured completely.

keywords: PCOS;PCOD;irregular periods;facial hair women;acne jawline;weight gain sudden;cysts on ovaries;difficulty conceiving
description_1: Hormonal imbalance common in women. Causes irregular missed periods, acne, and weight gain.
medicine_1: Lifestyle change is the main 'medicine'. Sometimes oral contraceptives prescribed to regulate cycle.
doctor_consult_1: Consult gynecologist if you have <4 periods a year;or are trying to conceive without success.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Low Glycemic Index foods;high fiber;protein. AVOID: Refined sugar/maida;processed snacks (insulin resistance is key in PCOS).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Exercise 30-45 mins daily (crucial for managing insulin). Manage stress.
description_2: Persistent untreated PCOS can lead to higher risk of diabetes and endometrial issues later.
medicine_2: Metformin is often prescribed to help with insulin resistance and weight.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor for annual checkups of blood sugar and cholesterol.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Spearmint tea (some studies say it helps reduce excess testosterone). AVOID: crash diets which mess up hormones more.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Track your cycles. even 5-10% weight loss can restart regular periods.
description_3: Severe long-term complications include infertility or metabolic syndrome.
medicine_3: Fertility treatments (like Clomiphene) might be needed if trying for a baby.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have very heavy prolonged bleeding (>7 days) after a long period of no flow.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced sustainable diet. AVOID: plastics in food storage (endocrine disruptors might worsen it).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Prioritize sleep - poor sleep worsens hormonal resistance.

keywords: tonsils;tonsil badhna;swollen throat glands;painful swallowing;white spots tonsils;fever with throat pain;bad breath throat
description_1: Infection of the tonsils (two oval pads at back of throat). They get red, swollen, and very painful.
medicine_1: Warm salt water gargles every 2 hours. Lozenges for soothing. Paracetamol for pain/fever.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if pain is so severe you can't swallow your own saliva;or fever >102°F.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Cold ice cream (soothes inflammation);smoothies;lukewarm soup. AVOID: Crunchy toast/chips;spicy foods.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Voice rest. Humidifier in room. Discard toothbrush after recovering to avoid re-infection.
description_2: Bacterial tonsillitis (strep) often has white pus spots on tonsils and high fever without cough.
medicine_2: Antibiotics (Penicillin group usually) needed if bacterial. Complete the course to prevent rheumatic fever.
doctor_consult_2: See ENT if you get this >5-7 times a year (might need tonsillectomy).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Honey and warm water. AVOID: very hot liquids that irritate raw tissues.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Avoid smoking or passive smoke.
description_3: Quinsy (Peritonsillar Abscess) is a severe complication where pus collects *behind* the tonsil.
medicine_3: Requires drainage of pus by a doctor with a needle/small cut.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have difficulty breathing;drooling;or can't open mouth fully (lockjaw/trismus).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Liquid diet. AVOID: ignoring one-sided severe throat pain.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Good oral hygiene can sometimes reduce frequency of attacks.

keywords: IBS;sensitive stomach;alternating diarrhea constipation;bloating after eating;gas pain cramping;mucus in stool;urgent need to poop
description_1: Gut sensitivity causing cramps, gas, and alternating between loose motions and constipation. NOT dangerous but annoying.
medicine_1: Identify triggers. Peppermint oil capsules can help cramps. Probiotics might help regulate gut.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have weight loss;blood in stool (NOT symptoms of IBS - need investigation).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Low FODMAP diet (restrict certain carbs temporarily to find triggers);curd;rice. AVOID: Common triggers: onions;garlic;beans;cabbage;milk (if lactose intolerant).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Regular meal times. Reduce stress (gut-brain axis is strong in IBS). Yoga helps.
description_2: Persistent IBS can cause anxiety about going out. You might feel you haven't completely emptied your bowel.
medicine_2: Antispasmodics (Meftal-Spas) for severe cramp days. Laxatives/anti-diarrheals used based on current predominant symptom.
doctor_consult_2: See gastroenterologist to rule out Celiac disease or IBD if symptoms are severe.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Soluble fiber (isabgol) can help BOTH diarrhea and constipation by regulating consistency. AVOID: caffeine and artificial sweeteners.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Keep a food diary to match what you ate with symptoms next day.
description_3: Severe IBS can significantly impact quality of life but does NOT lead to cancer or serious organ damage.
medicine_3: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy or low-dose antidepressants sometimes used for severe gut hypersensitivity.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if severe pain doesn't go away after passing stool or gas.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Small frequent meals. AVOID: large heavy meals that overstretch the gut.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Hypnotherapy specifically for gut has shown good results for some.

keywords: worms;pet mein kide;itchy anus night;stomach worms;grinding teeth sleep;white threads in poop;hungry all time
description_1: Common in kids. parasite infection causing anal itching (especially at night) and sometimes stomach ache.
medicine_1: De-worming tablet (Albendazole 400mg) - usually one dose, repeated after 2 weeks. Treat WHOLE family.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you see large worms in stool;vomiting worms (rare but possible in severe roundworm);or persistent toddler diarrhea.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Raw papaya/pumpkin seeds (traditional supports);healthy home food. AVOID: excess sugar (doesn't cause worms but they thrive on it).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Cut nails very short (eggs get trapped under nails when scratching bum). Wash hands with soap before eating strictly.
description_2: Heavy infestation can cause malnutrition, anemia, or intestinal blockage (roundworms).
medicine_2: Iron supplements if anemia has developed due to hookworms.
doctor_consult_2: See pediatrician if child is not gaining weight despite good appetite.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Carrots (rich in fiber/Vitamin A). AVOID: walking barefoot outdoors (hookworms enter through feet).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wash all raw vegetables/fruits thoroughly before eating.
description_3: Very rarely, worms can travel to other organs (brain/eyes - cysticercosis from pork tapeworm eggs).
medicine_3: Requires specialized long-term antiparasitic treatment and steroids.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if seizures occur (neurocysticercosis sign);or severe abdominal pain with vomiting (blockage).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Clean filtered water. AVOID: roadside food where hygiene is doubtful.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Regular de-worming every 6-12 months is often recommended for kids in endemic areas.

keywords: psoriasis;silvery scales;chale skin;thick red patches;itchy scalp plaques;nail pitting;joint pain skin
description_1: Autoimmune condition causing rapid skin cell growth. Results in thick, red patches with silvery-white scales.
medicine_1: Keep skin extremely moisturized (coconut oil/Vaseline). Coal tar shampoos for scalp. Sunlight helps (moderate exposure).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it covers large areas;affects joints (psoriatic arthritis);or causes severe emotional distress.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods (fish;nuts). AVOID: Alcohol;smoking (major triggers for flares);red meat.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Avoid injuring skin (cuts/scrapes can turn into new psoriasis patches - Koebner phenomenon). Manage stress.
description_2: Persistent plaques often on elbows/knees/scalp. They might crack and bleed.
medicine_2: Dermatologist prescribed Vitamin D analogues (Calcipotriol) or topical steroids for flares.
doctor_consult_2: See rheumatologist if you develop joint stiffness/swelling along with skin issues.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Turmeric (curcumin) might help inflammation. AVOID: hot water baths which dry skin further.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wear soft cotton clothing.
description_3: Severe Psoriasis can be widespread and very painful.
medicine_3: Systemic treatments like Methotrexate or modern Biologics (injections) might be needed.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if skin becomes universally red and shedding (Erythrodermic psoriasis - medical emergency).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy weight (obesity worsens psoriasis). AVOID: strong steroid withdrawal (can cause severe rebound).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's not contagious! You can't catch it from touching someone.

keywords: yeast infection;thrush;curdy white discharge;vaginal itching;itching private parts;painful urination women;fungal infection women
description_1: Fungal overgrowth causing intense itching and thick, white 'cottage cheese' like discharge.
medicine_1: OTC Clotrimazole vaginal pessary (tablet inserted inside) for 3-6 days. Apply antifungal cream externally for itching.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it's your first time (to confirm it's not an STD);or if it doesn't clear in a week.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Probiotic curd/yogurt (contains lactobacillus). AVOID: Excess sugar/sweets (yeast feeds on sugar);yeasted breads temporarily.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wear breathable cotton underwear. Avoid scented feminine hygiene sprays or douches (they kill good bacteria).
description_2: Recurrent infections (>4 times a year) might indicate underlying issues like uncontrolled diabetes.
medicine_2: Oral Fluconazole tablet (single dose) might be prescribed by doctor.
doctor_consult_2: See gynecologist to rule out other infections like Bacterial Vaginosis which need different meds.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Garlic (natural antifungal). AVOID: sitting in wet swimsuits/gym clothes.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Sleep without underwear to let the area 'breathe'.
description_3: Severe or complicated yeast infection can cause fissures (cracks) and severe swelling.
medicine_3: Longer course of oral/topical antifungals required (maintenance therapy for 6 months sometimes).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have pelvic pain or fever (could be PID, not just yeast).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet low in refined carbs. AVOID: antibiotics unless necessary (they often trigger yeast infections).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Wiping from front to back prevents transferring yeast from gut to vagina.

keywords: B12 deficiency;tingling hands feet;pins and needles;forgetfulness;mouth ulcers tongue;weakness;vegetarian vitamin
description_1: Very common in vegetarians/vegans. Causes nerve issues (tingling), fatigue, and memory fog.
medicine_1: Supplements (Methylcobalamin) are usually needed as veg food sources are scarce.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have numbness;balance issues;or intense fatigue.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Milk;curd;paneer;cheese;fortified cereals. (Non-veg: eggs/fish/chicken are best sources). AVOID: long-term use of antacids without doctor advice (reduces B12 absorption).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: If vegetarian, consider taking a regular low-dose B12 supplement proactively.
description_2: Persistent deficiency can lead to permanent nerve damage. You might feel 'pins and needles' constantly in hands/feet.
medicine_2: B12 Injections might be needed initially to boost levels quickly if they are very low.
doctor_consult_2: See neurologist if you have difficulty walking or severe memory lapses.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Nutritional yeast (if available). AVOID: ignoring tingling symptoms.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Alcohol can interfere with B12 absorption, moderate intake.
description_3: Severe deficiency can cause 'megaloblastic anemia' and neurological degeneration.
medicine_3: Requires lifelong supplementation if absorption is the issue (Pernicious Anemia).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if severe unsteadiness or confusion develops.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Regular dairy intake if vegetarian. AVOID: strict vegan diet without supplementation.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Get levels checked annually if you are strictly vegetarian.

keywords: dehydration;paani ki kami;dry mouth tongue;dark yellow urine;no urine;sunken eyes;dizzy standing up;lethargy
description_1: Losing more fluid than you take in (due to vomiting, diarrhea, or extreme heat). dangerous for kids/elderly.
medicine_1: Sip ORS (Oral Rehydration Solution) frequently - not just plain water. suck on ice chips.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if NO urine passed for >8 hours;extreme lethargy;or confusion.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: ORS;coconut water;diluted juices;watery fruits (watermelon). AVOID: Coffee/Tea/Alcohol (diuretics - make you pee more);high protein diet temporarily.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Rest in a cool place. If child is dehydrated, give small sips every few minutes rather than large amounts at once (to prevent vomiting).
description_2: Persistent dehydration affects kidney function. Skin might lose elasticity ('tents' when pinched).
medicine_2: Medical attention needed for IV fluids if oral intake isn't keeping up with losses.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if underlying cause (like continuous vomiting) isn't stopping.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: salty snacks (crackers) with water can help retain fluid if ORS not available. AVOID: sports drinks with too much sugar for severe diarrhea cases.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Monitor urine color - aim for pale straw color.
description_3: Severe dehydration can lead to shock, kidney failure, and death.
medicine_3: Emergency IV resuscitation required in hospital.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if person is unconscious;has rapid weak pulse;or cold hands/feet.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: IV fluids. AVOID: intense activity until fully recovered (takes 24-48 hours).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Always carry water during Indian summers.

keywords: carpal tunnel;wrist pain;numb fingers;tingling thumb index finger;pain typing;hand weakness;dropping things
description_1: Nerve pinched in the wrist, often from repetitive use (typing/mouse). Causes numbness/pain in thumb, index, and middle fingers.
medicine_1: Rest the hand. Wear a wrist splint at NIGHT to keep wrist neutral (straight). severe pain.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if numbness is constant;or grip strength is weak (dropping objects).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods (turmeric/ginger). AVOID: Salty foods (water retention can increase swelling in wrist).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Take frequent breaks from typing to stretch wrists. Ergonomic mouse/keyboard setup.
description_2: Persistent symptoms can lead to permanent nerve damage and wasting of thumb muscles.
medicine_2: Corticosteroid injection into the wrist can provide long-term relief for many.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist if night pain prevents sleep despite splinting.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin B6 supplements (sometimes helpful, ask doctor). AVOID: sleeping with wrists bent (curled under pillow).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use voice-to-text if typing is very painful.
description_3: Severe cases with muscle wasting require surgery to release the pressure on nerve.
medicine_3: Carpal tunnel release surgery is a common and effective procedure.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you completely lose feeling in fingers.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: ignoring early tingling - it's easier to fix early.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Stretching exercises (prayer stretch) done daily can help prevention.

keywords: gout;high uric acid;big toe pain;sudden joint pain;red hot joint;gathiya;rich man's disease
description_1: Type of arthritis caused by high uric acid crystals in joints. Classic sign is sudden, severe pain in BIG TOE.
medicine_1: Rest and elevate the joint. Ice pack for 20 mins. NSAIDs (Indomethacin/Naproxen) work best if taken IMMEDIATELY.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if fever is present with joint pain (could be septic arthritis - dangerous);or if attacks are frequent.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Cherries (tart cherry juice);plenty of water;low-fat dairy. AVOID: Alcohol (especially beer);red meat;shellfish;organ meats;high fructose drinks.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Weight loss helps significantly. Stay hydrated to flush out uric acid.
description_2: Persistent high uric acid can cause tophi (hard lumps of crystals) under skin and kidney stones.
medicine_2: Allopurinol or Febuxostat are long-term preventative meds to lower uric acid. NOT started during an acute attack.
doctor_consult_2: See rheumatologist for long-term management if you have >2 attacks/year.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Complex carbs. AVOID: sudden crash diets (can trigger an attack).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Limit sweetened beverages.
description_3: Severe chronic gout can destroy joints and damage kidneys.
medicine_3: Requires lifelong urate-lowering therapy.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if joint is extremely hot;red;and you have fever (rule out infection).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Vegetable proteins (dals/beans) are generally safer than animal proteins for gout. AVOID: Aspirin (can raise uric acid).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's often hereditary but strongly influenced by diet/lifestyle.

keywords: stye;aankh ki bilni;pimple on eyelid;painful red bump eye;swollen eyelid;eye abscess
description_1: A red, painful lump near the edge of eyelid, like a pimple. usually a bacterial infection of an eyelash follicle.
medicine_1: Warm compress is the GOLD STANDARD: clean cloth dipped in warm water, applied for 10-15 mins, 4 times/day.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it doesn't start shrinking after 48 hours of warm compresses;or if entire eyelid swells up causing vision issue.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: Rubbing eyes;wearing eye makeup/contact lenses until healed.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't 'pop' it like a pimple! It might spread infection. Wash hands before touching face.
description_2: Persistent stye might turn into a Chalazion (hard painless lump) which takes longer to go.
medicine_2: Antibiotic eye ointment (Erythromycin) sometimes prescribed if it's recurring or draining a lot.
doctor_consult_2: See ophthalmologist if it keeps coming back (might need vision check or diabetes check).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Flaxseed (omega-3) might help prevent blockage of oil glands. AVOID: using old expired eye cosmetics.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Clean eyelids with diluted baby shampoo if prone to them (Blepharitis).
description_3: Severe cases can spread infection to the whole eyelid/skin around eye (Preseptal Cellulitis).
medicine_3: Requires oral antibiotics.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if eye itself is red and painful, or you have fever and double vision.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: putting pure hot water directly on eye (burn risk) - test temp on wrist first.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Most drain and heal on their own within a week with just warm compresses.

keywords: bronchitis;chest cold;cough with mucus;sore chest;wheezing mild;rattling cough;fever mild cough
description_1: Inflammation of lower airways, usually AFTER a cold/flu. Causes persistent cough with mucus for weeks.
medicine_1: Steam inhalation is best to loosen mucus. Honey for cough. Rest. Most are viral, so antibiotics DON'T help.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if cough lasts >3 weeks;mucus contains blood;or high fever >102°F.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Warm fluids;soup;ginger tea. AVOID: Smoking (absolutely critical to stop);dusty/polluted environments.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use a humidifier. Sleep propped up to reduce overnight coughing.
description_2: Persistent bronchitis in smokers can turn into Chronic Bronchitis (COPD) - irreversible lung damage.
medicine_2: Cough suppressants ONLY at night if sleep is impossible. Expectorants during day to clear mucus.
doctor_consult_2: See pulmonologist if you get this every winter (sign of asthma or COPD).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Spicy foods might help thin mucus. AVOID: dairy if it makes phlegm feel thicker (subjective).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wear a mask in highly polluted areas.
description_3: Severe bronchitis can lead to pneumonia, especially in elderly.
medicine_3: Chest X-ray needed if high fever and breathing trouble develop.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if severe shortness of breath;blue lips;or confusion occurs.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Nutritious diet to support immunity. AVOID: passive smoking.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Getting annual flu shot can prevent many cases of bronchitis.

keywords: kidney infection;high fever back pain;flank pain;severe UTI;shivering with urine pain;vomiting with back pain
description_1: Usually a UTI that traveled up to kidneys. Much worse than simple UTI - causes HIGH fever, chills, and severe side/back pain.
medicine_1: Require medical treatment. Start drinking lots of water immediately while heading to doctor. Paracetamol for fever.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately. This is not treatable at home with just remedies.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Plain water;coconut water;bland foods if nauseous. AVOID: Coffee;alcohol;spicy food.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Complete bed rest is usually needed due to severity of fever and pain.
description_2: Persistent or untreated infection can permanently scar kidneys or spread to blood (sepsis).
medicine_2: Antibiotics (often injectable initially, then oral for 10-14 days) are MANDATORY.
doctor_consult_2: See urologist if you get these often to check for stones or reflux issues.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Cranberry supplements might help prevention (ask doctor). AVOID: delaying treatment - it can get dangerous fast.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Urinate frequently.
description_3: Severe cases can cause kidney abscess or life-threatening sepsis.
medicine_3: Hospitalization for IV antibiotics and fluids is standard for severe cases.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if confused;blood pressure drops (feeling faint);or unable to keep oral meds down due to vomiting.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Easy to digest foods. AVOID: NSAID painkillers (like Brufen) as they can stress infected kidneys further.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Finish EVERY single antibiotic pill even if you feel 100% better in 3 days.

keywords: allergic rhinitis;hay fever;naak behna allergy;sneezing fits;itchy nose eyes;runny nose clear water;dust allergy
description_1: Allergic reaction to dust, pollen, or pets. Causes non-stop sneezing, watery itchy eyes, and runny nose.
medicine_1: Antihistamines (Cetirizine/Allegra) provide quick relief. Saline nasal sprays wash out allergens.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if OTC meds don't work;or if it causes severe sinus infections/asthma flares.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Warm fluids. Local honey (some believe it helps pollen allergies). AVOID: Known triggers (dusting without mask;pets in bedroom).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Shower after coming indoors from outside to wash off pollen. Keep windows closed during high pollen times.
description_2: Persistent allergies can lead to nasal polyps or chronic sinusitis. You might be a 'mouth breather'.
medicine_2: Steroid nasal sprays (Fluticasone) are most effective for long-term control if used DAILY during allergy season.
doctor_consult_2: See allergist for Skin Prick Testing to find exact triggers if severe.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin C rich foods. AVOID: hanging clothes to dry outside during pollen season.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use an air purifier in bedroom if dust/pollution is a major trigger.
description_3: Severe allergies rarely cause Anaphylaxis (usually food/drug/sting allergies, not rhinitis).
medicine_3: Immunotherapy (allergy shots) can sometimes 'cure' it over few years.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you also have wheezing/chest tightness (allergic asthma).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory diet. AVOID: rubbing eyes constantly (causes dark circles - 'allergic shiners').
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Vacuum regularly with HEPA filter.

keywords: gallstones;pitt ki pathri;pain upper right stomach;pain after fatty meal;biliary colic;nausea right side pain
description_1: Stones in gallbladder. Often no symptoms, but can cause sudden severe pain in upper right belly, especially after oily food.
medicine_1: For an attack: no food, sips of water, painkiller (Diclofenac injection often needed from doctor). Heating pad might help mildly.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if pain lasts >2-4 hours;or is accompanied by fever/yellow eyes (jaundice).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Low-fat high-fiber diet (fruits/veggies/whole grains). AVOID: Fried foods;ghee;cream;cheese;red meat (major triggers).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Maintain healthy weight, but avoid rapid crash diets (can CAUSE stones).
description_2: Persistent stones causing multiple attacks usually need surgery.
medicine_2: Ursodiol medication can sometimes dissolve small non-calcified stones (takes months/years, low success rate).
doctor_consult_2: See surgeon. Gallbladder removal (cholecystectomy) is the standard effective cure.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Coffee (moderate amounts linked to lower risk). AVOID: large heavy meals.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Eating regular meals helps gallbladder empty regularly.
description_3: Severe complications: inflamed gallbladder (cholecystitis), blocked bile duct (jaundice), or pancreatitis (very dangerous).
medicine_3: Emergency surgery might be needed for acute infected gallbladder.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if pain is unbearable;high fever with chills;or vomiting continuously.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Clear liquids during attacks. AVOID: fatty foods even after surgery initially (let body adapt).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: You can live a totally normal life without a gallbladder.

keywords: cold sore;fever blister;munh ke chale lips;tingling on lip;blister on lip;herpes lips
description_1: Viral infection (HSV-1) causing painful fluid-filled blisters ON or around lips. Highly contagious while blister is present.
medicine_1: Acyclovir cream applied 5 times/day at the VERY FIRST sign of tingling (before blister fully forms) helps most.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it's near your eyes (dangerous!);lasts >2 weeks;or very frequent attacks.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Cool soft foods. Lysine supplements might help prevent attacks. AVOID: Acidic/salty foods that sting the open sore;nuts/chocolate (arginine might trigger flares).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't kiss anyone or share cups/utensils while you have a sore. Don't pick the scab.
description_2: Persistent or frequent attacks often triggered by stress, sunlight, or other illness (hence 'fever blister').
medicine_2: Oral antiviral pills (Valacyclovir) can be prescribed by doctor for severe outbreaks to shorten healing time.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist if you have eczema and get cold sores (risk of widespread infection).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Immune boosting foods. AVOID: intense sunlight on lips (use SPF lip balm).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Replace toothbrush after blister heals.
description_3: Severe widespread infection can occur in newborns or immunocompromised people.
medicine_3: Requires IV antivirals in hospital.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if it spreads to eyes (can cause blindness).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Zinc supplements. AVOID: touching it then touching genitals (can spread virus there).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Once you have the virus, it stays in body forever, but outbreaks can be managed.

keywords: head lice;juen;lice eggs;nits;itchy head kids;crawling sensation scalp;white specks hair
description_1: Tiny insects living in hair and drinking blood from scalp. Very common in school kids. intense itching.
medicine_1: Use Lice Shampoo (Mediker/Permethrin 1%) strictly according to directions. MUST use fine-toothed lice comb to remove nits (eggs) manually.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if standard treatments fail after 2 attempts;or scalp is infected from scratching.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: sharing combs;hats;hair accessories;helmets.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wash bed linen/towels in hot water. Tie long hair up in braids for school to prevent catching them.
description_2: Persistent lice usually means eggs (nits) weren't fully removed. They hatch after 7-10 days causing re-infestation.
medicine_2: Oral Ivermectin is sometimes prescribed for very stubborn cases.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist if you can't get rid of them.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Good general hygiene. AVOID: home remedies like kerosene (DANGEROUS and ineffective).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Check all family members. Wet combing with conditioner every 3 days for 2 weeks is very effective.
description_3: Severe untreated infestation can lead to matted hair and bacterial scalp infections.
medicine_3: Requires cutting hair short sometimes if untreatable otherwise due to matting.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if scalp has open pus-filled sores and swollen lymph nodes in neck.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Patience - it takes time to pick out every egg. AVOID: shame - it has nothing to do with being 'dirty'.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Lice can't jump or fly, they only crawl from head to head.

keywords: appendicitis;appendix pain;pain lower right belly;navel pain moving to right;rebound tenderness;fever with stomach pain
description_1: Inflammation of the appendix. Pain often starts around navel, then moves to lower RIGHT side. Worsens with movement/coughing.
medicine_1: Medical Emergency. DO NOT use heating pads. DO NOT take laxatives (can cause it to burst). Go to hospital.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately. Better to be checked and sent home than ignore a bursting appendix.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Nothing by mouth (NBM) if you suspect it, in case surgery is needed. AVOID: Eating/drinking anything until doctor checks.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: If pressing on the area and quickly releasing it hurts MORE (rebound tenderness), it's a classic sign.
description_2: Persistent pain that suddenly stops might mean it has burst (ruptured) - this is deceptively dangerous as serious infection follows soon.
medicine_2: Surgery (Appendectomy) is the only cure. Antibiotics given before surgery.
doctor_consult_2: See surgeon immediately. Ultrasound/CT scan confirms diagnosis.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Liquid diet post-surgery, slowly advancing to solids. AVOID: lifting heavy things for few weeks post-surgery.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: It can happen to anyone, usually ages 10-30.
description_3: Severe Ruptured Appendix causes Peritonitis (infection of whole abdomen), which is life-threatening.
medicine_3: Emergency open surgery and strong IV antibiotics required.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if severe right side pain accompanied by vomiting and fever.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: IV fluids in hospital. AVOID: delaying - time is critical.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Recovery from laparoscopic surgery is usually quick (1-2 weeks).

keywords: tetanus;lockjaw;dhanustambha;rusty nail injury;muscle stiffness spasms;jaw tight;puncture wound risk
description_1: Bacterial infection from soil/dirt entering a deep cut (not just rusty nails!). Causes severe painful muscle spasms, starting with jaw.
medicine_1: IMMEDIATE cleaning of ANY deep/dirty wound with soap and water. Get Tetanus Toxoid (TT) injection if not taken in last 5-10 years.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have a deep puncture wound;wound contaminated with dirt/manure;or animal bite.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: ignoring deep dirty wounds even if they don't look 'bad'.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Good wound care is key. Leave deep dirty wounds open (don't bandage tightly immediately) until doctor sees them.
description_2: Persistent symptoms start days to weeks after injury. Stiffness in jaw ('lockjaw') or neck, difficulty swallowing.
medicine_2: Tetanus Immunoglobulin (TIG) injection needed if symptoms appear (neutralizes toxin). ICU care required.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor for EVERY deep wound to assess need for booster.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: High calorie intake if recovering (illness burns massive energy). AVOID: home remedies like putting turmeric on deep dirty wounds without cleaning first.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Vaccination is practically 100% effective prevention.
description_3: Severe Tetanus causes violent whole-body spasms that can break bones and stop breathing. High fatality rate.
medicine_3: Requires ventilator support in ICU for weeks, muscle paralytics, and sedation.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if you have muscle stiffness or spasms after a recent injury.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: IV nutrition in ICU. AVOID: assuming you are safe if you had vaccines as a baby - boosters are needed every 10 years.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Check your vaccination status today.

keywords: flu;influenza;viral fever severe;body ache fever;high fever cough;seasonal flu;bedridden with cold
description_1: Unlike a common cold, the Flu hits you suddenly like a truck. High fever, severe body aches, and extreme fatigue are common.
medicine_1: Paracetamol (Dolo/Crocin) for fever/aches. Oseltamivir (Tamiflu) ONLY if prescribed early (within 48hrs). Rest is the main cure.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if fever >103°F lasts >3 days;or difficulty breathing (could be pneumonia complication).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Hot soups;turmeric milk;plenty of fluids (fever causes dehydration). AVOID: Cold foods;exertion of ANY kind.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Complete bed rest for at least 3-5 days. Isolate from family to prevent spread.
description_2: Persistent flu can leave you feeling weak for weeks ('post-viral fatigue'). Cough might linger.
medicine_2: Continue supportive care (steam;warm fluids). Don't rush back to work/school.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you start getting better then suddenly get worse again with high fever (secondary bacterial infection).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin C rich fruits once fever settles. AVOID: smoking.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Gentle movement only after fully recovered.
description_3: Severe Flu can be fatal for elderly/babies due to pneumonia or organ failure.
medicine_3: Hospitalization for IV fluids/oxygen might be needed for high-risk groups.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if severe shortness of breath;chest pain;or blue lips occur.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Soft nutritious diet. AVOID: ignoring annual flu vaccine if you are in a high-risk group.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Cover coughs/sneezes strictly.

keywords: chikungunya;joint pain fever;mosquito fever joints;severe joint swelling;bending joint pain;rash with fever
description_1: Viral infection from mosquitoes. Similar to Dengue but characterized by intense, debilitating joint pain that can last months.
medicine_1: Paracetamol for fever/pain. Do NOT take Aspirin. Cold packs on painful swollen joints.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if fever persists >5 days;or joint pain is unbearable and prevents walking completely.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Coconut water;fresh juices;leafy greens to boost recovery. AVOID: Processed/oily foods that increase inflammation.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Rest is vital. Use mosquito nets. Even after fever goes, joints might hurt severely.
description_2: Persistent joint pain (arthritis) can last for months or even years after the initial fever is gone.
medicine_2: Doctor might prescribe stronger NSAIDs (Naproxen) or mild steroids specifically for post-chikungunya arthritis.
doctor_consult_2: See rheumatologist if joint pain continues beyond 3 months.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory diet (rich in Omega-3;turmeric/curcumin). AVOID: strenuous high-impact exercise while joints are inflamed.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Gentle physiotherapy helps prevent joints from becoming permanently stiff.
description_3: Severe cases are rarely fatal but can cause long-term disability due to joint pain.
medicine_3: Supportive care in hospital if dehydration occurs during acute fever phase.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have unusual bleeding or severe neurological symptoms (rare).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: allowing mosquitoes to breed near your house.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Use repellents diligently.

keywords: dog bite;kutte ne kata;animal bite;rabies risk;cat bite;monkey bite;scratch by stray animal
description_1: Any bite or scratch from a stray animal (dog/cat/monkey) carries a Rabies risk, which is 100% fatal if NOT treated.
medicine_1: IMMEDIATE: Wash wound with soap and RUNNING water for 15 full minutes. This is the most crucial step. Go to hospital for vaccine.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately. You MUST get the Anti-Rabies Vaccine (ARV) course (usually 4-5 injections over a month).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: Applying turmeric/chilli powder/soil to the wound (increases infection risk).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Do NOT stitch the wound immediately unless very severe (traps virus inside).
description_2: Persistent fear of water (hydrophobia) appears only when it's too late. Prevention is the ONLY cure.
medicine_2: Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) injection directly into the wound might be needed if bite is deep/bleeding (Category 3).
