doctor_consult_2: See doctor for EVERY animal bite, even a small scratch from a stray pup.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Nutritious food to support immune response to vaccine. AVOID: missing ANY scheduled dose of the vaccine.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Observe the animal for 10 days if possible (if it's a known pet), but don't delay YOUR treatment.
description_3: Severe Rabies is untreatable once symptoms start.
medicine_3: Palliative care only.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL immediately after ANY animal bite for PEP (Post-Exposure Prophylaxis).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: traditional healers/magic remedies for dog bites - they do not work for rabies.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Complete the full vaccine course (Days 0, 3, 7, 14, 28 usually).

keywords: stroke;brain attack;lakwa;paralysis one side;slurred speech sudden;face drooping;arm weakness sudden
description_1: Sudden interruption of blood to brain. remember F.A.S.T: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call ambulance.
medicine_1: Medical Emergency. NO home remedies. Do not give food/water (might choke). Note the EXACT time symptoms started.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately. Rush to a major hospital with CT scan facility. Time is brain (millions of neurons die every minute).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Nothing by mouth until cleared by doctor. AVOID: giving aspirin unless doctor on phone says so (could be a bleeding stroke).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Lay patient flat or with head slightly raised. Loosen tight clothing. Keep them calm.
description_2: Persistent symptoms depend on how quickly they got treatment. Can range from mild weakness to total paralysis.
medicine_2: Clot-busting injection (tPA) can ONLY be given within 4.5 hours of first symptom. Rehabilitation is key later.
doctor_consult_2: See neurologist for long term management and prevention of second stroke.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Low salt;low fat DASH diet to prevent recurrence. AVOID: Smoking;trans fats.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Physical/Speech therapy is crucial for recovery of lost functions.
description_3: Severe massive stroke can be fatal or cause permanent coma/severe disability.
medicine_3: Neurosurgery might be needed to relieve pressure if it's a bleeding (hemorrhagic) stroke.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: CALL AMBULANCE if ANY stroke sign appears, even if it goes away quickly (TIA - 'mini stroke' is a major warning sign).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Tube feeding might be needed initially. AVOID: ignoring TIA symptoms just because they resolved.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Manage BP, diabetes, and cholesterol strictly to prevent it.

keywords: hernia;aant utarna;bulge in groin;swelling near navel;pain when lifting;lump in stomach appearing when coughing
description_1: An internal organ (usually intestine) pushes through a weak spot in muscle wall. Causes a soft bulge that might disappear when lying down.
medicine_1: Avoid heavy lifting or straining (constipation/heavy coughing). Wear supportive underwear. It will NOT heal on its own.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if bulge becomes painful;red;hard;or doesn't go back in when lying down.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: High fiber diet to PREVENT constipation and straining. AVOID: Heavy meals that cause bloating and increase abdominal pressure.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: When coughing/sneezing, press gently on the hernia to support it.
description_2: Persistent hernias usually get bigger over time. You might feel a dragging sensation in groin.
medicine_2: Surgery (Hernioplasty with mesh) is the standard lasting cure.
doctor_consult_2: See surgeon to plan elective surgery before it becomes an emergency.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Healthy weight (obesity increases pressure). AVOID: smoking (causes coughing which worsens hernia).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Gentle walks are okay, avoid intense core exercises until treated.
description_3: Strangulated Hernia: The trapped intestine loses blood supply. It's life-threatening.
medicine_3: Emergency surgery required to save the intestine from dying (gangrene).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if hernia is stuck OUT and is extremely painful;swollen;or you are vomiting.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: NBM (nothing by mouth) if heading to hospital for emergency. AVOID: waiting if it gets stuck.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Post-surgery recovery usually takes 4-6 weeks before heavy lifting is allowed.

keywords: lactose intolerance;doodh se allergy;milk allergy;gas after milk;diarrhea after dairy;bloating from milk;stomach rumble milk
description_1: Inability to digest lactose (sugar in milk). Causes gas, bloating, and diarrhea 30 mins to 2 hours after dairy.
medicine_1: Stop drinking plain milk. Try curd/yogurt (often better tolerated due to fermentation). Use lactose-free milk if available.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have these symptoms with ALL foods (might be IBS, not just lactose);or if you lose weight.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Lactose-free dairy;soy/almond milk;curd;hard cheeses (low lactose). AVOID: Milk;soft cheeses;ice cream;cream sauces.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Read labels: 'whey', 'milk solids' contain lactose. Enzyme tablets (Lactase) can be taken before dairy meals.
description_2: Persistent symptoms mean you are still consuming hidden lactose. It's uncomfortable but not dangerous.
medicine_2: Lactase enzyme supplements (like Yamoo tablets) can allow you to eat occasional dairy without symptoms.
doctor_consult_2: See gastroenterologist/dietitian to ensure you are getting enough Calcium if you cut ALL dairy.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Calcium rich non-dairy foods (ragi;sesame seeds;leafy greens). AVOID: forcing yourself to drink milk if it hurts.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Experiment to find your threshold - some can handle a little tea/coffee with milk.
description_3: Severe intolerance causes immediate explosive diarrhea and severe cramping after even small amounts.
medicine_3: Strict avoidance is necessary.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you see blood in stool (NOT a symptom of lactose intolerance - something else is wrong).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration after diarrhea episodes. AVOID: assuming it's a milk 'allergy' (allergy can cause hives/anaphylaxis, intolerance is just gut issues).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Most Indian adults have some degree of lactose intolerance naturally.

keywords: bleeding gums;masoode se khoon;gingivitis;swollen gums;blood when brushing;bad breath gums;gum infection
description_1: Early stage gum disease from plaque buildup. Gums are red, puffy, and bleed easily when brushing.
medicine_1: Brush GENTLY twice daily with soft brush. Floss daily (bleeding will STOP after a week of regular flossing). Warm salt water rinses.
doctor_consult_1: Consult dentist for a professional cleaning (scaling). It's often needed to remove hardened plaque (tartar).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Vitamin C rich foods (amla/oranges) for gum health. Crunchy raw veggies. AVOID: Sugary sticky snacks that sit on teeth.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't stop brushing because it bleeds! That makes it worse. Brush visibly red areas gently but thoroughly.
description_2: Persistent bleeding can lead to Periodontitis (advanced gum disease) where bone is lost and teeth become loose.
medicine_2: Medicinal toothpastes (containing alum/astringents) might help temporarily but don't cure the root cause (tartar).
doctor_consult_2: See dentist every 6 months. If teeth start feeling loose, it's advanced.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Green tea (catechins help gum health). AVOID: Smoking/tobacco (major cause of severe gum disease).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Massage gums gently with finger after brushing.
description_3: Severe Periodontitis can lead to tooth loss and is linked to heart disease and diabetes complications.
medicine_3: Deep cleaning (root planing) or gum surgery might be needed.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if gums are severely swollen;painful;with pus discharge (dental abscess).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Soft foods if painful. AVOID: neglecting it - you can't grow back lost gum/bone.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Pregnant women are more prone to gingivitis due to hormones.

keywords: ear wax;kaan band;wax blockage;hard wax ear;decreased hearing;plugged ear sensation;tinnitus from wax
description_1: Earwax is normal, but sometimes it builds up and blocks the ear canal, causing sudden hearing loss or 'fullness'.
medicine_1: Do NOT use ear buds/Q-tips/pins (pushes wax deeper!). Use OTC wax softening drops (Otorex/Soliwax) for 3-5 days.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if drops don't clear it;or if you have pain/discharge (might be infection, not just wax).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. Chewing helps move wax out naturally. AVOID: putting hot oil or garlic in ear without medical advice.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: After 3 days of drops, gentle shower water might wash it out. If not, need doctor to remove it.
description_2: Persistent blockage can cause tinnitus (ringing) or mild dizziness.
medicine_2: ENT doctor can perform microsuction or ear syringing to remove hard wax safely in minutes.
doctor_consult_2: See ENT. Don't let unqualified roadside 'ear cleaners' touch your ears with sharp tools.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Stay hydrated. AVOID: inserting anything smaller than your elbow into your ear!
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Some people just naturally produce more wax.
description_3: Severe impaction can press on eardrum causing pain.
medicine_3: Professional removal required.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have severe pain;bleeding;or sudden TOTAL hearing loss (could be sudden sensorineural hearing loss - emergency).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Patience with drops. AVOID: aggressive cleaning.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Ears are generally self-cleaning; wax slowly migrates out on its own usually.

keywords: boil;baltod;furuncle;painful pus bump;abscess skin;red swollen lump;pimple turned big
description_1: A deep bacterial infection of a hair follicle. Starts as a red painful lump, then fills with pus.
medicine_1: Warm compress (cloth dipped in hot water) for 15 mins, 4 times a day to bring it to a head. Do NOT squeeze it early.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if boil is on FACE (danger zone);very large (>2 inches);accompanied by fever;or keeps recurring.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Turmeric (anti-inflammatory). AVOID: excess sugar (high sugar levels can cause recurrent boils).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wash hands before and after touching it. Wash clothes/towels separately in hot water.
description_2: Persistent or multiple boils (carbuncle) often need antibiotics. Might indicate diabetes if frequent.
medicine_2: Oral antibiotics (like Cephalexin/Amoxicillin) and topical antibiotic cream (T-Bact/Mupirocin).
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if it doesn't drain on its own after a week of warm compresses.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Garlic/neem (traditional blood purifiers). AVOID: sharing razors/towels.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Don't shave over a boil.
description_3: Severe large boils might need small surgical cut (incision and drainage) by doctor to let pus out.
medicine_3: NEVER try to cut it open yourself at home (risk of severe spreading infection/sepsis).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if red streaks appear spreading away from the boil (cellulitis) or you have high fever.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: popping it with a needle at home.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Keep it covered with a sterile bandage once it opens and drains.

keywords: measles;khasra;high fever rash kids;runny nose red eyes rash;koplik spots;viral rash unvaccinated
description_1: Highly contagious viral illness. Starts with high fever, runny nose, red eyes, then a blotchy rash starts on face and spreads down.
medicine_1: No specific antiviral. Supportive care: Paracetamol for fever. Vitamin A supplements drastically reduce severity/complications.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately if suspected. It is highly contagious. Isolate the child.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Fluids;ORS;soft foods. AVOID: contact with unvaccinated babies/pregnant women.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Keep child in a dimly lit room if eyes are sensitive to light (common).
description_2: Persistent measles can lead to ear infections, pneumonia, or severe diarrhea.
medicine_2: Antibiotics ONLY if secondary bacterial pneumonia/ear infection develops.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if breathing becomes fast or difficult, or child becomes very drowsy.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin A rich foods once recovered. AVOID: public places for at least 4 days after rash appears.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Vaccination (MMR) is highly effective prevention.
description_3: Severe complications include encephalitis (brain swelling) and death, especially in malnourished children.
medicine_3: Requires hospitalization for supportive care (oxygen/IV fluids).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if seizures occur;severe difficulty breathing;or extreme lethargy.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Continued breastfeeding for babies. AVOID: underestimating it - it's a major killer of children globally.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Check MMR vaccination status of all family members.

keywords: mumps;kanped;swollen cheeks;pain near jaw ear;swollen salivary glands;fever puffy face
description_1: Viral infection causing painful swelling of salivary glands (parotid) just below/in front of ears. Gives 'hamster face' look.
medicine_1: Supportive care: Paracetamol for pain/fever. Warm or cold compress on swollen jaw (whichever feels better).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have severe headache/stiff neck;or testicular pain in males (orchitis complication).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Soft foods that don't require much chewing (khichdi/soup/mashed potatoes). AVOID: Sour foods (lemon/pickles) - they stimulate painful glands to make more saliva.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Isolate patient for 5 days after swelling starts. Bed rest.
description_2: Persistent Mumps can sometimes spread to other glands. In teen/adult males, it can affect testicles.
medicine_2: Scrotal support and stronger painkillers needed for orchitis. rare sterility risk.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if abdominal pain is severe (pancreatitis is a rare complication).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Hydrating fluids (non-acidic). AVOID: going to school/work until 5 days after swelling began.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: MMR vaccine prevents it.
description_3: Severe complications include meningitis or deafness (rare but possible).
medicine_3: Hospitalization needed for severe complications.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if severe headache;repeated vomiting;or seizures occur.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Bland diet. AVOID: contact with unvaccinated people.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Good oral hygiene is important during illness.

keywords: warts;massa;skin growth;viral wart;verruca;rough bump on skin;cauliflower like bump
description_1: Small, rough, non-painful growths on skin caused by HPV virus. Common on hands/feet.
medicine_1: Most go away eventually (can take years). OTC Salicylic acid paint (Duofilm/Salicyl) applied DAILY after soaking in warm water works slowly.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if warts are on face/genitals (need different treatment);painful;or multiplying rapidly.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Immune boosting foods. AVOID: picking or biting them (spreads virus to other areas/fingers).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use a pumice stone gently to remove dead skin before applying wart paint. Don't share nail clippers.
description_2: Persistent warts can be stubborn. Plantar warts (on feet) can be painful to walk on.
medicine_2: Dermatologist can do Cryotherapy (freezing with liquid nitrogen) or Radiofrequency removal for quicker results.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist. Don't try to cut them off yourself (they bleed a lot and will regrow).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: walking barefoot in public showers/pools.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Keep warts covered with a band-aid if kids are prone to picking them.
description_3: Severe/Multiple warts might indicate lower immunity.
medicine_3: Immunomodulators might be prescribed.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if wart bleeds uncontrollably or changes color/appearance drastically (rarely could be something else).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Patience - treatment takes weeks to months. AVOID: magic cures.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: They are contagious through direct contact.

keywords: corns;callus;gokhru;hard skin foot;painful thickened skin toe;shoe bite marks;hard lump on foot
description_1: Thickened, hardened layers of skin caused by friction/pressure, usually from ill-fitting shoes. Corns are smaller/deeper, calluses are wider.
medicine_1: Wear comfortable shoes! Use Corn caps (contain salicylic acid) with caution. Soak feet in warm water and gently use pumice stone.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have DIABETES (never treat foot issues at home if diabetic!);or if it looks infected (red/pus).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: Tight pointed shoes;walking barefoot outside.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use silicone toe separators or cushioned insoles to reduce pressure on the area.
description_2: Persistent corns can feel like walking on a stone. They have a hard center core that presses on nerves.
medicine_2: Podiatrist can safely pare (shave) down the corn with a sterile blade.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor/podiatrist if it's very painful or keeps coming back.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Good foot hygiene. AVOID: cutting corns with razor blades at home (high infection risk).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Moisturize feet daily (but not between toes if prone to fungus).
description_3: Severe infected corns can lead to foot ulcers, especially in diabetics.
medicine_3: Requires antibiotics and professional wound care.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if area becomes red;hot;and very painful (cellulitis).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy diet for tissue repair. AVOID: ignoring them until they alter how you walk (can cause knee/back pain).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Changing footwear is usually the most important long-term cure.

keywords: tennis elbow;elbow pain;pain outside elbow;lateral epicondylitis;pain lifting cup;stiff elbow;forearm pain
description_1: Pain on the OUTER part of elbow caused by overuse of forearm muscles (not just from tennis! common in carpenters/cooks/typing).
medicine_1: Rest from the activity that caused it. Ice pack 15 mins 3x/day. Tennis elbow brace (strap just below elbow) helps reduce strain.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if pain is severe;elbow is swollen/red;or you can't bend/straighten arm.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods. AVOID: repetitive gripping/twisting actions (wringing clothes/using screwdriver).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Lift objects with palm facing UP. Use thicker pens/tools (easier to grip).
description_2: Persistent pain can last 6 months to 2 years if not rested. It hurts to shake hands or lift a cup.
medicine_2: Physiotherapy for eccentric strengthening exercises is the most effective long-term cure. Steroid injection gives short term relief only.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist if no improvement after 6 months of conservative care.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Collagen/Vitamin C might help tendon repair. AVOID: pushing through the pain.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Ergonomic workstation setup if typing is the cause.
description_3: Severe chronic cases might rarely need surgery to remove damaged tendon tissue.
medicine_3: Surgery is last resort.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have numbness in hand (could be nerve entrapment instead).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: sudden heavy lifting after a period of rest.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Warming up arm muscles before work/sport can prevent recurrence.

keywords: osteoporosis;haddi kamzor;weak bones;silent disease;fracture easily;stooped posture;loss of height
description_1: Bones become porous and weak. Usually NO symptoms until a bone breaks from a minor fall (wrist/hip/spine).
medicine_1: Prevention is key: Weight-bearing exercise (walking/dancing). Adequate Calcium and Vitamin D intake throughout life.
doctor_consult_1: Consult doctor for a DEXA scan (bone density test) if you are a post-menopausal woman or man >70.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Milk;yogurt;cheese;ragi;leafy greens;supplements if prescribed. AVOID: Smoking;excess alcohol;excess salt/caffeine (leaches calcium).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Fall-proof your home: remove loose rugs, install grab bars, keep good lighting.
description_2: Persistent untreated osteoporosis leads to 'fragility fractures' and hunched back (dowager's hump) from spinal compression.
medicine_2: Bisphosphonate medications (taken weekly/monthly) can help increase bone density.
doctor_consult_2: See endocrinologist/orthopedist for management.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Protein is also needed for bone structure. AVOID: forward bending exercises (like toe touches) if you have spinal osteoporosis (risk of crush fracture).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Tai Chi or yoga can help improve balance to prevent falls.
description_3: Severe hip fractures in elderly can be life-threatening due to immobility complications.
medicine_3: Surgery often needed for hip fractures.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if sudden severe back pain occurs (could be spinal fracture) even without a fall.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet with enough calories. AVOID: being dangerously underweight.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's never too late to start bone-healthy habits, but earlier is better.

keywords: enlarged prostate;BPH;frequent urination night men;weak urine stream;dribbling urine;urgency to pee;prostate problem
description_1: Non-cancerous enlargement of prostate gland in older men. Squeezes urethra causing trouble starting flow, weak stream, and frequent night visits.
medicine_1: Limit fluids 2 hours before bed. Double void (pee, wait a min, try again to empty bladder fully). decrease caffeine/alcohol.
doctor_consult_1: Consult urologist if you can't pee AT ALL (medical emergency);or have blood in urine.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Pumpkin seeds (some evidence they help);tomatoes (lycopene for prostate health). AVOID: Antihistamines/decongestants (can suddenly block urine flow in BPH patients).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't hold urine for long. Pelvic floor exercises (Kegels) might help some control.
description_2: Persistent BPH gets slowly worse. You might feel bladder is never empty.
medicine_2: Medications (Tamsulosin/Finasteride) can relax muscles or shrink the prostate effectively.
doctor_consult_2: See urologist annually to monitor and rule out prostate cancer (PSA test).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Healthy fats. AVOID: constipation (straining worsens symptoms).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Sit down to urinate if it helps empty bladder better.
description_3: Severe BPH can completely block urine flow (Acute Urinary Retention). Very painful.
medicine_3: Requires immediate catheterization in hospital to drain bladder, possibly surgery (TURP) later.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if you have a visibly swollen painful lower belly and cannot pass urine.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: High fiber to avoid constipation. AVOID: delaying treatment - it can damage kidneys back-pressure.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's very common part of aging for men, not always dangerous.

keywords: dry eye;aankh mein ruk hapan;gritty eyes;burning eyes chronic;feeling something in eye;redness irritation;watery eyes reflex
description_1: Chronic lack of sufficient lubrication on eye surface. ironically, can sometimes cause watery eyes (reflex tearing due to irritation).
medicine_1: Use preservative-free artificial tears frequently (4+ times/day). Warm compresses help unblock oil glands in eyelids.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if OTC drops don't help enough;or you have severe pain/sensitivity to light.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Omega-3 fatty acid supplements (fish oil/flaxseed) significantly help tear quality. AVOID: Direct fans/AC blowing on face;smoke.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Blink consciously when on screens. Use a humidifier in your room.
description_2: Persistent severe dry eye can damage the cornea surface. Eyes might feel constantly sandy or burning.
medicine_2: Ophthalmologist might prescribe Cyclosporine eye drops (Restasis) to increase tear production. Punctal plugs might be inserted to save tears.
doctor_consult_2: See eye doctor to rule out autoimmune conditions like Sjogren's syndrome.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Hydrating foods. AVOID: prolonged contact lens use if eyes are irritated.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Take regular screen breaks (20-20-20 rule).
description_3: Severe untreated cases can lead to corneal ulcers or scarring and vision loss.
medicine_3: Specialized scleral contact lenses might be needed for extreme cases.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have sudden vision changes or intense pain.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Water. AVOID: rubbing eyes (can scratch the dry cornea).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Sleep with eyes fully closed (some people sleep with them slightly open without realizing).

keywords: vitiligo;leucoderma;safed daag;white patches on skin;loss of skin color;depigmentation;white spots
description_1: Autoimmune condition where pigment cells die, causing milky white patches on skin. Not contagious or dangerous, just cosmetic.
medicine_1: Sunscreen is vital on white patches (they burn easily). Cosmetic camouflage (makeup) can be used if desired.
doctor_consult_1: Consult dermatologist for diagnosis and to discuss treatment options if patches are spreading.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Foods rich in antioxidants might help (evidence limited but good for general health). AVOID: Stress (often triggers new patches);skin injury (new patches can form on cuts).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: It does NOT happen due to eating fish after milk (common myth in India).
description_2: Persistent vitiligo might be stable for years or slowly spread. It most often affects face, hands, and feet.
medicine_2: Treatments include corticosteroid creams, tacrolimus, or UV light therapy (phototherapy) to restore some color.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist early - treatment works better on new, small patches.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: chemical/industrial exposure that might trigger it.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Psychological support is important if it affects self-esteem.
description_3: Severe widespread vitiligo might be treated by depigmenting the remaining normal skin to match (Michael Jackson case).
medicine_3: Requires strict medical supervision.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None - it is not a medical emergency. Consult standard for management.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy lifestyle. AVOID: myths and stigma - educate family that it's not contagious.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Some patches might repigment spontaneously, especially in children.

keywords: cholera;haiza;rice water stools;severe watery diarrhea;rapid dehydration;vomiting no nausea;contaminated water disease
description_1: Bacterial infection causing catastrophic, painless, watery diarrhea ('rice-water' mostly fluid). Can kill within hours via dehydration.
medicine_1: IMMEDIATE and CONTINUOUS ORS (Oral Rehydration Solution). Literally drink as much as you are losing. Go to hospital NOW.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately. Cholera is a notifiable medical emergency.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: ORS is the ONLY priority initially. Normal food once rehydrated. AVOID: Plain water only (need electrolytes);unsanitary water sources.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wash hands with soap relentlessly. Boil all drinking/cooking water during outbreaks.
description_2: Persistent symptoms without massive rehydration lead to shock, muscle cramps, and collapse very quickly.
medicine_2: Antibiotics (Doxycycline/Azithromycin) can shorten duration but FLUIDS save lives. IV fluids almost always needed.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor. Don't wait to see if it gets better.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Zinc supplements for children after recovery. AVOID: eating raw/undercooked seafood (common source).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Safe disposal of patient's stool is critical to prevent community spread.
description_3: Severe Cholera can cause death in 50% of cases if untreated, drops to <1% with proper rehydration.
medicine_3: Requires massive volumes of IV fluids rapidly.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if diarrhea is like 'rice water' and very frequent.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Coconut water if ORS unavailable temporarily. AVOID: delaying transport to hospital.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Oral cholera vaccines are available for travelers to high-risk areas.

keywords: flu;influenza;viral fever severe;body ache fever;high fever cough;seasonal flu;bedridden with cold
description_1: Unlike a common cold, the Flu hits you suddenly like a truck. High fever, severe body aches, and extreme fatigue are common.
medicine_1: Paracetamol (Dolo/Crocin) for fever/aches. Oseltamivir (Tamiflu) ONLY if prescribed early (within 48hrs). Rest is the main cure.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if fever >103°F lasts >3 days;or difficulty breathing (could be pneumonia complication).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Hot soups;turmeric milk;plenty of fluids (fever causes dehydration). AVOID: Cold foods;exertion of ANY kind.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Complete bed rest for at least 3-5 days. Isolate from family to prevent spread.
description_2: Persistent flu can leave you feeling weak for weeks ('post-viral fatigue'). Cough might linger.
medicine_2: Continue supportive care (steam;warm fluids). Don't rush back to work/school.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you start getting better then suddenly get worse again with high fever (secondary bacterial infection).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin C rich fruits once fever settles. AVOID: smoking.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Gentle movement only after fully recovered.
description_3: Severe Flu can be fatal for elderly/babies due to pneumonia or organ failure.
medicine_3: Hospitalization for IV fluids/oxygen might be needed for high-risk groups.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if severe shortness of breath;chest pain;or blue lips occur.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Soft nutritious diet. AVOID: ignoring annual flu vaccine if you are in a high-risk group.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Cover coughs/sneezes strictly.

keywords: chikungunya;joint pain fever;mosquito fever joints;severe joint swelling;bending joint pain;rash with fever
description_1: Viral infection from mosquitoes. Similar to Dengue but characterized by intense, debilitating joint pain that can last months.
medicine_1: Paracetamol for fever/pain. Do NOT take Aspirin. Cold packs on painful swollen joints.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if fever persists >5 days;or joint pain is unbearable and prevents walking completely.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Coconut water;fresh juices;leafy greens to boost recovery. AVOID: Processed/oily foods that increase inflammation.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Rest is vital. Use mosquito nets. Even after fever goes, joints might hurt severely.
description_2: Persistent joint pain (arthritis) can last for months or even years after the initial fever is gone.
medicine_2: Doctor might prescribe stronger NSAIDs (Naproxen) or mild steroids specifically for post-chikungunya arthritis.
doctor_consult_2: See rheumatologist if joint pain continues beyond 3 months.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory diet (rich in Omega-3;turmeric/curcumin). AVOID: strenuous high-impact exercise while joints are inflamed.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Gentle physiotherapy helps prevent joints from becoming permanently stiff.
description_3: Severe cases are rarely fatal but can cause long-term disability due to joint pain.
medicine_3: Supportive care in hospital if dehydration occurs during acute fever phase.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have unusual bleeding or severe neurological symptoms (rare).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: allowing mosquitoes to breed near your house.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Use repellents diligently.

keywords: dog bite;kutte ne kata;animal bite;rabies risk;cat bite;monkey bite;scratch by stray animal
description_1: Any bite or scratch from a stray animal (dog/cat/monkey) carries a Rabies risk, which is 100% fatal if NOT treated.
medicine_1: IMMEDIATE: Wash wound with soap and RUNNING water for 15 full minutes. This is the most crucial step. Go to hospital for vaccine.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately. You MUST get the Anti-Rabies Vaccine (ARV) course (usually 4-5 injections over a month).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: Applying turmeric/chilli powder/soil to the wound (increases infection risk).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Do NOT stitch the wound immediately unless very severe (traps virus inside).
description_2: Persistent fear of water (hydrophobia) appears only when it's too late. Prevention is the ONLY cure.
medicine_2: Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) injection directly into the wound might be needed if bite is deep/bleeding (Category 3).
doctor_consult_2: See doctor for EVERY animal bite, even a small scratch from a stray pup.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Nutritious food to support immune response to vaccine. AVOID: missing ANY scheduled dose of the vaccine.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Observe the animal for 10 days if possible (if it's a known pet), but don't delay YOUR treatment.
description_3: Severe Rabies is untreatable once symptoms start.
medicine_3: Palliative care only.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL immediately after ANY animal bite for PEP (Post-Exposure Prophylaxis).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: traditional healers/magic remedies for dog bites - they do not work for rabies.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Complete the full vaccine course (Days 0, 3, 7, 14, 28 usually).

keywords: stroke;brain attack;lakwa;paralysis one side;slurred speech sudden;face drooping;arm weakness sudden
description_1: Sudden interruption of blood to brain. remember F.A.S.T: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call ambulance.
medicine_1: Medical Emergency. NO home remedies. Do not give food/water (might choke). Note the EXACT time symptoms started.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately. Rush to a major hospital with CT scan facility. Time is brain (millions of neurons die every minute).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Nothing by mouth until cleared by doctor. AVOID: giving aspirin unless doctor on phone says so (could be a bleeding stroke).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Lay patient flat or with head slightly raised. Loosen tight clothing. Keep them calm.
description_2: Persistent symptoms depend on how quickly they got treatment. Can range from mild weakness to total paralysis.
medicine_2: Clot-busting injection (tPA) can ONLY be given within 4.5 hours of first symptom. Rehabilitation is key later.
doctor_consult_2: See neurologist for long term management and prevention of second stroke.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Low salt;low fat DASH diet to prevent recurrence. AVOID: Smoking;trans fats.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Physical/Speech therapy is crucial for recovery of lost functions.
description_3: Severe massive stroke can be fatal or cause permanent coma/severe disability.
medicine_3: Neurosurgery might be needed to relieve pressure if it's a bleeding (hemorrhagic) stroke.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: CALL AMBULANCE if ANY stroke sign appears, even if it goes away quickly (TIA - 'mini stroke' is a major warning sign).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Tube feeding might be needed initially. AVOID: ignoring TIA symptoms just because they resolved.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Manage BP, diabetes, and cholesterol strictly to prevent it.

keywords: hernia;aant utarna;bulge in groin;swelling near navel;pain when lifting;lump in stomach appearing when coughing
description_1: An internal organ (usually intestine) pushes through a weak spot in muscle wall. Causes a soft bulge that might disappear when lying down.
medicine_1: Avoid heavy lifting or straining (constipation/heavy coughing). Wear supportive underwear. It will NOT heal on its own.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if bulge becomes painful;red;hard;or doesn't go back in when lying down.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: High fiber diet to PREVENT constipation and straining. AVOID: Heavy meals that cause bloating and increase abdominal pressure.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: When coughing/sneezing, press gently on the hernia to support it.
description_2: Persistent hernias usually get bigger over time. You might feel a dragging sensation in groin.
medicine_2: Surgery (Hernioplasty with mesh) is the standard lasting cure.
doctor_consult_2: See surgeon to plan elective surgery before it becomes an emergency.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Healthy weight (obesity increases pressure). AVOID: smoking (causes coughing which worsens hernia).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Gentle walks are okay, avoid intense core exercises until treated.
description_3: Strangulated Hernia: The trapped intestine loses blood supply. It's life-threatening.
medicine_3: Emergency surgery required to save the intestine from dying (gangrene).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if hernia is stuck OUT and is extremely painful;swollen;or you are vomiting.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: NBM (nothing by mouth) if heading to hospital for emergency. AVOID: waiting if it gets stuck.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Post-surgery recovery usually takes 4-6 weeks before heavy lifting is allowed.

keywords: lactose intolerance;doodh se allergy;milk allergy;gas after milk;diarrhea after dairy;bloating from milk;stomach rumble milk
description_1: Inability to digest lactose (sugar in milk). Causes gas, bloating, and diarrhea 30 mins to 2 hours after dairy.
medicine_1: Stop drinking plain milk. Try curd/yogurt (often better tolerated due to fermentation). Use lactose-free milk if available.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have these symptoms with ALL foods (might be IBS, not just lactose);or if you lose weight.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Lactose-free dairy;soy/almond milk;curd;hard cheeses (low lactose). AVOID: Milk;soft cheeses;ice cream;cream sauces.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Read labels: 'whey', 'milk solids' contain lactose. Enzyme tablets (Lactase) can be taken before dairy meals.
description_2: Persistent symptoms mean you are still consuming hidden lactose. It's uncomfortable but not dangerous.
medicine_2: Lactase enzyme supplements (like Yamoo tablets) can allow you to eat occasional dairy without symptoms.
doctor_consult_2: See gastroenterologist/dietitian to ensure you are getting enough Calcium if you cut ALL dairy.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Calcium rich non-dairy foods (ragi;sesame seeds;leafy greens). AVOID: forcing yourself to drink milk if it hurts.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Experiment to find your threshold - some can handle a little tea/coffee with milk.
description_3: Severe intolerance causes immediate explosive diarrhea and severe cramping after even small amounts.
medicine_3: Strict avoidance is necessary.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you see blood in stool (NOT a symptom of lactose intolerance - something else is wrong).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration after diarrhea episodes. AVOID: assuming it's a milk 'allergy' (allergy can cause hives/anaphylaxis, intolerance is just gut issues).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Most Indian adults have some degree of lactose intolerance naturally.

keywords: bleeding gums;masoode se khoon;gingivitis;swollen gums;blood when brushing;bad breath gums;gum infection
description_1: Early stage gum disease from plaque buildup. Gums are red, puffy, and bleed easily when brushing.
medicine_1: Brush GENTLY twice daily with soft brush. Floss daily (bleeding will STOP after a week of regular flossing). Warm salt water rinses.
doctor_consult_1: Consult dentist for a professional cleaning (scaling). It's often needed to remove hardened plaque (tartar).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Vitamin C rich foods (amla/oranges) for gum health. Crunchy raw veggies. AVOID: Sugary sticky snacks that sit on teeth.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't stop brushing because it bleeds! That makes it worse. Brush visibly red areas gently but thoroughly.
description_2: Persistent bleeding can lead to Periodontitis (advanced gum disease) where bone is lost and teeth become loose.
medicine_2: Medicinal toothpastes (containing alum/astringents) might help temporarily but don't cure the root cause (tartar).
doctor_consult_2: See dentist every 6 months. If teeth start feeling loose, it's advanced.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Green tea (catechins help gum health). AVOID: Smoking/tobacco (major cause of severe gum disease).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Massage gums gently with finger after brushing.
description_3: Severe Periodontitis can lead to tooth loss and is linked to heart disease and diabetes complications.
medicine_3: Deep cleaning (root planing) or gum surgery might be needed.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if gums are severely swollen;painful;with pus discharge (dental abscess).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Soft foods if painful. AVOID: neglecting it - you can't grow back lost gum/bone.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Pregnant women are more prone to gingivitis due to hormones.

keywords: ear wax;kaan band;wax blockage;hard wax ear;decreased hearing;plugged ear sensation;tinnitus from wax
description_1: Earwax is normal, but sometimes it builds up and blocks the ear canal, causing sudden hearing loss or 'fullness'.
medicine_1: Do NOT use ear buds/Q-tips/pins (pushes wax deeper!). Use OTC wax softening drops (Otorex/Soliwax) for 3-5 days.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if drops don't clear it;or if you have pain/discharge (might be infection, not just wax).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. Chewing helps move wax out naturally. AVOID: putting hot oil or garlic in ear without medical advice.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: After 3 days of drops, gentle shower water might wash it out. If not, need doctor to remove it.
description_2: Persistent blockage can cause tinnitus (ringing) or mild dizziness.
medicine_2: ENT doctor can perform microsuction or ear syringing to remove hard wax safely in minutes.
doctor_consult_2: See ENT. Don't let unqualified roadside 'ear cleaners' touch your ears with sharp tools.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Stay hydrated. AVOID: inserting anything smaller than your elbow into your ear!
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Some people just naturally produce more wax.
description_3: Severe impaction can press on eardrum causing pain.
medicine_3: Professional removal required.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have severe pain;bleeding;or sudden TOTAL hearing loss (could be sudden sensorineural hearing loss - emergency).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Patience with drops. AVOID: aggressive cleaning.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Ears are generally self-cleaning; wax slowly migrates out on its own usually.

keywords: boil;baltod;furuncle;painful pus bump;abscess skin;red swollen lump;pimple turned big
description_1: A deep bacterial infection of a hair follicle. Starts as a red painful lump, then fills with pus.
medicine_1: Warm compress (cloth dipped in hot water) for 15 mins, 4 times a day to bring it to a head. Do NOT squeeze it early.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if boil is on FACE (danger zone);very large (>2 inches);accompanied by fever;or keeps recurring.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Turmeric (anti-inflammatory). AVOID: excess sugar (high sugar levels can cause recurrent boils).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wash hands before and after touching it. Wash clothes/towels separately in hot water.
description_2: Persistent or multiple boils (carbuncle) often need antibiotics. Might indicate diabetes if frequent.
medicine_2: Oral antibiotics (like Cephalexin/Amoxicillin) and topical antibiotic cream (T-Bact/Mupirocin).
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if it doesn't drain on its own after a week of warm compresses.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Garlic/neem (traditional blood purifiers). AVOID: sharing razors/towels.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Don't shave over a boil.
description_3: Severe large boils might need small surgical cut (incision and drainage) by doctor to let pus out.
medicine_3: NEVER try to cut it open yourself at home (risk of severe spreading infection/sepsis).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if red streaks appear spreading away from the boil (cellulitis) or you have high fever.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: popping it with a needle at home.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Keep it covered with a sterile bandage once it opens and drains.

keywords: measles;khasra;high fever rash kids;runny nose red eyes rash;koplik spots;viral rash unvaccinated
description_1: Highly contagious viral illness. Starts with high fever, runny nose, red eyes, then a blotchy rash starts on face and spreads down.
medicine_1: No specific antiviral. Supportive care: Paracetamol for fever. Vitamin A supplements drastically reduce severity/complications.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately if suspected. It is highly contagious. Isolate the child.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Fluids;ORS;soft foods. AVOID: contact with unvaccinated babies/pregnant women.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Keep child in a dimly lit room if eyes are sensitive to light (common).
description_2: Persistent measles can lead to ear infections, pneumonia, or severe diarrhea.
medicine_2: Antibiotics ONLY if secondary bacterial pneumonia/ear infection develops.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if breathing becomes fast or difficult, or child becomes very drowsy.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin A rich foods once recovered. AVOID: public places for at least 4 days after rash appears.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Vaccination (MMR) is highly effective prevention.
description_3: Severe complications include encephalitis (brain swelling) and death, especially in malnourished children.
medicine_3: Requires hospitalization for supportive care (oxygen/IV fluids).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if seizures occur;severe difficulty breathing;or extreme lethargy.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Continued breastfeeding for babies. AVOID: underestimating it - it's a major killer of children globally.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Check MMR vaccination status of all family members.

keywords: mumps;kanped;swollen cheeks;pain near jaw ear;swollen salivary glands;fever puffy face
description_1: Viral infection causing painful swelling of salivary glands (parotid) just below/in front of ears. Gives 'hamster face' look.
medicine_1: Supportive care: Paracetamol for pain/fever. Warm or cold compress on swollen jaw (whichever feels better).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have severe headache/stiff neck;or testicular pain in males (orchitis complication).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Soft foods that don't require much chewing (khichdi/soup/mashed potatoes). AVOID: Sour foods (lemon/pickles) - they stimulate painful glands to make more saliva.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Isolate patient for 5 days after swelling starts. Bed rest.
description_2: Persistent Mumps can sometimes spread to other glands. In teen/adult males, it can affect testicles.
medicine_2: Scrotal support and stronger painkillers needed for orchitis. rare sterility risk.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if abdominal pain is severe (pancreatitis is a rare complication).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Hydrating fluids (non-acidic). AVOID: going to school/work until 5 days after swelling began.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: MMR vaccine prevents it.
description_3: Severe complications include meningitis or deafness (rare but possible).
medicine_3: Hospitalization needed for severe complications.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if severe headache;repeated vomiting;or seizures occur.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Bland diet. AVOID: contact with unvaccinated people.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Good oral hygiene is important during illness.

keywords: warts;massa;skin growth;viral wart;verruca;rough bump on skin;cauliflower like bump
description_1: Small, rough, non-painful growths on skin caused by HPV virus. Common on hands/feet.
medicine_1: Most go away eventually (can take years). OTC Salicylic acid paint (Duofilm/Salicyl) applied DAILY after soaking in warm water works slowly.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if warts are on face/genitals (need different treatment);painful;or multiplying rapidly.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Immune boosting foods. AVOID: picking or biting them (spreads virus to other areas/fingers).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use a pumice stone gently to remove dead skin before applying wart paint. Don't share nail clippers.
description_2: Persistent warts can be stubborn. Plantar warts (on feet) can be painful to walk on.
medicine_2: Dermatologist can do Cryotherapy (freezing with liquid nitrogen) or Radiofrequency removal for quicker results.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist. Don't try to cut them off yourself (they bleed a lot and will regrow).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: walking barefoot in public showers/pools.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Keep warts covered with a band-aid if kids are prone to picking them.
description_3: Severe/Multiple warts might indicate lower immunity.
medicine_3: Immunomodulators might be prescribed.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if wart bleeds uncontrollably or changes color/appearance drastically (rarely could be something else).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Patience - treatment takes weeks to months. AVOID: magic cures.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: They are contagious through direct contact.

keywords: corns;callus;gokhru;hard skin foot;painful thickened skin toe;shoe bite marks;hard lump on foot
description_1: Thickened, hardened layers of skin caused by friction/pressure, usually from ill-fitting shoes. Corns are smaller/deeper, calluses are wider.
medicine_1: Wear comfortable shoes! Use Corn caps (contain salicylic acid) with caution. Soak feet in warm water and gently use pumice stone.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have DIABETES (never treat foot issues at home if diabetic!);or if it looks infected (red/pus).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: Tight pointed shoes;walking barefoot outside.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use silicone toe separators or cushioned insoles to reduce pressure on the area.
description_2: Persistent corns can feel like walking on a stone. They have a hard center core that presses on nerves.
medicine_2: Podiatrist can safely pare (shave) down the corn with a sterile blade.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor/podiatrist if it's very painful or keeps coming back.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Good foot hygiene. AVOID: cutting corns with razor blades at home (high infection risk).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Moisturize feet daily (but not between toes if prone to fungus).
description_3: Severe infected corns can lead to foot ulcers, especially in diabetics.
medicine_3: Requires antibiotics and professional wound care.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if area becomes red;hot;and very painful (cellulitis).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy diet for tissue repair. AVOID: ignoring them until they alter how you walk (can cause knee/back pain).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Changing footwear is usually the most important long-term cure.

keywords: tennis elbow;elbow pain;pain outside elbow;lateral epicondylitis;pain lifting cup;stiff elbow;forearm pain
description_1: Pain on the OUTER part of elbow caused by overuse of forearm muscles (not just from tennis! common in carpenters/cooks/typing).
medicine_1: Rest from the activity that caused it. Ice pack 15 mins 3x/day. Tennis elbow brace (strap just below elbow) helps reduce strain.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if pain is severe;elbow is swollen/red;or you can't bend/straighten arm.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods. AVOID: repetitive gripping/twisting actions (wringing clothes/using screwdriver).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Lift objects with palm facing UP. Use thicker pens/tools (easier to grip).
description_2: Persistent pain can last 6 months to 2 years if not rested. It hurts to shake hands or lift a cup.
medicine_2: Physiotherapy for eccentric strengthening exercises is the most effective long-term cure. Steroid injection gives short term relief only.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist if no improvement after 6 months of conservative care.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Collagen/Vitamin C might help tendon repair. AVOID: pushing through the pain.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Ergonomic workstation setup if typing is the cause.
description_3: Severe chronic cases might rarely need surgery to remove damaged tendon tissue.
medicine_3: Surgery is last resort.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have numbness in hand (could be nerve entrapment instead).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: sudden heavy lifting after a period of rest.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Warming up arm muscles before work/sport can prevent recurrence.

keywords: osteoporosis;haddi kamzor;weak bones;silent disease;fracture easily;stooped posture;loss of height
description_1: Bones become porous and weak. Usually NO symptoms until a bone breaks from a minor fall (wrist/hip/spine).
medicine_1: Prevention is key: Weight-bearing exercise (walking/dancing). Adequate Calcium and Vitamin D intake throughout life.
doctor_consult_1: Consult doctor for a DEXA scan (bone density test) if you are a post-menopausal woman or man >70.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Milk;yogurt;cheese;ragi;leafy greens;supplements if prescribed. AVOID: Smoking;excess alcohol;excess salt/caffeine (leaches calcium).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Fall-proof your home: remove loose rugs, install grab bars, keep good lighting.
description_2: Persistent untreated osteoporosis leads to 'fragility fractures' and hunched back (dowager's hump) from spinal compression.
medicine_2: Bisphosphonate medications (taken weekly/monthly) can help increase bone density.
doctor_consult_2: See endocrinologist/orthopedist for management.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Protein is also needed for bone structure. AVOID: forward bending exercises (like toe touches) if you have spinal osteoporosis (risk of crush fracture).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Tai Chi or yoga can help improve balance to prevent falls.
description_3: Severe hip fractures in elderly can be life-threatening due to immobility complications.
medicine_3: Surgery often needed for hip fractures.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if sudden severe back pain occurs (could be spinal fracture) even without a fall.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet with enough calories. AVOID: being dangerously underweight.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's never too late to start bone-healthy habits, but earlier is better.

keywords: enlarged prostate;BPH;frequent urination night men;weak urine stream;dribbling urine;urgency to pee;prostate problem
description_1: Non-cancerous enlargement of prostate gland in older men. Squeezes urethra causing trouble starting flow, weak stream, and frequent night visits.
medicine_1: Limit fluids 2 hours before bed. Double void (pee, wait a min, try again to empty bladder fully). decrease caffeine/alcohol.
doctor_consult_1: Consult urologist if you can't pee AT ALL (medical emergency);or have blood in urine.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Pumpkin seeds (some evidence they help);tomatoes (lycopene for prostate health). AVOID: Antihistamines/decongestants (can suddenly block urine flow in BPH patients).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't hold urine for long. Pelvic floor exercises (Kegels) might help some control.
description_2: Persistent BPH gets slowly worse. You might feel bladder is never empty.
medicine_2: Medications (Tamsulosin/Finasteride) can relax muscles or shrink the prostate effectively.
doctor_consult_2: See urologist annually to monitor and rule out prostate cancer (PSA test).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Healthy fats. AVOID: constipation (straining worsens symptoms).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Sit down to urinate if it helps empty bladder better.
description_3: Severe BPH can completely block urine flow (Acute Urinary Retention). Very painful.
medicine_3: Requires immediate catheterization in hospital to drain bladder, possibly surgery (TURP) later.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if you have a visibly swollen painful lower belly and cannot pass urine.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: High fiber to avoid constipation. AVOID: delaying treatment - it can damage kidneys back-pressure.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's very common part of aging for men, not always dangerous.

keywords: dry eye;aankh mein ruk hapan;gritty eyes;burning eyes chronic;feeling something in eye;redness irritation;watery eyes reflex
description_1: Chronic lack of sufficient lubrication on eye surface. ironically, can sometimes cause watery eyes (reflex tearing due to irritation).
medicine_1: Use preservative-free artificial tears frequently (4+ times/day). Warm compresses help unblock oil glands in eyelids.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if OTC drops don't help enough;or you have severe pain/sensitivity to light.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Omega-3 fatty acid supplements (fish oil/flaxseed) significantly help tear quality. AVOID: Direct fans/AC blowing on face;smoke.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Blink consciously when on screens. Use a humidifier in your room.
description_2: Persistent severe dry eye can damage the cornea surface. Eyes might feel constantly sandy or burning.
medicine_2: Ophthalmologist might prescribe Cyclosporine eye drops (Restasis) to increase tear production. Punctal plugs might be inserted to save tears.
doctor_consult_2: See eye doctor to rule out autoimmune conditions like Sjogren's syndrome.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Hydrating foods. AVOID: prolonged contact lens use if eyes are irritated.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Take regular screen breaks (20-20-20 rule).
description_3: Severe untreated cases can lead to corneal ulcers or scarring and vision loss.
medicine_3: Specialized scleral contact lenses might be needed for extreme cases.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have sudden vision changes or intense pain.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Water. AVOID: rubbing eyes (can scratch the dry cornea).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Sleep with eyes fully closed (some people sleep with them slightly open without realizing).

keywords: vitiligo;leucoderma;safed daag;white patches on skin;loss of skin color;depigmentation;white spots
description_1: Autoimmune condition where pigment cells die, causing milky white patches on skin. Not contagious or dangerous, just cosmetic.
medicine_1: Sunscreen is vital on white patches (they burn easily). Cosmetic camouflage (makeup) can be used if desired.
doctor_consult_1: Consult dermatologist for diagnosis and to discuss treatment options if patches are spreading.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Foods rich in antioxidants might help (evidence limited but good for general health). AVOID: Stress (often triggers new patches);skin injury (new patches can form on cuts).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: It does NOT happen due to eating fish after milk (common myth in India).
description_2: Persistent vitiligo might be stable for years or slowly spread. It most often affects face, hands, and feet.
medicine_2: Treatments include corticosteroid creams, tacrolimus, or UV light therapy (phototherapy) to restore some color.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist early - treatment works better on new, small patches.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: chemical/industrial exposure that might trigger it.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Psychological support is important if it affects self-esteem.
description_3: Severe widespread vitiligo might be treated by depigmenting the remaining normal skin to match (Michael Jackson case).
medicine_3: Requires strict medical supervision.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None - it is not a medical emergency. Consult standard for management.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy lifestyle. AVOID: myths and stigma - educate family that it's not contagious.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Some patches might repigment spontaneously, especially in children.

keywords: cholera;haiza;rice water stools;severe watery diarrhea;rapid dehydration;vomiting no nausea;contaminated water disease
description_1: Bacterial infection causing catastrophic, painless, watery diarrhea ('rice-water' mostly fluid). Can kill within hours via dehydration.
medicine_1: IMMEDIATE and CONTINUOUS ORS (Oral Rehydration Solution). Literally drink as much as you are losing. Go to hospital NOW.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately. Cholera is a notifiable medical emergency.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: ORS is the ONLY priority initially. Normal food once rehydrated. AVOID: Plain water only (need electrolytes);unsanitary water sources.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wash hands with soap relentlessly. Boil all drinking/cooking water during outbreaks.
description_2: Persistent symptoms without massive rehydration lead to shock, muscle cramps, and collapse very quickly.
medicine_2: Antibiotics (Doxycycline/Azithromycin) can shorten duration but FLUIDS save lives. IV fluids almost always needed.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor. Don't wait to see if it gets better.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Zinc supplements for children after recovery. AVOID: eating raw/undercooked seafood (common source).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Safe disposal of patient's stool is critical to prevent community spread.
description_3: Severe Cholera can cause death in 50% of cases if untreated, drops to <1% with proper rehydration.
medicine_3: Requires massive volumes of IV fluids rapidly.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if diarrhea is like 'rice water' and very frequent.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Coconut water if ORS unavailable temporarily. AVOID: delaying transport to hospital.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Oral cholera vaccines are available for travelers to high-risk areas.

keywords: lost voice;gala baithna;hoarse voice;husky voice;can't speak properly;sore throat no voice;whispering only
description_1: Inflammation of your voice box (larynx) usually from a cold or shouting too much. Your voice sounds raspy or disappears.
medicine_1: COMPLETE voice rest (no whispering either! it strains more). Steam inhalation. Salt water gargles.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it lasts >2 weeks (persistent hoarseness needs checking for other causes like nodules);or if you cough blood.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Warm honey-lemon water;soups. AVOID: Very hot/very cold drinks;caffeine;alcohol (dehydrates vocal cords).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use a humidifier. Do not smoke. Avoid clearing your throat forcefully (it slams vocal cords together).
description_2: Persistent hoarseness in smokers needs serious evaluation to rule out throat cancer.
medicine_2: No specific meds usually. Cough suppressants if coughing is irritating the cords.
doctor_consult_2: See ENT specialist for laryngoscopy if it doesn't resolve.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Hydrating non-acidic fluids. AVOID: spicy foods that might cause reflux (which irritates vocal cords).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Communicate via writing/texting to give cords total break.
description_3: Severe swelling can rarely block airway in children (Croup - sounds like barking cough).
medicine_3: Medical emergency in kids if breathing is noisy (stridor).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if child has difficulty breathing or makes high-pitched noise when inhaling.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Cool mist might help kids. AVOID: panicking the child (crying makes swelling worse).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Adults rarely get severe airway blockage from simple laryngitis.

keywords: hyperthyroid;wajan kam hona;weight loss sudden;shaking hands;fast heartbeat at rest;feeling hot always;bulging eyes
description_1: Thyroid gland is OVERactive. Everything speeds up: you lose weight despite eating, feel anxious, shaky, and hot.
medicine_1: Requires specific anti-thyroid drugs (Neomercazole) prescribed by endocrinologist after blood tests confirms low TSH/high T3/T4.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have racing heart rate >100bpm at rest;unexplained weight loss;or very shaky hands.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: High calorie nutritious diet (you burn energy fast). Calcium rich foods. AVOID: excessive iodine (seaweed/iodized salt supplements) unless doctor advises.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Reduce stress. Avoid caffeine (already overstimulated). Wear light clothing if feeling hot.
description_2: Persistent untreated hyperthyroidism can strain the heart and cause osteoporosis.
medicine_2: Beta-blockers (Propranolol) often given initially to control fast heart rate and shaking while waiting for main meds to work.
doctor_consult_2: See endocrinologist regularly to adjust dose. Over-treatment can make you hypothyroid!
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Broccoli/cabbage (goitrogens) might be slightly beneficial here (opposite of hypothyroid advice). AVOID: stimulants.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use eye drops if you have bulging eyes (Graves' ophthalmopathy) to prevent dryness.
description_3: Thyroid Storm is a life-threatening flare-up with high fever, rapid irregular heart rate, and delirium.
medicine_3: Medical emergency requiring ICU care.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if you have high fever;intense agitation;or confusion.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: High energy / protein diet during active phase. AVOID: vigorous exercise until stabilized.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Radioactive iodine or surgery might be needed if tablets don't work long-term.

keywords: GERD;chronic acidity;food coming up;severe heartburn daily;sour taste in mouth morning;chest burning night;acid regurgitation
description_1: More severe than simple acidity. Stomach acid constantly flows back into food pipe, especially at night, causing damage.
medicine_1: Lifestyle changes are key. PPIs (Pantoprazole DSR) taken daily EMPTY STOMACH for a prescribed course (e.g. 4-8 weeks).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have difficulty swallowing (feels like food gets stuck);weight loss;or black stools.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Oatmeal;ginger;non-citrus fruits (melon/banana);boiled vegetables. AVOID: The 'big triggers': Tomato;raw onion;garlic;chocolate;coffee;mint;fatty fried food.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Eat dinner 3 hours before lying down. Raise the head side of your BED by 6 inches (blocks not just pillows).
description_2: Persistent untreated GERD can lead to Barrett's esophagus (pre-cancerous changes).
medicine_2: Long-term acid suppression might be needed. Antacids (Gelusil) for breakthrough symptoms only.
doctor_consult_2: See gastroenterologist for Endoscopy if symptoms persist despite meds.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Alkaline foods. AVOID: tight belts or clothes that press on stomach.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Sleep on your LEFT side (anatomy makes it harder for acid to rise). lose weight if obese.
description_3: Severe cases might need surgery (Fundoplication) to tighten the valve between stomach and food pipe.
medicine_3: Surgery is a last resort but effective.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if chest pain is severe and crushing (can mimic heart attack - get ECG to be safe).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Smaller frequent meals (5 small instead of 3 big). AVOID: alcohol and smoking completely.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Chewing sugar-free gum after meals can increase saliva and neutralize acid.

keywords: contact dermatitis;skin allergy soap;rash from jewelry;itchy red skin after touching;metal allergy;chemical rash
description_1: Skin rash caused by touching something you are allergic to (nickel in artificial jewelry, new soap, harsh detergent).
medicine_1: Identify and REMOVE the trigger immediately. Wash area with mild soap water. Calamine lotion or mild steroid cream (Hydrocortisone) for itch.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if rash is severe;blistered;on face/genitals;or spreading widely.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods. AVOID: wearing cheap artificial jewelry if you have metal allergy (stick to gold/silver/stainless steel).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Switch to fragrance-free, hypoallergenic soaps and detergents. Wear gloves when cleaning with chemicals.
description_2: Persistent rash will continue as long as the trigger is touching you. It can become thick and leathery.
medicine_2: Stronger topical steroids prescribed by dermatologist.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist for Patch Testing to find out exactly what you are allergic to.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: scratching (can cause secondary bacterial infection).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Moisturize constantly to repair skin barrier.
description_3: Severe cases can cause widespread blistering and weeping skin.
medicine_3: Oral steroids might be needed for a short course to calm massive inflammation.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if rash is near eyes or covers large part of body.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: using the suspected product 'just one more time' to test it.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Common Indian triggers: 'rol-gold' jewelry, certain bindis/sindoor, harsh detergents used for hand-washing clothes.

keywords: trigger finger;finger stuck bent;finger clicking when straightening;pain at base of finger;locking finger;thumb catch
description_1: A finger (or thumb) gets stuck in a bent position and then snaps straight with a click (like a trigger). caused by inflamed tendon.
medicine_1: Rest the hand. Splinting the finger straight at night can help. Gently massage the base of the finger.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if finger is permanently stuck bent and you cannot straighten it at all with other hand.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory diet (turmeric/omega-3). AVOID: repetitive gripping actions (using scissors/screwdriver) that aggravate it.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use tools with wider grip handles to reduce strain on tendons.
description_2: Persistent clicking can be painful and make it hard to use the hand. Common in diabetics.
medicine_2: Steroid injection directly into the tendon sheath by orthopedist is VERY effective for most people.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist if it doesn't improve with rest/splinting.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: forcing it to snap repeatedly (damages tendon more).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Soak hand in warm water before doing gentle stretching exercises.
description_3: Severe cases that don't respond to injections need minor surgery.
medicine_3: Trigger finger release surgery is a quick day-care procedure with high success rate.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None typically. Consult standard.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Good blood sugar control (if diabetic) to prevent recurrence. AVOID: ignoring early stiffness.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Often starts as just a painless clicking before becoming painful.

keywords: costochondritis;chest wall pain;pain when pressing chest;rib pain near breastbone;sharp chest pain breathing;not heart pain
description_1: Inflammation of cartilage connecting ribs to breastbone. Causes sharp chest pain, often mistaken for heart attack, but it HURTS TO TOUCH.
medicine_1: Rest. NSAID painkillers (Ibuprofen/Diclofenac) are main treatment. Heating pad on chest.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately if unsure if it's heart pain or rib pain. Always safer to get ECG if aged >35 or have risk factors.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods. AVOID: heavy lifting;push-ups;strenuous upper body activity.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Correct posture. avoid carrying heavy bags on one shoulder.
description_2: Persistent pain can last weeks or months. It is harmless but annoying.
medicine_2: Physiotherapy with ultrasound or TENS can help chronic cases.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you have fever with it, or swelling (Tietze syndrome).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: anxiety - once heart is cleared, remind yourself it's just inflammation.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Gentle chest stretching exercises once acute pain subsides.
description_3: Severe cases are rare, it's usually self-limiting.
medicine_3: Stronger anti-inflammatories might be needed.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if pain radiates to arm/jaw, or you are sweating/breathless (classic heart attack signs).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: pressing it constantly to 'check' if it still hurts (keeps it inflamed!).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It often follows a viral cough (from strain of coughing).

keywords: BV;fishy smell discharge;bad smelling vaginal discharge;thin grey discharge;vaginal odor;imbalance bacteria
description_1: Not an STD, but an imbalance of natural bacteria. Main symptom is a strong 'fishy' odor and thin greyish discharge.
medicine_1: Doesn't always need treatment if mild, but Metronidazole (antibiotic) tablets or gel is standard cure if bothersome.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you are pregnant (BV can sometimes cause early labor);or if odor is persistent.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Probiotics might help prevent recurrence. AVOID: Douching (washing inside vagina) - this is the #1 CAUSE of BV as it destroys good bacteria!
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use only plain water to wash external genitals. Avoid scented soaps/sprays.
description_2: Persistent BV can be annoying and embarrassing. It often comes back after periods or sex.
medicine_2: Doctor might prescribe longer course of probiotics or different antibiotics if it keeps recurring.
doctor_consult_2: See gynecologist to confirm it's BV and not Trichomoniasis (an STD with similar symptoms).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Yogurt with live cultures. AVOID: smoking (linked to higher risk of BV).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wear cotton underwear. Sleep without underwear.
description_3: Severe untreated BV can increase risk of catching STDs or cause Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (rarely).
medicine_3: Antibiotics are needed to prevent complications, especially before any gynecological surgery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have lower belly pain and fever with the discharge.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy diet. AVOID: unprotected sex with new partners (can upset bacterial balance).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Male partners usually don't need treatment.

keywords: rotator cuff;shoulder tear;pain lifting arm side;shoulder weakness;can't comb hair;pain sleeping on shoulder;injury shoulder
description_1: Tear or strain in muscles helping lift the arm. Common in older age or after a fall. Pain often felt deep in shoulder, worse at night.
medicine_1: R.I.C.E initially. NSAID painkillers. Avoid overhead activities but DON'T stop moving shoulder completely (prevents frozen shoulder).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you cannot lift your arm away from your body AT ALL;or severe pain after a fall.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Protein for muscle repair. AVOID: lifting heavy weights;sleeping on the painful side.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use a pillow under your arm while sitting to take weight off the shoulder.
description_2: Persistent pain and weakness means a likely tear. You might use your shoulder blade to 'hike' your arm up instead of smooth movement.
medicine_2: Physiotherapy is CRUCIAL to strengthen remaining intact muscles to compensate.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist for MRI if physio doesn't help in 6 weeks.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Collagen rich foods might help. AVOID: repetitive overhead throwing actions.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Pendulum exercises (swinging arm gently) to keep joint moving.
description_3: Severe complete tears in active young people usually need surgery. Elderly might manage with just physio.
medicine_3: Arthroscopic rotator cuff repair surgery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if sudden inability to move arm after injury.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: carrying heavy bags on that shoulder.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Recovery is slow, takes months of dedicated exercises.

keywords: tinea versicolor;white spots chest back;fungal patches skin;discolored skin patches sweat;non-itchy white spots
description_1: Fungal infection causing small discolored (often white/pink/tan) patches, usually on chest/back. More noticeable after sun exposure as they don't tan.
medicine_1: Anti-fungal shampoo (Ketoconazole) used as a body wash - leave on for 5-10 mins before rinsing, daily for a week.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it covers large part of body;or doesn't improve after 2 weeks of home treatment.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: excessive sweating/oily skin products (fungus loves oily, hot environments).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wear breathable fabrics. Shower immediately after gym/sweating.
description_2: Persistent patches might remain white even after fungus is dead (takes months for color to even out).
medicine_2: Oral antifungal pills (Fluconazole) sometimes needed for widespread cases.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist if you are unsure if it's this or vitiligo (Vitiligo is usually whiter and affects different areas).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Probiotics. AVOID: heavy oil massages on chest/back if prone to this.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wash gym clothes in hot water.
description_3: Severe cases are just cosmetically bothersome, not dangerous.
medicine_3: Recurrence is very common in Indian summers. Preventive use of Ketoconazole wash once a week can help.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None. Consult standard.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Good hygiene. AVOID: worry - it's not contagious to others.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Sun exposure makes it LOOK worse because surrounding skin gets darker, highlighting the pale infected spots.

keywords: fibromyalgia;widespread body pain;chronic fatigue pain;tender points body;fibro fog;unexplained muscle pain
description_1: Chronic condition causing widespread pain, fatigue, and 'tender points' all over body. Not dangerous but very draining.
medicine_1: Gentle aerobic exercise (walking/swimming) is THE best treatment, start very slow. Heat packs for pain.
doctor_consult_1: Consult Rheumatologist for diagnosis (it's a diagnosis of exclusion - other things must be ruled out first).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: Processed foods/excess sugar (some find it worsens pain);caffeine near bedtime.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Prioritize sleep hygiene - poor sleep is a major trigger for fibro pain. Manage stress.
description_2: Persistent 'fibro fog' (difficulty concentrating/memory issues) often accompanies the pain.
medicine_2: Medications like Duloxetine or Pregabalin can help nerve pain and sleep. Standard painkillers (Brufen) usually DON'T help much.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor for regular follow-ups and support.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Magnesium supplements might help muscle tenderness. AVOID: staying in bed all day (inactivity makes pain WORSE long-term).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) helps cope with chronic pain.
description_3: Severe days ('flares') can feel like you have a bad flu permanently.
medicine_3: Be kind to yourself during flares, rest but don't stop moving completely.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None typically. Consult if new different pain develops.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Warm baths with Epsom salts. AVOID: overdoing it on 'good days' (leads to 'crash' next day).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's a real condition, not 'just in your head', despite normal blood tests.

keywords: black eye;kali aankh;bruised eye;punched in eye;swollen purple eyelid;injury to eye orbit
description_1: Bruising around the eye after an injury. Looks alarming (turns purple/black) but often just superficial bleeding under skin.
medicine_1: Ice pack immediately (gently!) for 15 mins every hour for first day to reduce swelling.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately if you have double vision;can't move the eye;blood IN the colored part of eye (hyphema);or severe pain.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Pineapple (contains bromelain, may help bruising fade faster). AVOID: Aspirin (increases bleeding/bruising).
