lifestyle_suggestions_1: Sleep with head elevated to let gravity drain the swelling.
description_2: Persistent bruising changes color (purple -> green -> yellow) over 2 weeks as it heals.
medicine_2: Warm compresses AFTER 48 hours can help clear remaining bruised blood.
doctor_consult_2: See ophthalmologist if vision is even slightly blurry.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin C for capillary health. AVOID: blowing your nose if eye injury was severe (air can get trapped under skin if bone is fractured).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wear protective eye gear during contact sports.
description_3: Severe injury could mean a 'blowout fracture' of the eye socket bones.
medicine_3: Surgery might be needed if muscles are trapped in the fracture.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if pupil shape is irregular or one pupil is much larger than other after injury.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Arnica gel (applied AROUND, not IN the eye) might help bruising. AVOID: pressing on the eyeball.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: The bruising might spread to the other eye or down the cheek due to gravity - this is normal.

keywords: gastritis;pet mein sujan;severe stomach burning;acute acidity;pain after NSAIDs;alcohol stomach pain;vomiting acid
description_1: Sudden inflammation of stomach lining. Often from too much alcohol, spicy food, or painkillers (NSAIDs). intense burning/gnawing pain.
medicine_1: Stop ALL alcohol/painkillers/spicy food immediately. Antacid liquid (Digene/Mucaine gel) every 4-6 hours.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you vomit blood;have severe unmanageable pain;or black stools.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Cold milk;curd rice;bland clear soup;coconut water. AVOID: Alcohol;coffee;chillies;hot tea;citrus juice.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Hydrate with frequent small sips if vomiting. Gut rest (bland food only) for 24-48 hours.
description_2: Persistent gastritis can turn into an ulcer. You might feel full very quickly after starting to eat.
medicine_2: PPIs (Pantoprazole/Rabeprazole) might be prescribed for 1-2 weeks to let lining heal.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if it doesn't settle in 2-3 days.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Aloe vera juice (some find it soothing). AVOID: smoking (increases stomach acid).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Manage stress.
description_3: Severe erosive gastritis can cause significant stomach bleeding.
medicine_3: Requires IV PPIs and possibly endoscopy to stop bleeding.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if you feel dizzy/faint upon standing (sign of internal blood loss).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: very soft diet (khichdi). AVOID: aspirin/brufen for any reason during this time.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Don't eat within 3 hours of bedtime.

keywords: DNS;tedhi naak ki haddi;blocked nose one side;crooked nose inside;frequent sinus infection;snoring DNS;nosebleed one side
description_1: The wall between your nostrils is crooked. Common, but if severe, it blocks one side permanently causing issues.
medicine_1: Saline nasal sprays can keep it moist and reduce crusting. Nasal dilator strips might help sleep.
doctor_consult_1: Consult ENT if it causes chronic sinus infections;severe snoring;or difficulty breathing through nose.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: picking nose (DNS often makes one side dry and prone to bleeding, picking worsens it).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use a humidifier if you frequently get dry nose/bleeds on the wider side.
description_2: Persistent blockage might mean you are a 'mouth breather', leading to dry mouth and bad breath.
medicine_2: Surgery (Septoplasty) is the only way to physically straighten it.
doctor_consult_2: See ENT to discuss if surgery is worth it for your symptom severity.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: decongestant sprays for >3 days (won't fix the bone, will cause rebound).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: If you break your nose, get it set quickly to prevent severe DNS later.
description_3: Severe DNS can completely block one nostril and lead to chronic inevitable sinusitis.
medicine_3: Septoplasty is a common, effective planned surgery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None typically. Consult standard.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Good sleep hygiene. AVOID: ignoring it if it causes sleep apnea.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Many people have mild DNS without knowing it - only treat if it causes problems.

keywords: chronic fatigue;ME;always tired;unrefreshing sleep;exhaustion after minor activity;brain fog fatigue;PEM
description_1: Extreme fatigue that doesn't go away with rest and has no other medical cause. Minor activity (mental/physical) causes a 'crash' later.
medicine_1: 'Pacing' is CRITICAL: do less than you think you can. Stop BEFORE you feel tired. Rest proactively.
doctor_consult_1: Consult to rule out ALL other treatable causes of fatigue (thyroid, anemia, diabetes, sleep apnea etc.).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Balanced nutritious diet. Some find avoiding gluten/dairy helps (unproven but tried by many). AVOID: caffeine/sugar 'crashes' (using energy drinks to push through - it backfires badly).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Prioritize absolutely essential tasks only. Learn to say 'no'.
description_2: Persistent CFS can be debilitating, leaving people housebound. 'Brain fog' makes thinking hard.
medicine_2: No cure. Symptom management (for sleep/pain) helps. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) helps cope with the limitations.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor for supportive care.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Supplements ONLY if deficiencies found. AVOID: 'Graded Exercise Therapy' (pushing harder progressively) - often makes CFS worse.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Listen to your body. If you need a nap, take it.
description_3: Severe cases might need wheelchair use for energy conservation.
medicine_3: Support groups can be very helpful mentally.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if new severe symptoms develop or depression becomes severe.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration with electrolytes (sometimes helps with accompanying dizzy spells). AVOID: snake oil cures.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's a recognized biological illness, not 'laziness'.

keywords: AS;bamboo spine;stiff back morning young male;hip pain morning;spine fusing;inflammatory back pain
description_1: Type of arthritis affecting spine/hips. Usually starts in young men (<40). causes severe MORNING stiffness that improves with exercise.
medicine_1: Exercise is VITAL - stay active to prevent spine from fusing. NSAIDs (Indomethacin) are main early treatment.
doctor_consult_1: Consult rheumatologist if you have back pain >3 months that is worse in morning and better with activity (opposite of mechanical back pain).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory diet (omega-3). AVOID: smoking (accelerates spinal fusion!);high starch diet (some claim it helps to reduce, controversial).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Maintain good posture at all times. Sleep on a firm mattress with a thin pillow.
description_2: Persistent untreated AS can lead to spine vertebrae fusing together ('bamboo spine'), making it rigid.
medicine_2: Biologic drugs (TNF blockers) are revolutionary and can stop progression if started early.
doctor_consult_2: See rheumatologist regularly for monitoring.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Calcium/Vitamin D. AVOID: high impact sports if spine is already stiff (fracture risk).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Swimming is the BEST exercise for AS.
description_3: Severe cases can cause rigid hunched posture and difficulty looking up or turning head.
medicine_3: Surgery (osteotomy) rarely needed for severe deformity.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you develop severe eye redness/pain (Uveitis is a common linked condition).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy weight. AVOID: becoming sedentary - 'rest = rust' in AS.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Genetic marker HLA-B27 is often positive.

keywords: glaucoma attack;kala motiya acute;severe eye pain sudden;blurred vision rainbow halos;hard eye red;headache with eye pain
description_1: Sudden blockage of fluid drainage in eye. Causes excruciating eye pain, headache, nausea, and seeing rainbow-colored halos around lights.
medicine_1: MEDICAL EMERGENCY. RUSH TO EYE HOSPITAL NOW. Permanent blindness can happen in HOURS. No home treatment.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately. Do not wait for morning.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: NBM (nothing by mouth) in case urgent surgery/laser needed. AVOID: waiting;using OTC eye drops (some can make it WORSE).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Try to keep head upright while traveling to hospital.
description_2: Persistent high pressure kills the optic nerve irreversibly.
medicine_2: Hospital will give IV meds (Mannitol) and eye drops to lower pressure instantly. Laser iridotomy done later to prevent recurrence.
doctor_consult_2: See ophthalmologist.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet later. AVOID: activities in dark rooms if prone to this (pupil dilation can trigger attack in susceptible people).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Regular eye checks >40 years old can detect risk factors early.
description_3: Severe attack = Blindness if untreated quickly.
medicine_3: Emergency laser or surgery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if you have severe eye pain with nausea and blurred vision.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Patience during treatment; it can be painful but saves sight. AVOID: stress.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's different from common 'chronic' glaucoma which is painless and slow.

keywords: cataract;motiyabind;cloudy vision;foggy vision;glare from lights night;fading colors eye;lens opacity elderly
description_1: Natural clouding of the eye's lens with age. Vision becomes slowly foggy, like looking through a dirty window.
medicine_1: No medicines/drops can cure it. Surgery is the only fix. Use brighter lights for reading temporarily.
doctor_consult_1: Consult ophthalmologist when vision loss starts interfering with your daily life (driving/reading/cooking).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Antioxidant rich foods (lutein/zeaxanthin in leafy greens/eggs) might SLOW progression slightly. AVOID: smoking (accelerates cataract);excessive UV exposure without sunglasses.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Ensure prescription glasses are up to date (can help temporarily).
description_2: Persistent cataract will eventually make you functionally blind until removed. It is reversible blindness.
medicine_2: Cataract surgery (replacing cloudy lens with artificial one) is very safe and effective.
doctor_consult_2: See eye doctor annually to monitor maturity of cataract.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: rubbing eyes hard.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Surgery is usually done one eye at a time.
description_3: Severe 'mature' white cataracts can sometimes leak and cause painful secondary glaucoma if left too long.
medicine_3: Don't wait until it's completely white/ripe if it's bothering you earlier.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None usually, it's slow. Consult if sudden vision change occurs (not cataract).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Good diabetes control (high sugar accelerates cataracts). AVOID: fear of surgery - it's one of the most common surgeries worldwide.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Post-surgery vision is often excellent.

keywords: pilonidal sinus;tailbone cyst;pain above bum crack;pus near tailbone;hair cyst;jeep bottom;painful lump natal cleft
description_1: Cyst near the tailbone (top of buttocks crack), often containing ingrown hair. Common in hairy young men who sit a lot. very painful if infected.
medicine_1: Keep area clean and dry. Shave the area to prevent more hair entering. Warm compress if it's starting to swell.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it becomes red;hot;very painful swollen lump (abscess) - needs draining.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: prolonged sitting on hard surfaces.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use a coccyx cushion (donut cushion) to sit if painful. lose weight if obese.
description_2: Persistent sinus might keep filling with pus and draining periodically.
medicine_2: Antibiotics calm acute infection. Surgery is needed to remove the whole track permanently.
doctor_consult_2: See surgeon. It often recurs if not removed completely.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: High protein for healing if surgery done. AVOID: ignoring it - complex branching tracts can form.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Laser hair removal in that area is HIGHLY recommended to prevent recurrence.
description_3: Severe infected abscess needs immediate incision and drainage (very painful but instant relief after draining).
medicine_3: Surgery can sometimes leave a wound that takes weeks to heal.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if fever develops with the buttock pain.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Good hygiene. AVOID: embarrassment - surgeons see this everyday.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Keep the area hair-free forever ideally.

keywords: spider bite;insect bite swelling;kide ka katna;red swollen bite;painful bite mark;blister from bite;allergic reaction bite
description_1: Most Indian house spider/insect bites are harmless, causing mild red bumps. Some can cause severe local swelling/pain (e.g., some centipedes/wasps).
medicine_1: Wash with soap/water. Ice pack for swelling. Antihistamine for itching. Elevate the limb if swollen.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if swelling spreads widely;bite area turns black (necrosis);or you feel generally unwell (fever/nausea).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: scratching (causes infection);traditional remedies like applying lime/metal.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Draw a circle around the redness with a pen to track if it's spreading over next few hours.
description_2: Persistent non-healing wound after a bite might need medical care.
medicine_2: Antibiotics if secondary infection occurs. Tetanus booster might be needed.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you suspect a poisonous creature (rare in cities, but possible).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: trying to suck out poison (doesn't work, increases infection risk).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Shake out shoes/clothes before wearing in areas with many insects.
description_3: Severe bites from venomous creatures (snakes/scorpions) are different EMERGENCY. This is for standard bug bites that got bad.
medicine_3: Specific anti-venom ONLY for confirmed snake/scorpion bites in hospital.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if bitten by snake/scorpion;or if trouble breathing after ANY bite (anaphylaxis).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Stay calm. AVOID: tourniquets for standard insect bites (can cause more harm).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Most 'spider bites' are actually just unidentified bug bites.

keywords: endometriosis;severe period pain;painful sex;chronic pelvic pain;infertility pain;chocolate cyst;painful poop during periods
description_1: Tissue similar to womb lining grows OUTSIDE the womb. Causes EXTREME period pain, pain during sex, and sometimes infertility.
medicine_1: Heating pads. NSAIDs (Meftal-Spas/Ibuprofen) taken BEFORE pain gets bad. It's a chronic condition needing management.
doctor_consult_1: Consult gynecologist if period pain stops you from normal life every month;or pain during sex/bowel movements.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory diet (gluten/dairy free helps some women). AVOID: inflammatory processed foods;excess caffeine/alcohol.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Yoga and pelvic floor physiotherapy can help manage chronic pain.
description_2: Persistent untreated endo can cause internal scarring (adhesions) sticking organs together.
medicine_2: Hormonal treatments (Birth control pills/progesterone) are mainstays to suppress the tissue growth.
doctor_consult_2: See specialist gynecologist. Laparoscopy is the only way to 100% confirm diagnosis.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Omega-3 fatty acids. AVOID: suffering in silence because people say 'periods are supposed to hurt' - not THIS much.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Track symptoms in detail for your doctor.
description_3: Severe cases can block fallopian tubes (infertility) or invade bowel/bladder.
medicine_3: Surgery (Laparoscopic excision) to remove tissue might be needed, especially for fertility.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have sudden severe unimaginable pelvic pain (could be ruptured cyst).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Gentle walks. AVOID: high impact exercise during painful flare-ups.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Menopause usually ends symptoms, but that's a long wait for young women.

keywords: lost voice;gala baithna;hoarse voice;husky voice;can't speak properly;sore throat no voice;whispering only
description_1: Inflammation of your voice box (larynx) usually from a cold or shouting too much. Your voice sounds raspy or disappears.
medicine_1: COMPLETE voice rest (no whispering either! it strains more). Steam inhalation. Salt water gargles.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it lasts >2 weeks (persistent hoarseness needs checking for other causes like nodules);or if you cough blood.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Warm honey-lemon water;soups. AVOID: Very hot/very cold drinks;caffeine;alcohol (dehydrates vocal cords).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use a humidifier. Do not smoke. Avoid clearing your throat forcefully (it slams vocal cords together).
description_2: Persistent hoarseness in smokers needs serious evaluation to rule out throat cancer.
medicine_2: No specific meds usually. Cough suppressants if coughing is irritating the cords.
doctor_consult_2: See ENT specialist for laryngoscopy if it doesn't resolve.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Hydrating non-acidic fluids. AVOID: spicy foods that might cause reflux (which irritates vocal cords).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Communicate via writing/texting to give cords total break.
description_3: Severe swelling can rarely block airway in children (Croup - sounds like barking cough).
medicine_3: Medical emergency in kids if breathing is noisy (stridor).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if child has difficulty breathing or makes high-pitched noise when inhaling.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Cool mist might help kids. AVOID: panicking the child (crying makes swelling worse).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Adults rarely get severe airway blockage from simple laryngitis.

keywords: hyperthyroid;wajan kam hona;weight loss sudden;shaking hands;fast heartbeat at rest;feeling hot always;bulging eyes
description_1: Thyroid gland is OVERactive. Everything speeds up: you lose weight despite eating, feel anxious, shaky, and hot.
medicine_1: Requires specific anti-thyroid drugs (Neomercazole) prescribed by endocrinologist after blood tests confirms low TSH/high T3/T4.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have racing heart rate >100bpm at rest;unexplained weight loss;or very shaky hands.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: High calorie nutritious diet (you burn energy fast). Calcium rich foods. AVOID: excessive iodine (seaweed/iodized salt supplements) unless doctor advises.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Reduce stress. Avoid caffeine (already overstimulated). Wear light clothing if feeling hot.
description_2: Persistent untreated hyperthyroidism can strain the heart and cause osteoporosis.
medicine_2: Beta-blockers (Propranolol) often given initially to control fast heart rate and shaking while waiting for main meds to work.
doctor_consult_2: See endocrinologist regularly to adjust dose. Over-treatment can make you hypothyroid!
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Broccoli/cabbage (goitrogens) might be slightly beneficial here (opposite of hypothyroid advice). AVOID: stimulants.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Use eye drops if you have bulging eyes (Graves' ophthalmopathy) to prevent dryness.
description_3: Thyroid Storm is a life-threatening flare-up with high fever, rapid irregular heart rate, and delirium.
medicine_3: Medical emergency requiring ICU care.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if you have high fever;intense agitation;or confusion.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: High energy / protein diet during active phase. AVOID: vigorous exercise until stabilized.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Radioactive iodine or surgery might be needed if tablets don't work long-term.

keywords: GERD;chronic acidity;food coming up;severe heartburn daily;sour taste in mouth morning;chest burning night;acid regurgitation
description_1: More severe than simple acidity. Stomach acid constantly flows back into food pipe, especially at night, causing damage.
medicine_1: Lifestyle changes are key. PPIs (Pantoprazole DSR) taken daily EMPTY STOMACH for a prescribed course (e.g. 4-8 weeks).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have difficulty swallowing (feels like food gets stuck);weight loss;or black stools.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Oatmeal;ginger;non-citrus fruits (melon/banana);boiled vegetables. AVOID: The 'big triggers': Tomato;raw onion;garlic;chocolate;coffee;mint;fatty fried food.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Eat dinner 3 hours before lying down. Raise the head side of your BED by 6 inches (blocks not just pillows).
description_2: Persistent untreated GERD can lead to Barrett's esophagus (pre-cancerous changes).
medicine_2: Long-term acid suppression might be needed. Antacids (Gelusil) for breakthrough symptoms only.
doctor_consult_2: See gastroenterologist for Endoscopy if symptoms persist despite meds.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Alkaline foods. AVOID: tight belts or clothes that press on stomach.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Sleep on your LEFT side (anatomy makes it harder for acid to rise). lose weight if obese.
description_3: Severe cases might need surgery (Fundoplication) to tighten the valve between stomach and food pipe.
medicine_3: Surgery is a last resort but effective.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if chest pain is severe and crushing (can mimic heart attack - get ECG to be safe).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Smaller frequent meals (5 small instead of 3 big). AVOID: alcohol and smoking completely.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Chewing sugar-free gum after meals can increase saliva and neutralize acid.

keywords: contact dermatitis;skin allergy soap;rash from jewelry;itchy red skin after touching;metal allergy;chemical rash
description_1: Skin rash caused by touching something you are allergic to (nickel in artificial jewelry, new soap, harsh detergent).
medicine_1: Identify and REMOVE the trigger immediately. Wash area with mild soap water. Calamine lotion or mild steroid cream (Hydrocortisone) for itch.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if rash is severe;blistered;on face/genitals;or spreading widely.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods. AVOID: wearing cheap artificial jewelry if you have metal allergy (stick to gold/silver/stainless steel).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Switch to fragrance-free, hypoallergenic soaps and detergents. Wear gloves when cleaning with chemicals.
description_2: Persistent rash will continue as long as the trigger is touching you. It can become thick and leathery.
medicine_2: Stronger topical steroids prescribed by dermatologist.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist for Patch Testing to find out exactly what you are allergic to.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: scratching (can cause secondary bacterial infection).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Moisturize constantly to repair skin barrier.
description_3: Severe cases can cause widespread blistering and weeping skin.
medicine_3: Oral steroids might be needed for a short course to calm massive inflammation.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if rash is near eyes or covers large part of body.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: using the suspected product 'just one more time' to test it.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Common Indian triggers: 'rol-gold' jewelry, certain bindis/sindoor, harsh detergents used for hand-washing clothes.

keywords: trigger finger;finger stuck bent;finger clicking when straightening;pain at base of finger;locking finger;thumb catch
description_1: A finger (or thumb) gets stuck in a bent position and then snaps straight with a click (like a trigger). caused by inflamed tendon.
medicine_1: Rest the hand. Splinting the finger straight at night can help. Gently massage the base of the finger.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if finger is permanently stuck bent and you cannot straighten it at all with other hand.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory diet (turmeric/omega-3). AVOID: repetitive gripping actions (using scissors/screwdriver) that aggravate it.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use tools with wider grip handles to reduce strain on tendons.
description_2: Persistent clicking can be painful and make it hard to use the hand. Common in diabetics.
medicine_2: Steroid injection directly into the tendon sheath by orthopedist is VERY effective for most people.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist if it doesn't improve with rest/splinting.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: forcing it to snap repeatedly (damages tendon more).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Soak hand in warm water before doing gentle stretching exercises.
description_3: Severe cases that don't respond to injections need minor surgery.
medicine_3: Trigger finger release surgery is a quick day-care procedure with high success rate.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None typically. Consult standard.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Good blood sugar control (if diabetic) to prevent recurrence. AVOID: ignoring early stiffness.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Often starts as just a painless clicking before becoming painful.

keywords: costochondritis;chest wall pain;pain when pressing chest;rib pain near breastbone;sharp chest pain breathing;not heart pain
description_1: Inflammation of cartilage connecting ribs to breastbone. Causes sharp chest pain, often mistaken for heart attack, but it HURTS TO TOUCH.
medicine_1: Rest. NSAID painkillers (Ibuprofen/Diclofenac) are main treatment. Heating pad on chest.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately if unsure if it's heart pain or rib pain. Always safer to get ECG if aged >35 or have risk factors.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods. AVOID: heavy lifting;push-ups;strenuous upper body activity.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Correct posture. avoid carrying heavy bags on one shoulder.
description_2: Persistent pain can last weeks or months. It is harmless but annoying.
medicine_2: Physiotherapy with ultrasound or TENS can help chronic cases.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you have fever with it, or swelling (Tietze syndrome).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: anxiety - once heart is cleared, remind yourself it's just inflammation.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Gentle chest stretching exercises once acute pain subsides.
description_3: Severe cases are rare, it's usually self-limiting.
medicine_3: Stronger anti-inflammatories might be needed.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if pain radiates to arm/jaw, or you are sweating/breathless (classic heart attack signs).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: pressing it constantly to 'check' if it still hurts (keeps it inflamed!).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It often follows a viral cough (from strain of coughing).

keywords: BV;fishy smell discharge;bad smelling vaginal discharge;thin grey discharge;vaginal odor;imbalance bacteria
description_1: Not an STD, but an imbalance of natural bacteria. Main symptom is a strong 'fishy' odor and thin greyish discharge.
medicine_1: Doesn't always need treatment if mild, but Metronidazole (antibiotic) tablets or gel is standard cure if bothersome.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you are pregnant (BV can sometimes cause early labor);or if odor is persistent.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Probiotics might help prevent recurrence. AVOID: Douching (washing inside vagina) - this is the #1 CAUSE of BV as it destroys good bacteria!
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use only plain water to wash external genitals. Avoid scented soaps/sprays.
description_2: Persistent BV can be annoying and embarrassing. It often comes back after periods or sex.
medicine_2: Doctor might prescribe longer course of probiotics or different antibiotics if it keeps recurring.
doctor_consult_2: See gynecologist to confirm it's BV and not Trichomoniasis (an STD with similar symptoms).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Yogurt with live cultures. AVOID: smoking (linked to higher risk of BV).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wear cotton underwear. Sleep without underwear.
description_3: Severe untreated BV can increase risk of catching STDs or cause Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (rarely).
medicine_3: Antibiotics are needed to prevent complications, especially before any gynecological surgery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have lower belly pain and fever with the discharge.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy diet. AVOID: unprotected sex with new partners (can upset bacterial balance).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Male partners usually don't need treatment.

keywords: rotator cuff;shoulder tear;pain lifting arm side;shoulder weakness;can't comb hair;pain sleeping on shoulder;injury shoulder
description_1: Tear or strain in muscles helping lift the arm. Common in older age or after a fall. Pain often felt deep in shoulder, worse at night.
medicine_1: R.I.C.E initially. NSAID painkillers. Avoid overhead activities but DON'T stop moving shoulder completely (prevents frozen shoulder).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you cannot lift your arm away from your body AT ALL;or severe pain after a fall.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Protein for muscle repair. AVOID: lifting heavy weights;sleeping on the painful side.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use a pillow under your arm while sitting to take weight off the shoulder.
description_2: Persistent pain and weakness means a likely tear. You might use your shoulder blade to 'hike' your arm up instead of smooth movement.
medicine_2: Physiotherapy is CRUCIAL to strengthen remaining intact muscles to compensate.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist for MRI if physio doesn't help in 6 weeks.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Collagen rich foods might help. AVOID: repetitive overhead throwing actions.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Pendulum exercises (swinging arm gently) to keep joint moving.
description_3: Severe complete tears in active young people usually need surgery. Elderly might manage with just physio.
medicine_3: Arthroscopic rotator cuff repair surgery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if sudden inability to move arm after injury.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: carrying heavy bags on that shoulder.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Recovery is slow, takes months of dedicated exercises.

keywords: tinea versicolor;white spots chest back;fungal patches skin;discolored skin patches sweat;non-itchy white spots
description_1: Fungal infection causing small discolored (often white/pink/tan) patches, usually on chest/back. More noticeable after sun exposure as they don't tan.
medicine_1: Anti-fungal shampoo (Ketoconazole) used as a body wash - leave on for 5-10 mins before rinsing, daily for a week.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it covers large part of body;or doesn't improve after 2 weeks of home treatment.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: excessive sweating/oily skin products (fungus loves oily, hot environments).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wear breathable fabrics. Shower immediately after gym/sweating.
description_2: Persistent patches might remain white even after fungus is dead (takes months for color to even out).
medicine_2: Oral antifungal pills (Fluconazole) sometimes needed for widespread cases.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist if you are unsure if it's this or vitiligo (Vitiligo is usually whiter and affects different areas).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Probiotics. AVOID: heavy oil massages on chest/back if prone to this.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wash gym clothes in hot water.
description_3: Severe cases are just cosmetically bothersome, not dangerous.
medicine_3: Recurrence is very common in Indian summers. Preventive use of Ketoconazole wash once a week can help.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None. Consult standard.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Good hygiene. AVOID: worry - it's not contagious to others.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Sun exposure makes it LOOK worse because surrounding skin gets darker, highlighting the pale infected spots.

keywords: fibromyalgia;widespread body pain;chronic fatigue pain;tender points body;fibro fog;unexplained muscle pain
description_1: Chronic condition causing widespread pain, fatigue, and 'tender points' all over body. Not dangerous but very draining.
medicine_1: Gentle aerobic exercise (walking/swimming) is THE best treatment, start very slow. Heat packs for pain.
doctor_consult_1: Consult Rheumatologist for diagnosis (it's a diagnosis of exclusion - other things must be ruled out first).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: Processed foods/excess sugar (some find it worsens pain);caffeine near bedtime.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Prioritize sleep hygiene - poor sleep is a major trigger for fibro pain. Manage stress.
description_2: Persistent 'fibro fog' (difficulty concentrating/memory issues) often accompanies the pain.
medicine_2: Medications like Duloxetine or Pregabalin can help nerve pain and sleep. Standard painkillers (Brufen) usually DON'T help much.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor for regular follow-ups and support.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Magnesium supplements might help muscle tenderness. AVOID: staying in bed all day (inactivity makes pain WORSE long-term).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) helps cope with chronic pain.
description_3: Severe days ('flares') can feel like you have a bad flu permanently.
medicine_3: Be kind to yourself during flares, rest but don't stop moving completely.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None typically. Consult if new different pain develops.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Warm baths with Epsom salts. AVOID: overdoing it on 'good days' (leads to 'crash' next day).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's a real condition, not 'just in your head', despite normal blood tests.

keywords: black eye;kali aankh;bruised eye;punched in eye;swollen purple eyelid;injury to eye orbit
description_1: Bruising around the eye after an injury. Looks alarming (turns purple/black) but often just superficial bleeding under skin.
medicine_1: Ice pack immediately (gently!) for 15 mins every hour for first day to reduce swelling.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately if you have double vision;can't move the eye;blood IN the colored part of eye (hyphema);or severe pain.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Pineapple (contains bromelain, may help bruising fade faster). AVOID: Aspirin (increases bleeding/bruising).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Sleep with head elevated to let gravity drain the swelling.
description_2: Persistent bruising changes color (purple -> green -> yellow) over 2 weeks as it heals.
medicine_2: Warm compresses AFTER 48 hours can help clear remaining bruised blood.
doctor_consult_2: See ophthalmologist if vision is even slightly blurry.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin C for capillary health. AVOID: blowing your nose if eye injury was severe (air can get trapped under skin if bone is fractured).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wear protective eye gear during contact sports.
description_3: Severe injury could mean a 'blowout fracture' of the eye socket bones.
medicine_3: Surgery might be needed if muscles are trapped in the fracture.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if pupil shape is irregular or one pupil is much larger than other after injury.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Arnica gel (applied AROUND, not IN the eye) might help bruising. AVOID: pressing on the eyeball.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: The bruising might spread to the other eye or down the cheek due to gravity - this is normal.

keywords: gastritis;pet mein sujan;severe stomach burning;acute acidity;pain after NSAIDs;alcohol stomach pain;vomiting acid
description_1: Sudden inflammation of stomach lining. Often from too much alcohol, spicy food, or painkillers (NSAIDs). intense burning/gnawing pain.
medicine_1: Stop ALL alcohol/painkillers/spicy food immediately. Antacid liquid (Digene/Mucaine gel) every 4-6 hours.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you vomit blood;have severe unmanageable pain;or black stools.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Cold milk;curd rice;bland clear soup;coconut water. AVOID: Alcohol;coffee;chillies;hot tea;citrus juice.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Hydrate with frequent small sips if vomiting. Gut rest (bland food only) for 24-48 hours.
description_2: Persistent gastritis can turn into an ulcer. You might feel full very quickly after starting to eat.
medicine_2: PPIs (Pantoprazole/Rabeprazole) might be prescribed for 1-2 weeks to let lining heal.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if it doesn't settle in 2-3 days.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Aloe vera juice (some find it soothing). AVOID: smoking (increases stomach acid).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Manage stress.
description_3: Severe erosive gastritis can cause significant stomach bleeding.
medicine_3: Requires IV PPIs and possibly endoscopy to stop bleeding.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if you feel dizzy/faint upon standing (sign of internal blood loss).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: very soft diet (khichdi). AVOID: aspirin/brufen for any reason during this time.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Don't eat within 3 hours of bedtime.

keywords: DNS;tedhi naak ki haddi;blocked nose one side;crooked nose inside;frequent sinus infection;snoring DNS;nosebleed one side
description_1: The wall between your nostrils is crooked. Common, but if severe, it blocks one side permanently causing issues.
medicine_1: Saline nasal sprays can keep it moist and reduce crusting. Nasal dilator strips might help sleep.
doctor_consult_1: Consult ENT if it causes chronic sinus infections;severe snoring;or difficulty breathing through nose.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: picking nose (DNS often makes one side dry and prone to bleeding, picking worsens it).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use a humidifier if you frequently get dry nose/bleeds on the wider side.
description_2: Persistent blockage might mean you are a 'mouth breather', leading to dry mouth and bad breath.
medicine_2: Surgery (Septoplasty) is the only way to physically straighten it.
doctor_consult_2: See ENT to discuss if surgery is worth it for your symptom severity.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: decongestant sprays for >3 days (won't fix the bone, will cause rebound).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: If you break your nose, get it set quickly to prevent severe DNS later.
description_3: Severe DNS can completely block one nostril and lead to chronic inevitable sinusitis.
medicine_3: Septoplasty is a common, effective planned surgery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None typically. Consult standard.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Good sleep hygiene. AVOID: ignoring it if it causes sleep apnea.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Many people have mild DNS without knowing it - only treat if it causes problems.

keywords: chronic fatigue;ME;always tired;unrefreshing sleep;exhaustion after minor activity;brain fog fatigue;PEM
description_1: Extreme fatigue that doesn't go away with rest and has no other medical cause. Minor activity (mental/physical) causes a 'crash' later.
medicine_1: 'Pacing' is CRITICAL: do less than you think you can. Stop BEFORE you feel tired. Rest proactively.
doctor_consult_1: Consult to rule out ALL other treatable causes of fatigue (thyroid, anemia, diabetes, sleep apnea etc.).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Balanced nutritious diet. Some find avoiding gluten/dairy helps (unproven but tried by many). AVOID: caffeine/sugar 'crashes' (using energy drinks to push through - it backfires badly).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Prioritize absolutely essential tasks only. Learn to say 'no'.
description_2: Persistent CFS can be debilitating, leaving people housebound. 'Brain fog' makes thinking hard.
medicine_2: No cure. Symptom management (for sleep/pain) helps. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) helps cope with the limitations.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor for supportive care.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Supplements ONLY if deficiencies found. AVOID: 'Graded Exercise Therapy' (pushing harder progressively) - often makes CFS worse.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Listen to your body. If you need a nap, take it.
description_3: Severe cases might need wheelchair use for energy conservation.
medicine_3: Support groups can be very helpful mentally.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if new severe symptoms develop or depression becomes severe.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration with electrolytes (sometimes helps with accompanying dizzy spells). AVOID: snake oil cures.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's a recognized biological illness, not 'laziness'.

keywords: AS;bamboo spine;stiff back morning young male;hip pain morning;spine fusing;inflammatory back pain
description_1: Type of arthritis affecting spine/hips. Usually starts in young men (<40). causes severe MORNING stiffness that improves with exercise.
medicine_1: Exercise is VITAL - stay active to prevent spine from fusing. NSAIDs (Indomethacin) are main early treatment.
doctor_consult_1: Consult rheumatologist if you have back pain >3 months that is worse in morning and better with activity (opposite of mechanical back pain).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory diet (omega-3). AVOID: smoking (accelerates spinal fusion!);high starch diet (some claim it helps to reduce, controversial).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Maintain good posture at all times. Sleep on a firm mattress with a thin pillow.
description_2: Persistent untreated AS can lead to spine vertebrae fusing together ('bamboo spine'), making it rigid.
medicine_2: Biologic drugs (TNF blockers) are revolutionary and can stop progression if started early.
doctor_consult_2: See rheumatologist regularly for monitoring.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Calcium/Vitamin D. AVOID: high impact sports if spine is already stiff (fracture risk).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Swimming is the BEST exercise for AS.
description_3: Severe cases can cause rigid hunched posture and difficulty looking up or turning head.
medicine_3: Surgery (osteotomy) rarely needed for severe deformity.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you develop severe eye redness/pain (Uveitis is a common linked condition).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy weight. AVOID: becoming sedentary - 'rest = rust' in AS.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Genetic marker HLA-B27 is often positive.

keywords: glaucoma attack;kala motiya acute;severe eye pain sudden;blurred vision rainbow halos;hard eye red;headache with eye pain
description_1: Sudden blockage of fluid drainage in eye. Causes excruciating eye pain, headache, nausea, and seeing rainbow-colored halos around lights.
medicine_1: MEDICAL EMERGENCY. RUSH TO EYE HOSPITAL NOW. Permanent blindness can happen in HOURS. No home treatment.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately. Do not wait for morning.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: NBM (nothing by mouth) in case urgent surgery/laser needed. AVOID: waiting;using OTC eye drops (some can make it WORSE).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Try to keep head upright while traveling to hospital.
description_2: Persistent high pressure kills the optic nerve irreversibly.
medicine_2: Hospital will give IV meds (Mannitol) and eye drops to lower pressure instantly. Laser iridotomy done later to prevent recurrence.
doctor_consult_2: See ophthalmologist.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet later. AVOID: activities in dark rooms if prone to this (pupil dilation can trigger attack in susceptible people).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Regular eye checks >40 years old can detect risk factors early.
description_3: Severe attack = Blindness if untreated quickly.
medicine_3: Emergency laser or surgery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if you have severe eye pain with nausea and blurred vision.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Patience during treatment; it can be painful but saves sight. AVOID: stress.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's different from common 'chronic' glaucoma which is painless and slow.

keywords: cataract;motiyabind;cloudy vision;foggy vision;glare from lights night;fading colors eye;lens opacity elderly
description_1: Natural clouding of the eye's lens with age. Vision becomes slowly foggy, like looking through a dirty window.
medicine_1: No medicines/drops can cure it. Surgery is the only fix. Use brighter lights for reading temporarily.
doctor_consult_1: Consult ophthalmologist when vision loss starts interfering with your daily life (driving/reading/cooking).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Antioxidant rich foods (lutein/zeaxanthin in leafy greens/eggs) might SLOW progression slightly. AVOID: smoking (accelerates cataract);excessive UV exposure without sunglasses.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Ensure prescription glasses are up to date (can help temporarily).
description_2: Persistent cataract will eventually make you functionally blind until removed. It is reversible blindness.
medicine_2: Cataract surgery (replacing cloudy lens with artificial one) is very safe and effective.
doctor_consult_2: See eye doctor annually to monitor maturity of cataract.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: rubbing eyes hard.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Surgery is usually done one eye at a time.
description_3: Severe 'mature' white cataracts can sometimes leak and cause painful secondary glaucoma if left too long.
medicine_3: Don't wait until it's completely white/ripe if it's bothering you earlier.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None usually, it's slow. Consult if sudden vision change occurs (not cataract).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Good diabetes control (high sugar accelerates cataracts). AVOID: fear of surgery - it's one of the most common surgeries worldwide.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Post-surgery vision is often excellent.

keywords: pilonidal sinus;tailbone cyst;pain above bum crack;pus near tailbone;hair cyst;jeep bottom;painful lump natal cleft
description_1: Cyst near the tailbone (top of buttocks crack), often containing ingrown hair. Common in hairy young men who sit a lot. very painful if infected.
medicine_1: Keep area clean and dry. Shave the area to prevent more hair entering. Warm compress if it's starting to swell.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it becomes red;hot;very painful swollen lump (abscess) - needs draining.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: prolonged sitting on hard surfaces.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use a coccyx cushion (donut cushion) to sit if painful. lose weight if obese.
description_2: Persistent sinus might keep filling with pus and draining periodically.
medicine_2: Antibiotics calm acute infection. Surgery is needed to remove the whole track permanently.
doctor_consult_2: See surgeon. It often recurs if not removed completely.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: High protein for healing if surgery done. AVOID: ignoring it - complex branching tracts can form.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Laser hair removal in that area is HIGHLY recommended to prevent recurrence.
description_3: Severe infected abscess needs immediate incision and drainage (very painful but instant relief after draining).
medicine_3: Surgery can sometimes leave a wound that takes weeks to heal.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if fever develops with the buttock pain.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Good hygiene. AVOID: embarrassment - surgeons see this everyday.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Keep the area hair-free forever ideally.

keywords: spider bite;insect bite swelling;kide ka katna;red swollen bite;painful bite mark;blister from bite;allergic reaction bite
description_1: Most Indian house spider/insect bites are harmless, causing mild red bumps. Some can cause severe local swelling/pain (e.g., some centipedes/wasps).
medicine_1: Wash with soap/water. Ice pack for swelling. Antihistamine for itching. Elevate the limb if swollen.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if swelling spreads widely;bite area turns black (necrosis);or you feel generally unwell (fever/nausea).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: scratching (causes infection);traditional remedies like applying lime/metal.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Draw a circle around the redness with a pen to track if it's spreading over next few hours.
description_2: Persistent non-healing wound after a bite might need medical care.
medicine_2: Antibiotics if secondary infection occurs. Tetanus booster might be needed.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you suspect a poisonous creature (rare in cities, but possible).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: trying to suck out poison (doesn't work, increases infection risk).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Shake out shoes/clothes before wearing in areas with many insects.
description_3: Severe bites from venomous creatures (snakes/scorpions) are different EMERGENCY. This is for standard bug bites that got bad.
medicine_3: Specific anti-venom ONLY for confirmed snake/scorpion bites in hospital.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if bitten by snake/scorpion;or if trouble breathing after ANY bite (anaphylaxis).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Stay calm. AVOID: tourniquets for standard insect bites (can cause more harm).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Most 'spider bites' are actually just unidentified bug bites.

keywords: endometriosis;severe period pain;painful sex;chronic pelvic pain;infertility pain;chocolate cyst;painful poop during periods
description_1: Tissue similar to womb lining grows OUTSIDE the womb. Causes EXTREME period pain, pain during sex, and sometimes infertility.
medicine_1: Heating pads. NSAIDs (Meftal-Spas/Ibuprofen) taken BEFORE pain gets bad. It's a chronic condition needing management.
doctor_consult_1: Consult gynecologist if period pain stops you from normal life every month;or pain during sex/bowel movements.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory diet (gluten/dairy free helps some women). AVOID: inflammatory processed foods;excess caffeine/alcohol.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Yoga and pelvic floor physiotherapy can help manage chronic pain.
description_2: Persistent untreated endo can cause internal scarring (adhesions) sticking organs together.
medicine_2: Hormonal treatments (Birth control pills/progesterone) are mainstays to suppress the tissue growth.
doctor_consult_2: See specialist gynecologist. Laparoscopy is the only way to 100% confirm diagnosis.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Omega-3 fatty acids. AVOID: suffering in silence because people say 'periods are supposed to hurt' - not THIS much.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Track symptoms in detail for your doctor.
description_3: Severe cases can block fallopian tubes (infertility) or invade bowel/bladder.
medicine_3: Surgery (Laparoscopic excision) to remove tissue might be needed, especially for fertility.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have sudden severe unimaginable pelvic pain (could be ruptured cyst).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Gentle walks. AVOID: high impact exercise during painful flare-ups.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Menopause usually ends symptoms, but that's a long wait for young women.

keywords: menopause;hot flashes;periods stopping;night sweats women 50s;mood swings menopause;vaginal dryness;weight gain 40s women
description_1: Natural end of periods, usually between age 45-55. Causes hot flashes, sleep issues, and mood changes due to dropping estrogen.
medicine_1: Lifestyle changes first. Black cohosh or soy isoflavone supplements help SOME women (ask doctor first). Calcium/Vitamin D is vital now.
doctor_consult_1: Consult gynecologist if periods are very heavy before stopping (flooding);or bleeding happens AFTER menopause (post-menopausal bleeding is a red flag).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Soy products (tofu/soya chunks - contain phytoestrogens);calcium rich foods;cool drinks. AVOID: Spicy foods;caffeine;hot drinks (triggers hot flashes).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Dress in layers so you can peel off when a flash hits. Keep room cool at night.
description_2: Persistent severe symptoms can disrupt life. Vaginal dryness can make sex painful.
medicine_2: Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) is the most effective treatment for severe symptoms (prescribed by doctor after weighing risks). Vaginal estrogen cream for dryness.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor to discuss HRT if quality of life is poor.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Flaxseeds. AVOID: alcohol (can worsen flashes and sleep).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Regular weight-bearing exercise to prevent osteoporosis which accelerates after menopause.
description_3: Severe mood disorders or severe osteoporosis might develop.
medicine_3: Antidepressants (SSRIs) sometimes used for severe hot flashes if HRT isn't suitable.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have ANY vaginal bleeding after going 12 months without a period.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet to manage midlife weight gain. AVOID: smoking (worsens bone loss and flashes).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's a natural phase, not a disease, but support helps immensely.

keywords: diaper rash;nappy rash;red bum baby;rashes on baby bottom;sore baby bum;yeast diaper rash;ammonia rash
description_1: Red, angry skin on baby's bottom from wet diapers. Very common and painful for baby.
medicine_1: Change diapers FREQUENTLY. Air time is best cure - let baby be without diaper for few hours daily. Apply thick Zinc Oxide cream (Rashfree/Siloderm/Sudocrem) with every change.
doctor_consult_1: Consult pediatrician if rash has blisters;pus;is bright beefy red with satellite spots (likely fungal yeast infection);or baby has fever.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal feeding for baby. AVOID: acidic foods if baby started solids (sometimes causes acidic poop).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use only water and cotton wool to clean if wipes are irritating. Don't rub sore skin, pat dry gently.
description_2: Persistent rash >3 days might be a fungal infection (Candida), especially if in skin folds.
medicine_2: Antifungal cream (Clotrimazole) applied before the barrier zinc cream.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if it doesn't improve with antifungal in 2 days.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Probiotics for baby if on antibiotics (causes yeast rash). AVOID: tight plastic pants over diapers.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Switch diaper brands to rule out allergy to a specific brand.
description_3: Severe eroded rash can bleed and be extremely painful.
medicine_3: Mild steroid cream (hydrocortisone 1%) might be prescribed briefly for severe inflammation (NOT for fungal).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if rash spreads beyond diaper area significantly or baby is inconsolable.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: talcum powder (can be inhaled by baby; cream is safer).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Prevention: Change poop diapers immediately.

keywords: teething;baby teething;daant nikalna;drooling baby;cranky baby gum pain;chewing on everything;mild fever teething
description_1: Baby teeth pushing through gums (usually starts 6 months). Causes drooling, irritability, and gnawing on objects.
medicine_1: Give baby something cool to chew on (chilled teether toy/clean damp cold cloth). Gently rub gums with clean finger.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if fever is >101°F;baby has diarrhea (NOT usually true teething signs - likely picked up a bug from chewing dirty things).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Chilled pureed foods if started on solids (cool apple sauce). AVOID: hard biscuits that can break off and choke.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Bibs to catch drool (prevents chin rash). Extra cuddles needed!
description_2: Persistent crying might need mild pain relief, especially at night.
medicine_2: Paracetamol drops (Crocin drops) at correct pediatric dose for weight. rare use only.
doctor_consult_2: See dentist when first tooth appears for routine checkup.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal milk feeds. AVOID: teething gels with benzocaine (unsafe for babies).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Maintain hygiene of things baby chews on.
description_3: Severe symptoms like high fever, cough, or severe diarrhea are NOT teething.
medicine_3: Treat the actual illness (it's a myth that teething causes high fever).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if baby refuses ALL feeds due to pain.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: amber teething necklaces (choking/strangulation hazard).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's a phase that passes. The first few teeth usually hurt the most.

keywords: ED;erectile dysfunction;impotence;kamjori men;performance anxiety;unable to get erection;soft erection
description_1: Difficulty getting or keeping an erection. Often due to stress, performance anxiety ('in one's head'), or early physical issues.
medicine_1: Reduce stress/performance pressure. Stop smoking and limit alcohol. Regular exercise improves blood flow.
doctor_consult_1: Consult urologist/sexologist if it happens >50% of the time;or you lose morning erections (sign of physical cause).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Heart-healthy diet (what's good for heart is good for penis). Watermelon (contains citrulline). AVOID: Heavy fatty meals before sex;excess alcohol ('whiskey dick').
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Focus on intimacy without pressure of penetration ('sensate focus' exercises).
description_2: Persistent ED can be an early warning sign of heart disease or diabetes (clogged vessels show up here first).
medicine_2: PDE5 inhibitors (Sildenafil/Viagra, Tadalafil/Cialis) PRESCRIBED by doctor. NEVER take without advice, especially if on heart meds.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor to check BP, sugar, and cholesterol.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Nuts/seeds (zinc). AVOID: illicit drugs/steroids.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Kegel exercises for men can sometimes help.
description_3: Severe ED might not respond to pills.
medicine_3: Injections or penile implants are later options for organic causes.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if an erection lasts >4 hours (Priapism) - THIS IS AN EMERGENCY.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: buying unregistered 'herbal viagra' from roadside (dangerous adulterants).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Psychotherapy is very effective if the cause is mainly anxiety.

keywords: burn;jal gaya;kitchen burn;hot water scald;red skin burn;blister from touching hot pan;first degree burn
description_1: Minor superficial burn from hot object/liquid. Skin is red, painful, but intact (no big blisters initially).
medicine_1: IMMEDIATELY run COOL (not ice cold) tap water over it for 20 MINUTES. This is the most important step to stop deep damage. Apply Silver Sulfadiazine (Burnol/Silvadene) cream after cooling.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if burn is on face/hands/genitals;larger than your palm;or causes deep white/charred skin (3rd degree).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: High protein for healing. AVOID: Applying toothpaste/ghee/ink/butter immediately (traps heat and causes infection).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Keep it clean. Don't break small blisters if they form.
description_2: Persistent pain or infection signs (increasing redness/pus) need attention.
medicine_2: Antibiotic ointment if raw area is exposed. Painkillers (Ibuprofen).
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if you haven't had a Tetanus shot in 5 years.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin C. AVOID: exposing healing burn to sun (will leave dark mark).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Cover loosely with non-stick sterile gauze if needed.
description_3: Severe deep burns (3rd degree) might not hurt because nerves are dead. They look white/leathery.
medicine_3: EMERGENCY. Needs specialist burn unit care, skin grafting.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL for any electrical burn, chemical burn, or large thermal burn.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: using cotton wool directly on raw burn (sticks painfully).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Once healed, massage with moisturizer to prevent stiff scarring.

keywords: jaw pain;TMJ;jabde mein dard;clicking jaw;jaw locking;pain chewing;grinding teeth at night;ear pain from jaw
description_1: Pain in the jaw joint (in front of ears). Often from teeth grinding (bruxism) due to stress, or arthritis.
medicine_1: Soft diet. Warm/cold packs on jaw. GENTLE jaw stretches. Stop chewing gum! Avoid opening mouth super wide (yawning).
doctor_consult_1: Consult dentist if jaw locks open or closed;or pain is severe and persistent.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Soft foods (soup/yogurt/dals). AVOID: Hard/chewy foods (nuts/tough meat/caramel).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Manage stress to stop clenching. Sleep on your back if possible to reduce jaw pressure.
description_2: Persistent TMJ can cause chronic headaches and earaches.
medicine_2: Dentist might make a 'Night Guard' (splint) to wear while sleeping to stop grinding.
doctor_consult_2: See maxillofacial specialist if standard care fails.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods. AVOID: clenching teeth during day (keep lips together, teeth apart).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Massage jaw muscles gently.
description_3: Severe cases might involve arthritis of the jaw joint.
medicine_3: Steroid injections into the joint or rarely surgery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you cannot open your mouth at all (Trismus) - could be infection.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Smoothies. AVOID: resting chin on hand for long periods.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Good posture helps - forward head posture strains jaw muscles too.

keywords: hiccups;hichki;nonstop hiccups;diaphragm spasm;cant stop hiccuping;annoying hiccups
description_1: Spasm of the diaphragm muscle. Usually lasts minutes, caused by eating too fast, carbonated drinks, or excitement.
medicine_1: Hold breath for 10-20 seconds. Drink a glass of cold water quickly. Breathe into a paper bag (increases CO2). Swallow a teaspoon of sugar.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if hiccups last >48 HOURS (persistent hiccups need investigation);or interfere severely with eating/sleep.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Plain water. AVOID: Carbonated sodas;spicy food;alcohol;very hot/cold food combinations.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Eat slowly. Don't overeat.
description_2: Persistent hiccups (>2 days) can be a sign of underlying issues like reflux, nerve irritation, or even kidney/liver problems.
medicine_2: Doctor might prescribe muscle relaxants (Baclofen) or other specific meds (Chlorpromazine) to stop the spasm.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor to rule out serious causes if they just won't stop.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Bland diet. AVOID: smoking.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Sometimes gently rubbing the back of the roof of your mouth helps.
description_3: Severe intractable hiccups can last months (very rare) and cause malnutrition/exhaustion.
medicine_3: Requires specialist neurological management.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if accompanied by severe abdominal pain or neurological symptoms.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Small frequent meals. AVOID: becoming distressed, anxiety can worsen them.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Most cases stop on their own, even if annoying for an hour.

keywords: body odor;pasine ki badbu;smelly sweat;bad smell underarms;stinky feet;BO problem
description_1: Sweat itself is odorless; bacteria on skin break it down causing smell. Worse in humid climates or with certain foods.
medicine_1: Antiperspirant (containing aluminium chloride) applied AT NIGHT works best. Antibacterial soap (Dettol/Lifebuoy) daily.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if sudden CHANGE in body odor (could be metabolic issue);or if 'fishy' smell (Trimethylaminuria - rare genetic condition).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Chlorophyll rich greens (natural deodorizer). AVOID: Strong smelling foods (garlic/onion/fenugreek/certain spices) which excrete through sweat.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wear breathable natural fabrics (cotton). Shave underarms to reduce bacterial breeding ground.
description_2: Persistent severe odor despite hygiene can be distressing socially.
medicine_2: Dermatologist can prescribe strong aluminium chloride solutions (Drysol) or topical antibiotics.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist. Botox injections in underarms can stop sweating for 6 months.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Plenty of water to dilute sweat. AVOID: synthetic tightly fitting clothes.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Change socks daily if feet smell. use antifungal powder in shoes.
description_3: Severe cases might need surgical options to remove sweat glands (rarely done now due to Botox).
medicine_3: Botox is highly effective for excessive localized sweating (Hyperhidrosis).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None. Consult standard.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: relying only on perfume to mask it - treat the cause (bacteria + sweat).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Using hand sanitizer on underarms in an emergency can kill bacteria and stop smell temporarily.

keywords: dark circles;aankhon ke niche kale ghere;tired eyes look;panda eyes;dark under eyes;puffy eyes morning
description_1: Darkening of skin under eyes. Caused by genetics, thin skin showing blood vessels, lack of sleep, allergies (rubbing), or anemia.
medicine_1: SLEEP 7-8 hours! Cold compress (chilled tea bags/cucumber slices) can temporarily reduce puffiness/darkness due to dilated vessels.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if accompanied by severe fatigue (check for anemia/thyroid);or significant swelling.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Iron rich foods (if anemic);water (dehydration makes them worse). AVOID: Excess salt (causes puffiness);alcohol.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't rub your eyes! (thickens and darkens skin over time). Wear sunglasses to prevent UV darkening.
description_2: Persistent dark circles are often genetic and hard to completely 'cure' with creams.
medicine_2: Creams with Vitamin C, Retinol, or Kojic acid might help slightly over months.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist for options like chemical peels or under-eye fillers (tear trough filler) if caused by hollows.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Vitamin K rich foods. AVOID: 'miracle' instant cures.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Elevate head while sleeping to reduce morning puffiness.
description_3: Severe cases are just cosmetic.
medicine_3: Lasers can sometimes help reduce pigmentation or visible blood vessels.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None. Consult standard.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: smoking (damages skin collagen prematurely).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Concealer makeup is the most effective immediate fix.

keywords: fainting;behoshi;chakkar khake girna;blackout;syncope;passing out;swooning;feeling lightheaded before fall
description_1: Sudden temporary loss of consciousness due to drop in blood flow to brain. Common triggers: standing too long, sight of blood, extreme pain/heat.
medicine_1: If you feel faint: LIE DOWN immediately and raise legs. NOT sit (lying is better to get blood to brain).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you fainted during exercise (DANGEROUS sign);fainted without warning triggers;or injured yourself falling.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Salty snack and water AFTER recovering fully. AVOID: Standing up quickly;dehydration;crowded hot places.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Learn your triggers and avoid them. Tense leg/arm muscles if you feel it coming on to pump blood back up.
description_2: Persistent frequent fainting needs cardiac evaluation to rule out heart rhythm issues.
medicine_2: Usually no meds needed. increasing salt/water intake sometimes advised by doctor for low BP prone people.
doctor_consult_2: See cardiologist if you are older or have heart history. Tilt Table Test might be done.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Adequate electrolytes. AVOID: skipping meals.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wear compression stockings if you faint from standing long periods.
description_3: Severe fainting from heart conditions (cardiac syncope) can be fatal if not treated.
medicine_3: Pacemaker might be needed for certain slow heart rate conditions.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if person doesn't wake up within 1 minute;or has chest pain before fainting.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Fluids. AVOID: driving until cleared by doctor if you have unexplained fainting spells.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Vasovagal fainting is harmless but falling down can cause injury.

keywords: cramps;nas chadna;leg cramp night;charley horse;painful muscle spasm leg;calf pain sudden;muscle catch night
description_1: Sudden, involuntary, intense pain from muscle locking up, often in calf at night.
medicine_1: Stretch the cramped muscle IMMEDIATELY (pull toes towards your knee for calf cramp). Massage firmly. Walk around on it.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if cramps are severe and happen every night;or don't release after stretching.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Bananas (potassium/magnesium);plenty of water. AVOID: dehydration (major cause).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Stretch calves before bed. mild exercise can help.
description_2: Persistent cramps can be from electrolyte imbalance, medications (statins/diuretics), or poor circulation.
medicine_2: Magnesium or Vitamin B12 supplements sometimes help if deficient. Quinine is rarely used now due to side effects.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor to check medication side effects if it started after new pills.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Electrolyte drinks (coconut water) if sweating a lot. AVOID: heavy blankets pressing toes down (can trigger cramps).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Keep legs warm at night.
description_3: Severe unremitting cramps could rarely be a sign of clot (DVT) if accompanied by swelling/redness.
medicine_3: DVT needs urgent medical attention (see DVT row).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if cramp leaves severe lingering pain and swelling in ONE leg.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: standing on concrete floors all day without good shoes.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Tonic water (contains tiny amount of quinine) helps some people, though unproven medically.

keywords: sebaceous cyst;epidermoid cyst;gathaan under skin;painless lump skin;lump with black dot;cheesy smelling discharge lump
description_1: A closed sac under skin filled with cheese-like oily material (keratin). Usually painless, slow-growing, has a small central dark pore.
medicine_1: Do NOT squeeze it (can cause internal rupture and severe inflammation). Leave it alone if painless.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it becomes red;hot;painful;or grows rapidly (signs of infection/rupture).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: trying to perform 'bathroom surgery' to drain it.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Keep area clean.
description_2: Persistent cysts can get infected repeatedly.
medicine_2: Antibiotics needed if it gets infected (becomes an abscess).
doctor_consult_2: See surgeon for removal if it bothers you cosmetically or keeps getting infected.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Healthy lifestyle. AVOID: applying irritants to try and 'dissolve' it.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: It might smell bad if some white material comes out.
description_3: Severe infected cyst can form a large painful abscess requiring drainage.
medicine_3: Incision and drainage under local anesthesia, followed by later surgery to remove the sac wall (to prevent recurrence).
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have fever with a large painful red cyst.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Patience. AVOID: believing it will just 'disappear' - the sac remains unless surgically removed.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Very common on back, neck, and face.

keywords: lipoma;charbi ki ganth;fatty lump;soft moveable lump under skin;doughy lump painless;benign tumor fat
description_1: Soft, rubbery bulge under skin made of fat cells. It slips away when you press it ('slippage sign'). Harmless.
medicine_1: No treatment needed. It is benign (non-cancerous). harmless.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if it grows fast;becomes hard;feels stuck to underlying tissue;or becomes painful.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. (No diet dissolves lipomas). AVOID: aggressive massage which might irritate it.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Ignore it if it's not bothering you.
description_2: Persistent lipomas might slowly grow over years. Some people have many (genetic).
medicine_2: Surgery is the only way to remove it.
doctor_consult_2: See surgeon if you want it removed for cosmetic reasons or if it presses on a nerve.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Healthy weight (though losing weight won't make lipomas disappear, they might shrink slightly). AVOID: worry - they extremely rarely turn cancerous.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: They are most common on shoulders, back, arms.
description_3: Severe: Extremely large lipomas (>10cm) might need removal just due to size/weight.
medicine_3: Surgical excision.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None. Consult standard if changing.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Normal lifestyle. AVOID: confusing it with other harder lumps - get checked once to be sure.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: If you have hundreds of them, it might be a genetic condition (Lipomatosis).

keywords: hypothermia;thand lagna severe;low body temperature;shivering uncontrollable;cold confusion;exposure to cold
description_1: Body temperature drops below 35°C (95°F) due to prolonged cold exposure. Mild stage involves intense shivering.
medicine_1: GET INDOORS. Remove wet clothes. Warm SLOWLY with blankets and warm sweet drinks. Do NOT use direct extreme heat (hot water bath) immediately.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if shivering STOPS but person is still cold (dangerous sign of moderate-severe hypothermia);or confusion occurs.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Warm sweet tea/coffee/soup. AVOID: Alcohol (makes you FEEL warm but actually lose more heat);cigarettes.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wear hat and dry layers. Huddle with others for body heat if stuck outside.
description_2: Persistent hypothermia (Moderate/Severe) causes confusion, clumsiness, and shivering STOPS. Life threatening.
medicine_2: Needs hospital rewarming with IV fluids.
doctor_consult_2: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if person is confused, drowsy, or unconscious after cold exposure.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: High energy foods. AVOID: rubbing frostbitten areas if present.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Cover head and neck (major heat loss areas).
description_3: Severe Hypothermia can lead to cardiac arrest.
medicine_3: Requires specialized internal rewarming techniques in ICU.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: CALL AMBULANCE. Handle gently (rough handling can trigger heart arrest in severe hypothermia).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Warm fluids only if fully conscious. AVOID: assuming they are dead if cold/no pulse - 'not dead until warm and dead'.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Elderly and babies are at much higher risk even in moderately cool houses.

keywords: traveler's diarrhea;Delhi belly;turista;loose motion on holiday;stomach upset travel;contaminated water travel
description_1: Diarrhea affecting travelers, usually from bacteria (E.coli) in local water/food. Ruins holidays!
medicine_1: Hydration (ORS/bottled water) is #1. Loperamide (Imodium) can be used for long bus/plane rides but better to let it out if possible.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if diarrhea is bloody;you have high fever;or it lasts >3 days.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Safe bottled/boiled water ONLY. BRAT diet. AVOID: Street food;raw salads;cut fruits;ice cubes in drinks (often made from tap water).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: 'Boil it, cook it, peel it, or forget it'. Wash hands frequently with sanitizer.
description_2: Persistent severe cases might need antibiotics to save the trip.
medicine_2: Azithromycin or Ciprofloxacin are often carried by travelers as standby emergency treatment (take only if severe).
doctor_consult_2: See doctor before travel for a medical kit if going to remote areas.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Salty crackers. AVOID: dairy until recovered.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Probiotics started before trip might help prevention slightly.
description_3: Severe dehydration is the main risk.
medicine_3: IV fluids if unable to keep oral fluids down.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if dizzy, confused, or not passing urine.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Electrolytes. AVOID: brushing teeth with tap water in high-risk areas.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Usually resolves in 3-5 days on its own.

keywords: premature graying;samay se pehle safed baal;white hair young age;grey hair early;canities
description_1: Hair turning gray/white before age 25-30. Strongly genetic, but stress/deficiencies can accelerate it.
medicine_1: No cure if genetic. Cover with safe hair colors (henna/ammonia-free dyes) if desired. Manage stress.
doctor_consult_1: Consult to rule out deficiencies (B12/Iron/Thyroid/Copper) which might be reversible causes.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Curry leaves (kadi patta);Amla (gooseberry);B12 rich foods;Iron;Copper rich foods (mushrooms/seeds). AVOID: Smoking (proven to accelerate graying significantly!).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Protect hair from harsh sun (UV can bleach hair).
description_2: Persistent graying is usually progressive.
medicine_2: Supplements (Calcium Pantothenate/PABA) sometimes prescribed but results are poor if it's genetic.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist if it's very sudden.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Antioxidant rich diet. AVOID: plucking gray hairs (myth that more grow, but it damages the follicle).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Acceptance is the easiest long-term solution!
description_3: Severe: None, strictly cosmetic.
medicine_3: None.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None. Consult standard.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced lifestyle. AVOID: 'miracle' oils that claim to reverse graying - they don't work.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Sudden white patch of hair can sometimes be Vitiligo or Alopecia Areata recovering.

keywords: mono;glandular fever;kissing disease;extreme fatigue teen;swollen neck glands severe;sore throat weeks;EBV
description_1: Viral infection (Epstein-Barr Virus) common in teens/young adults. Causes severe sore throat, huge swollen glands, and EXTREME fatigue for weeks.
medicine_1: Rest, rest, rest. Paracetamol for fever/throat. Salt water gargles. It's viral, so no antibiotics.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if throat is so swollen you can't swallow;or you develop severe abdominal pain (spleen risk).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Soft cool foods;milkshakes;soups. AVOID: Alcohol (liver is often affected);contact sports (risk of ruptured spleen).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Do not share cups/cutlery/kisses (spreads via saliva).
description_2: Persistent fatigue can last for months after initial recovery ('post-viral fatigue').
medicine_2: Steroids (Prednisolone) rarely used only if throat swelling threatens breathing.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor for blood test (Mono spot test) to confirm.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Nutritious fluids. AVOID: rushing back to school/college - you will crash.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Spleen can become enlarged - be very careful with abdomen.
description_3: Severe complication is Ruptured Spleen (rare but life threatening).
medicine_3: Emergency surgery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if sudden severe pain in upper left abdomen.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Patience. AVOID: heavy lifting for at least one month.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Most people get infected as kids with mild symptoms, but teens get hit hard.

keywords: bad posture;hunchback;kubda;rounded shoulders;slouching pain;text neck;computer hunch
description_1: Rounding of upper back due to chronic slouching at desks/phones. Causes neck/back pain and 'hump' appearance.
medicine_1: Conscious effort to sit straight! 'Chest up, shoulders back'. Ergonomic chair. frequent stretch breaks.
doctor_consult_1: Consult orthopedist if the curve is rigid (you can't straighten up even if you try);or if accompanied by severe pain.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Calcium/Vitamin D for bone strength. AVOID: sitting for >30 mins without moving.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Exercises: Wall angels, doorway chest stretches, upper back strengthening (rows).
description_2: Persistent bad posture can lead to permanent structural changes in spine (Dowager's hump in elderly).
medicine_2: Physiotherapy is main treatment for postural correction. Braces sometimes used but active muscle strengthening is better.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor if it develops rapidly in elderly (could be osteoporosis fractures).
