food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Healthy weight. AVOID: looking down at phone for hours (bring phone to eye level).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Yoga is excellent for posture.
description_3: Severe fixed Kyphosis (Scheuermann's disease in kids, or from osteoporosis fractures) might need more aggression intervention.
medicine_3: Surgery only for extreme deformity affecting breathing.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if accompanied by numbness in arms/legs.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: super soft sofas that encourage slouching.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It takes months of consistent habit-changing to fix years of bad posture.

keywords: bunion;big toe bump;tedha angootha;painful joint big toe;toe pointing inward;bump on side of foot
description_1: Bony bump forming at the base of big toe. The big toe points inward towards other toes. Often from tight pointed shoes or genetics.
medicine_1: Switch to WIDE toe-box shoes immediately. Toe spacers/separators can help pain. Ice if inflamed.
doctor_consult_1: Consult orthopedist if pain makes walking difficult even in good shoes.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory diet. AVOID: High heels;pointed narrow shoes (worst culprits!).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use bunion pads to prevent rubbing against shoes.
description_2: Persistent bunions get slowly bigger. The second toe might get pushed up (hammer toe).
medicine_2: Surgery is the only way to remove the bump.
doctor_consult_2: See surgeon if conservative measures fail.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: ignoring it until it crosses over other toes.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Walking barefoot on sand can help strengthen foot muscles.
description_3: Severe bunions can cause severe deformity making standard shoes impossible to wear.
medicine_3: Bunionectomy surgery (cutting bone to realign toe). Long recovery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if the bump becomes red, hot, and very painful suddenly (could be bursitis or gout flare-up on top of bunion).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy weight to reduce foot pressure. AVOID: surgery purely for cosmetic reasons if it's painless.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's much more common in women due to footwear choices.

keywords: OCD;obsessive thoughts;compulsive checking;repeating tasks;intrusive thoughts;fear of germs excessive;need for symmetry
description_1: Anxiety disorder with unwanted repetitive thoughts (obsessions) driving repetitive behaviors (compulsions) to get relief.
medicine_1: Recognize it's OCD, not you. Delay the compulsion ('I will check the lock in 5 mins, not now').
doctor_consult_1: Consult psychiatrist/psychologist if it takes up >1 hour of your day or causes significant distress.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: caffeine/stimulants (can increase anxiety and racing thoughts).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Stress management. Mindfulness meditation helps detach from intrusive thoughts.
description_2: Persistent OCD can become severely disabling, preventing work or leaving house.
medicine_2: SSRI medications (higher doses than for depression) and specific therapy (ERP - Exposure and Response Prevention) are highly effective.
doctor_consult_2: See specialist.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Regular sleep. AVOID: alcohol as self-medication.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Join support groups.
description_3: Severe OCD can be completely totally incapacitating.
medicine_3: Intensive residential therapy or sometimes advanced brain stimulation techniques.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you have thoughts of harming yourself or others (intrusive thoughts are usually just fears, but good to get checked).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Routine. AVOID: giving in to every compulsion immediately - it feeds the OCD monster.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's often secretive due to shame, but highly treatable.

keywords: fungal nail;nakhun fungus;yellow thick nail;brittle nails;nail separating from bed;toenail fungus;discolored nail
description_1: Fungal infection making nails (usually toes) thickened, yellow, and brittle. It's slow-growing and painless initially.
medicine_1: Topical antifungal nail lacquers (Amorolfine) applied weekly work ONLY for mild surface cases. Vicks VapoRub helps some people (anecdotal).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if nail is becoming very thick/painful;or if you have diabetes (high risk of secondary infection).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: wearing closed damp shoes all day.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Keep feet bone dry. Wear open sandals to air them out. Trim nails carefully (don't share clippers).
description_2: Persistent infection deep in the nail bed won't clear with just creams/lacquers.
medicine_2: Oral antifungal pills (Terbinafine/Itraconazole) prescribed by dermatologist for 3-6 MONTHS are needed for cure.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist. Liver function tests needed before long-term oral antifungals.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Good hygiene. AVOID: walking barefoot in public gyms/pools.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Change socks twice daily if sweaty.
description_3: Severe neglected cases can cause painful ingrown nails or secondary bacterial cellulitis.
medicine_3: Sometimes permanent nail removal surgery is required.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if spreading redness appears on the toe skin around the nail.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Patience - toenails take 12 months to grow out completely. AVOID: nail polish (traps fungus).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Disinfect old shoes or throw them away to prevent reinfection.

keywords: cracked heels;phati ediyan;fissures feet;bleeding heels;painful cracks foot;dry rough feet winter
description_1: Thick dry skin on heels that cracks, often painful and bleeding. Worse in Indian winters or walking barefoot.
medicine_1: Soak feet in warm water 10 mins. Scrub gently with pumice stone. Apply THICK urea-based cream (Krack cream/Vaseline) and wear socks overnight.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if cracks are deep;bleeding;infected (pus);or you have diabetes (risk of non-healing foot ulcers).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Hydrating fluids;Omega-3 rich foods. AVOID: Walking barefoot on rough/hot surfaces.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't cut the hard skin with blades! (Infection risk). Moisturize EVERY night without fail.
description_2: Persistent deep fissures can be extremely painful to walk on and might get infected.
medicine_2: Antibiotic ointment if cracks are raw/bleeding. Salicylic acid ointment helps peel off thick dead skin.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist if standard creams don't help.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Zinc might help skin repair. AVOID: harsh soaps on feet.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wear cushioned footwear indoors.
description_3: Severe infected cracks in diabetics can lead to amputation if neglected.
medicine_3: Requires professional podiatry care and strict sugar control.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if foot becomes red, hot, and swollen.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: ignoring them until they bleed.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Consistency with moisturizing is the only long-term cure.

keywords: bedwetting;bistar gila karna;nocturnal enuresis;peeing in sleep child;wet bed morning;bladder control sleep
description_1: Child >5 years old still wetting the bed at night. often deep sleepers or slow bladder development. Not laziness!
medicine_1: Do NOT punish the child. Limit fluids 2 hours before bed. Make sure they pee IMMEDIATELY before sleep.
doctor_consult_1: Consult pediatrician if child was dry for months and SUDDENLY starts wetting again (could be UTI/Diabetes/stress);or if >7 years old.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: Caffeine/sugary drinks in evening (they increase urine output).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use a waterproof mattress protector. Involve child in changing sheets calmly (not as punishment, just responsibility).
description_2: Persistent bedwetting can cause low self-esteem.
medicine_2: Bedwetting alarms (ring when first drop hits) are very effective for training the brain. Desmopressin tablets sometimes used for sleepovers.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor to rule out constipation (a full bowel presses on bladder causing leaks).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Fiber to prevent constipation. AVOID: teasing the child.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: 'Lifting' (waking child once at midnight to pee) helps keep bed dry but doesn't 'cure' the problem.
description_3: Severe cases rarely might indicate spinal or anatomical issues.
medicine_3: Specialist urology assessment needed.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None typically. Consult if accompanied by daytime wetting or pain.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Patience. AVOID: shaming - it's usually developmental and they outgrow it.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Most kids outgrow it by puberty without any treatment.

keywords: mastitis;stan mein sujan;breast pain breastfeeding;red hard lump breast;fever nursing mother;blocked milk duct infection
description_1: Painful infection of breast tissue, common in breastfeeding mothers. Breast becomes red, hot, swollen, and you feel flu-like fever.
medicine_1: Keep breastfeeding from the affected side! (It hurts but essential to drain it). Warm compresses before feed, cold after.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if fever >101°F;or if it doesn't improve after 24hrs of intensive feeding/pumping.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Plenty of fluids;rest. AVOID: stopping feeding (will cause abscess);tight bras.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Massage the lump gently TOWARDS the nipple while baby is feeding.
description_2: Persistent mastitis can turn into a breast abscess (pus collection).
medicine_2: Antibiotics (safe for breastfeeding) are often needed if fever is present. Paracetamol/Ibuprofen for pain.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor immediately if you feel a distinct painful moveable lump (abscess).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Nutritious diet to keep immunity up. AVOID: ignoring cracked nipples (bacteria enter here).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Vary feeding positions to drain all areas of breast.
description_3: Severe Abscess needs draining with a needle or small cut.
medicine_3: Surgical drainage. Breastfeeding might need to pause briefly on THAT side only if incision is near nipple.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if area turns black or you feel very ill suddenly (sepsis risk).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Rest. AVOID: weaning abruptly during mastitis.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Lanolin cream for cracked nipples helps prevention.

keywords: DVT;leg blood clot;pair mein clot;swollen one leg;painful calf swelling;red warm leg;post-flight leg pain
description_1: Blood clot in a deep vein, usually in the leg. Causes swelling, warmth, and pain in ONE leg only. Risk after long flights/surgery.
medicine_1: MEDICAL EMERGENCY. Do NOT walk around or massage the leg (clot can break loose and go to lungs).
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately. Rush to hospital for Ultrasound Doppler scan.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: immobility during long travel in future.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Elevate the leg slightly while waiting for medical help.
description_2: Persistent/Untreated DVT can lead to Pulmonary Embolism (clot in lungs) - highly fatal.
medicine_2: Blood thinners (Anticoagulants like Heparin/Warfarin) started immediately in hospital.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor. D-Dimer blood test can help rule it out.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet (watch Vitamin K if on Warfarin later). AVOID: sitting for >4 hours without moving.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Wear compression stockings if you have DVT history.
description_3: Severe DVT can cause permanent leg swelling and ulcers (Post-thrombotic syndrome).
medicine_3: Long-term blood thinners needed.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if you have leg swelling AND sudden shortness of breath/chest pain (Pulmonary Embolism).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: NBM if heading to hospital. AVOID: ignoring one-sided leg swelling ever.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Early treatment prevents death from PE.

keywords: PMS;periods se pehle mood swings;bloating before period;irritability PMS;crying spells before period;breast tenderness cycle
description_1: Physical and emotional symptoms starting 1-2 weeks BEFORE period and ending when bleeding starts.
medicine_1: Exercise helps mood. Reduce salt (to stop bloating). Heating pad for backache.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if mood changes are extreme (severe depression/rage) - might be PMDD (severe form).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Complex carbs;calcium rich foods;small frequent meals. AVOID: excess Salt;Sugar;Caffeine;Alcohol during PMS week.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Sleep enough. Track cycle to know when it's coming so you can prepare mentally.
description_2: Persistent severe PMS (PMDD) can ruin relationships and work life every month.
medicine_2: SSRIs (antidepressants) sometimes prescribed just for the 2 weeks before period for severe mood issues.
doctor_consult_2: See gynecologist to discuss contraceptive pills which can sometimes level out hormones.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Magnesium/Vitamin B6 supplements might help. AVOID: stressful events during pre-period week if possible.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Yoga/meditation can reduce severity.
description_3: Severe PMDD might lead to suicidal thoughts before every period.
medicine_3: Requires psychiatric and gynecological combined care.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you feel unsafe due to your mood swings.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Comfort foods in moderation. AVOID: blaming yourself - it's biological.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Keeping a symptom diary helps confirm diagnosis.

keywords: OSMF;munh nahi khulta;cannot open mouth gutka;restricted mouth opening;burning mouth spicy food;white bands in mouth
description_1: Mouth becomes stiff and cannot open fully. Almost exclusively caused by chewing Gutka/Paan Masala/Areca nut.
medicine_1: STOP CHEWING GUTKA IMMEDIATELY. This is the only way to stop progression. Antioxidant supplements (Lycopene) help.
doctor_consult_1: Consult dentist/ENT if you can't open mouth more than 2-3 fingers width;or have burning sensation with normal food.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Soft non-spicy diet. AVOID: ALL forms of tobacco/areca nut/supari completely forever.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Jaw opening exercises (using ice cream sticks to gradually increase width) daily.
description_2: Persistent OSMF is a pre-cancerous condition. The fibrosis (scarring) doesn't easily reverse.
medicine_2: Steroid injections into the stiff bands in mouth can help improve opening slightly.
doctor_consult_2: See specialist for biopsy if any suspicious red/white patches appear (high cancer risk).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Green leafy vegetables. AVOID: ignoring burning sensation - it's the first sign.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Regular oral cancer screenings are vital.
description_3: Severe OSMF can lead to mouth opening <1 finger width and high risk of oral cancer.
medicine_3: Surgery to cut fibrous bands might be needed in extreme cases.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if you find a non-healing ulcer or lump in mouth.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Cool soothing foods. AVOID: alcohol (multiplies cancer risk with gutka).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It is 100% preventable by not chewing these products.

keywords: heat stroke;loo lagna severe;no sweating in heat;high body temp >104;confusion heat;fainting in sun hot skin
description_1: Life-threatening emergency where body can no longer cool itself. Temp >104°F, skin is HOT and DRY (no sweating), confusion/unconsciousness occurs.
medicine_1: COOL THE PERSON IMMEDIATELY while waiting for ambulance. Ice packs on neck, armpits, groin. Spray with cool water and fan them.
doctor_consult_1: MEDICAL EMERGENCY. CALL AMBULANCE. Do not try to treat at home with just drinks.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: DO NOT give oral fluids if person is confused or unconscious (choking risk). IV fluids needed. AVOID: giving fever meds like Paracetamol (doesn't work for environmental heat stroke and can harm liver).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Move to shade/AC immediately. Remove excess clothing.
description_2: Persistent high temp cooks the brain and internal organs leading to multi-organ failure.
medicine_2: Hospital treatment involves rapid active cooling (ice baths) and intensive care support.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor instantly.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: IV Electrolytes in hospital. AVOID: delay - every minute above 104°F causes brain damage.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Prevention: NEVER leave anyone (especially kids) in a parked car in India.
description_3: Severe Heat Stroke has high mortality rate if not cooled in under 30 minutes.
medicine_3: Permanent brain/kidney damage possible in survivors.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if someone in heat becomes confused, stops sweating, or has a seizure.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Cool environment during recovery. AVOID: heat exposure for weeks after recovery.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: It's different from heat exhaustion (where you still sweat). Dry hot skin = Danger.

keywords: bed sores;decubitus ulcer;ghao from lying down;pressure sore;red skin over bone;elderly bedridden wounds
description_1: Wounds caused by constant pressure on skin, usually in bedridden/wheelchair patients. Common on tailbone, heels, hips.
medicine_1: PREVENTION is key: Turn patient every 2 hours. Use air/water mattress. Keep skin clean and dry.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately if skin turns black (gangrene) or sore gets deeper/smells bad.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: High protein diet (essential for wound healing). Vitamin C/Zinc supplements. AVOID: letting patient lie in wet diapers/sheets.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use pillows to cushion bony areas. Do not massage red areas (can damage tissue more).
description_2: Persistent sores can get deep, reaching muscle or bone. Very hard to heal.
medicine_2: Specialized dressings (hydrocolloid/alginate) and debridement (cleaning dead tissue) by nurse/doctor.
doctor_consult_2: See surgeon if sore is deep (Stage 3 or 4).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Hydration. AVOID: dragging patient across bed (friction causes sores) - LIFT them.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Inspect skin daily for early redness.
description_3: Severe infected bed sores can cause life-threatening sepsis.
medicine_3: Might need plastic surgery (flap graft) to close large non-healing sores.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if fever develops or foul smell comes from sore.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Nutritional supplements. AVOID: thinking they are inevitable - most are preventable with good care.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Once formed, they take months to heal.

keywords: sepsis;blood poisoning;severe infection reaction;confusion fever fast heart;shivering extreme;mottled skin
description_1: Life-threatening reaction to an infection. Immune system attacks own body. IT IS A MEDICAL EMERGENCY.
medicine_1: TIME IS LIFE. Go to hospital immediately if you have an infection AND feel 'worse than ever before'.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately. Sepsis kills in hours.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Nothing by mouth if heading to ER. AVOID: waiting to see if it gets better 'tomorrow'.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Know the signs: S-Shivering, E-Extreme pain, P-Pale/discolored skin, S-Sleepy/confused, I-'I feel like I might die', S-Short of breath.
description_2: Persistent untreated sepsis leads to Septic Shock (BP drops dangerously low). Organs start failing.
medicine_2: IV Antibiotics and IV fluids must be started within ONE HOUR of arriving at hospital.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor. don't be afraid to ask 'Could this be sepsis?'
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Hospital care. AVOID: ignoring infection signs in elderly/diabetics/babies.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Early recognition saves lives.
description_3: Severe Septic Shock has a very high death rate even with ICU care.
medicine_3: Requires ventilator and drugs to keep heart going.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL for confusion, severe breathlessness, or unresponsiveness during any illness.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: intensive care. AVOID: self-medication with leftover antibiotics.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Vaccines (pneumonia/flu) can prevent infections that lead to sepsis.

keywords: chapped lips;phate honth;cracked lips;peeling lips bleeding;dry lips winter;cheilitis
description_1: Dry, cracked, peeling lips. Common in winter, or from dehydration, or lip licking habit.
medicine_1: Stop licking your lips! (Saliva dries them out more). Apply plain petroleum jelly (Vaseline) or thick fragrance-free balm every hour.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if corners of mouth are cracked and won't heal (Angular Cheilitis - often fungal/vitamin def);or if persistent solitary ulcer.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Water! (Dehydration #1 cause). Vitamin B rich foods. AVOID: Matte lipsticks;spicy/salty foods that sting;picking dead skin.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Use a humidifier at night. Cover face with scarf in cold wind.
description_2: Persistent cracking at corners (Angular Cheilitis) might need medication.
medicine_2: Antifungal or antibiotic cream prescribed by doctor for infected corner cracks.
doctor_consult_2: See dermatologist if lips are constantly peeling despite care (could be allergy to toothpaste or actinic cheilitis).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Riboflavin (B2) supplements might help corner cracks. AVOID: flavored lip balms (encourage licking).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Gentle exfoliation with wet washcloth once a week only if healed.
description_3: Severe: Actinic Cheilitis is pre-cancerous sun damage (persistent white/scaly patches on lower lip).
medicine_3: Needs dermatological treatment to prevent lip cancer.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: None. Consult if non-healing sore >2 weeks.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Healthy fats in diet. AVOID: breathing through mouth (dries lips).
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Don't peel the flakes, it causes bleeding and slower healing.

keywords: phimosis;tight foreskin;cannot retract foreskin;painful erection foreskin;ballooning foreskin pee;skin stuck penis
description_1: Foreskin cannot be pulled back (retracted) over the head of the penis. Normal in babies, should loosen by puberty. problem if painful/causing infection in adults.
medicine_1: Gentle daily stretching in warm bath (NEVER force it - causes scarring). Steroid creams can help loosen it.
doctor_consult_1: Consult urologist if it causes ballooning when peeing;repeated infections (balanitis);or painful erections.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: forceful retraction in babies (can cause paraphimosis - getting stuck).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Maintain good hygiene by washing gently under whatever skin CAN be retracted.
description_2: Persistent phimosis in adults can interfere with sex and increase risk of penile cancer if hygiene is poor.
medicine_2: Topical steroid ointments (Betamethasone) applied for 4-6 weeks can often cure it without surgery.
doctor_consult_2: See urologist. Circumcision is the surgical cure if conservative options fail.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Good hygiene is key. AVOID: ignoring white patches/hardening of foreskin (Lichen Sclerosus).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Diabetics are more prone to acquired phimosis due to repeated infections.
description_3: Severe Paraphimosis: Foreskin gets stuck RETRACTED and won't come forward, strangling the penis tip.
medicine_3: MEDICAL EMERGENCY. Needs immediate manual reduction or emergency slit surgery.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if foreskin is stuck pulled BACK and penis tip is turning blue/swollen.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Calmness. AVOID: waiting if paraphimosis occurs.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Circumcision is very standard and effective if needed.

keywords: reactive arthritis;Reiter's syndrome;joint pain after infection;eye red and joint pain;painful pee and joints;swollen knees after diarrhea
description_1: Joint pain and swelling triggered by an infection elsewhere in body (usually gut diarrhea or urinary STD) 1-4 weeks prior.
medicine_1: Rest joints. NSAIDs (Naproxen/Indomethacin) for pain. Treat the original infection if still present.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if joint pain is severe;or accompanied by eye redness (conjunctivitis) and burning urine (classic triad of symptoms).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Anti-inflammatory foods. AVOID: unprotected sex (if STD was the trigger, prevents reinfection).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Ice packs on swollen joints.
description_2: Persistent symptoms can last 3-12 months. It usually resolves eventually.
medicine_2: Stronger meds (Sulfasalazine/Steroids) might be needed if NSAIDs don't work.
doctor_consult_2: See rheumatologist if it doesn't clear up in a few months.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Normal diet. AVOID: high impact activity while joints are inflamed.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Physical therapy to maintain joint range of motion.
description_3: Severe chronic cases can mimic ankylosing spondylitis and cause permanent joint damage.
medicine_3: Biologic drugs might be used in rare chronic cases.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if eye is very painful and sensitive to light (Uveitis).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Patience, it takes time to settle. AVOID: anxiety - it is usually not permanent arthritis.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Common triggers: Salmonella food poisoning, Chlamydia infection.

keywords: color blindness;color deficiency;cannot distinguish red green;daltonism;genetic eye problem;failed color test
description_1: Inability to distinguish certain colors (usually red/green). It's usually genetic, present from birth, and affects mostly males.
medicine_1: No cure. It's a lifelong condition. Use accessibility settings on phones/computers.
doctor_consult_1: Consult eye doctor for standard Ishihara chart test to confirm type and severity, especially for career planning.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Normal diet (Vitamin A won't fix genetic color blindness). AVOID: careers requiring perfect color vision (pilot/electrician/some police roles) - check requirements early.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Teach color-blind kids coping strategies (labeling colored pencils, memorizing traffic light positions).
description_2: Persistent: It doesn't get worse with age.
medicine_2: Special tinted glasses (EnChroma) might help SOME people distinguish colors better, but don't 'fix' the eyes.
doctor_consult_2: See ophthalmologist if color vision changes SUDDENLY later in life (could be eye disease or brain issue).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Adaptation strategies. AVOID: thinking it's 'blindness' - they see clearly, just different hues.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Inform teachers if child has it (to avoid confusion with color-coded learning materials).
description_3: Severe total color blindness (Achromatopsia) is rare and causes poor vision and extreme light sensitivity.
medicine_3: Needs low-vision aids and dark glasses.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if sudden loss of color vision occurs.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Normal life otherwise. AVOID: undiagnosed struggles in school.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Apps exist to help identify colors using phone camera.

keywords: nightmares;night terrors;bad dreams;screaming in sleep child;sleep dread;waking up scared sweating;parasomnia
description_1: Nightmares: Scary dreams you REMEMBER, wake you up fully. Night Terrors: Child screams/thrashes while seemingly awake but is ASLEEP, DOESN'T remember it next day.
medicine_1: Nightmares: Comfort child. Night Terrors: Do NOT try to wake them up (makes it worse/confuses them). Just ensure they are safe and wait it out (lasts 5-15 mins).
doctor_consult_1: Consult if they happen almost every night;cause injury;or adult onset night terrors (might need investigation).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Relaxing bedtime routine. AVOID: scary movies/screens before bed;over-tiredness (major trigger for night terrors).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Keep regular sleep schedule. Ensure bedroom is safe if they thrash around.
description_2: Persistent issues might be linked to stress, trauma, or sleep apnea (poor quality sleep triggers them).
medicine_2: Usually no meds. Treating underlying anxiety or sleep apnea helps.
doctor_consult_2: See sleep specialist or psychologist if severe.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Calm environment. AVOID: discussing night terrors excessively with the child (they don't remember, it just worries them).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Scheduled awakening (waking child gently 15 mins before usual terror time) can sometimes break the cycle.
description_3: Severe cases in adults might need medication if dangerous actions occur during sleep.
medicine_3: Benzodiazepines sometimes used rarely.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if person becomes violent during episodes.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Patience. AVOID: sleep deprivation.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Most kids outgrow night terrors by age 12.

keywords: gangrene;dead tissue;black toe diabetes;rotten flesh smell;tissue death;foot turning black;no feeling in black area
description_1: Tissue death due to lack of blood flow or severe infection. Area turns black, cold, and shriveled (dry) or swollen, smelly, and oozing (wet).
medicine_1: MEDICAL EMERGENCY. Go to hospital immediately. NO home remedies can save dead tissue.
doctor_consult_1: Consult IMMediately. Delay leads to amputation or death.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: NBM if heading to hospital. AVOID: heating pads on numb/cold toes (causes burns which lead to gangrene in diabetics!).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Keep area clean and dry if waiting for transport.
description_2: Persistent gangrene spreads. Wet gangrene spreads FAST and causes sepsis.
medicine_2: IV antibiotics, surgical debridement (cutting away dead tissue), or revascularization (restoring blood flow) procedures.
doctor_consult_2: See vascular surgeon immediately.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Good blood sugar control is the BEST prevention. AVOID: smoking (major cause of poor blood flow).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Check feet daily if diabetic.
description_3: Severe cases require amputation of the affected limb to save the person's life.
medicine_3: Amputation is a life-saving surgery in advanced gangrene.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: RUSH TO HOSPITAL if you have a black smelly wound or fever with a black area on skin.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Hope - early treatment might save some of the limb. AVOID: denial.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Never ignore a non-healing foot wound if you are diabetic.

keywords: rickets;soft bones kids;bow legs child;knock knees;delayed walking;swollen wrists child;pigeon chest
description_1: Soft, weak bones in children usually due to extreme Vitamin D deficiency. Causes bowed legs, knobbly knees/wrists, delayed growth.
medicine_1: Vitamin D and Calcium supplementation is the cure. Sunlight exposure.
doctor_consult_1: Consult pediatrician if child has noticeably curved legs;delayed teething/walking;or widened wrists.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Fortified milk;eggs;fish;sunlight. AVOID: keeping child indoors all the time;exclusively breastfed for long period without Vitamin D drops.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Gentle sun exposure for babies/toddlers.
description_2: Persistent untreated rickets causes permanent bone deformities and short stature.
medicine_2: High therapeutic doses of Vitamin D and Calcium prescribed by doctor for a few months, then maintenance dose.
doctor_consult_2: See orthopedist if deformities are severe (might need braces or surgery later).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Balanced diet. AVOID: 'malnutrition' - even chubby kids can get rickets if they lack Vitamin D.
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Monitor growth charts.
description_3: Severe cases can cause seizures due to low calcium (hypocalcemic tetany).
medicine_3: Medical emergency requiring IV calcium.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if child has muscle spasms or seizures.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Proper supplementation. AVOID: assuming it's 'just how they are built' if legs are very curved.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Often completely curable if caught early before bones harden in wrong shape.

keywords: amoebiasis;amoeba infection;chronic loose motion;mucus and blood stool;stomach cramps intermittent;weight loss parasite
description_1: Infection by Entamoeba parasite. Often causes chronic, on-and-off diarrhea with mucus/blood, bloating, and cramping for weeks/months.
medicine_1: Metronidazole (Flagyl) or Tinidazole is the specific antibiotic needed. Must complete full course.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if diarrhea >2 weeks;blood in stool;or unexplainable weight loss.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Well-cooked food;boiled water. AVOID: raw salads/street food during infection. alcohol (SEVERE reaction with Metronidazole!).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Wash hands thoroughly. Proper sanitation is key.
description_2: Persistent untreated amoebiasis can spread to LIVER causing an Amoebic Liver Abscess.
medicine_2: Following Metronidazole, a second drug (like Diloxanide) is often given to kill remaining cysts in gut (to prevent carrier state).
doctor_consult_2: See doctor for stool microscopy (3 samples on different days often needed to find the parasite).
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Probiotics after treatment. AVOID: anti-diarrheal meds alone (they don't kill the parasite).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: In endemic areas, regular deworming doesn't always kill amoeba, specific meds needed.
description_3: Severe complication: Amoebic Liver Abscess causes high fever and severe right upper tummy pain.
medicine_3: Requires hospital treatment, sometimes drainage of abscess.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if severe right side abdominal pain and fever develop.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Safe water. AVOID: ice in drinks when traveling.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Carrier state is possible (passing cysts without symptoms) - can infect others.

keywords: seasickness;airsickness;vomiting on boat;nausea flight;travel sickness plane;dizzy on ship
description_1: Specific types of motion sickness. Seasickness is often the worst due to rolling motion.
medicine_1: Look at the horizon. Stay on deck for fresh air (ship). Sit over wings (plane). Take meclizine/dimenhydrinate 1 hour BEFORE travel.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if you have severe intractable vomiting leading to dehydration during long voyages.
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Ginger ale;dry crackers;green apples (anecdotal help). AVOID: heavy/greasy meals;alcohol;reading;staring at screens.
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Acupressure wrist bands (Sea-Bands) help some. Close eyes and try to sleep.
description_2: Persistent sickness usually improves after 2-3 days at sea as brain adapts ('getting sea legs').
medicine_2: Scopolamine patches (worn behind ear) are highly effective for multi-day trips (prescription needed).
doctor_consult_2: See doctor before a cruise if you are anxious about it.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Sips of water. AVOID: staying in cabin if feeling sick (go on deck and look at horizon).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Avoid others who are vomiting (it's contagious psychologically!).
description_3: Severe cases on ships might need injection anti-emetics from ship doctor.
medicine_3: IV fluids if severe dehydration occurs.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: Consult if confusion occurs (rare, severe dehydration).
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Bland food once nausea settles. AVOID: fatalistic attitude - meds work well if taken EARLY.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Don't wait until you feel sick to take the pill, it won't work then.

keywords: acute urticaria;sudden hives;allergic rash body;itchy welts all over;red bumps itchy sudden;reaction to medicine/food
description_1: Sudden outbreak of very itchy red welts, often after a specific trigger (new medicine, insect sting, specific food).
medicine_1: Oral Antihistamine (Cetirizine/Avil) immediately. Calamine lotion. Cool shower.
doctor_consult_1: Consult if hives are severe;spreading fast;or involve face/lips (risk of angioedema/anaphylaxis).
food_suggestions_1: HAVE: Bland diet. AVOID: suspected trigger immediately. Aspirin/NSAIDs (often worsen hives).
lifestyle_suggestions_1: Don't scratch! It releases more histamine and makes it worse. Wear loose cotton clothes.
description_2: Persistent hives >24 hours might need a short course of oral steroids from a doctor to calm the immune system.
medicine_2: Doctor might give an injection of antihistamine/steroid for faster relief in clinic.
doctor_consult_2: See doctor to identify trigger if unknown.
food_suggestions_2: HAVE: Water. AVOID: hot water baths (heat worsens histamine release).
lifestyle_suggestions_2: Keep a record of what you ate/took before it started.
description_3: Severe: Angioedema is deeper swelling (lips/eyes/throat). Throat swelling is an EMERGENCY.
medicine_3: Epinephrine injection needed for throat swelling.
doctor_consult_3: URGENT: CALL AMBULANCE if tongue feels thick, throat feels tight, or breathing is hard.
food_suggestions_3: HAVE: Calm environment. AVOID: panic, stress worsens allergic reactions.
lifestyle_suggestions_3: Most acute attacks settle within 24-48 hours.
